<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Three new MOFs comprising one mixed-donor ligand (5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI) are synthesized and structurally characterized. <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> features 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels and it performs (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> shows a 2D rarely sandwich-like tri-layer, and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8. The fluorescence properties of these three new MOFs were measured at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0025">
<ce:link id="lk00025" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716305381/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Three new metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TZI)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH (<ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>), [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(TZI)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>), and [Cd(TZI)]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>) (JUC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Jilin University China) have been synthesized by self-assembly of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>/Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and a prominent ligand, 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI). <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> exhibits fascinating three-dimensional (3D) structure containing 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and it performs (5,5)-connected topology with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> displays a 2D sandwich-layer which further forms into a 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> exhibits (4,4)-connected 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8. Furthermore, we research the fluorescence properties of these new MOFs measured at room temperature, and the results reveal that <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> display strong main emission spectra peaks at 410, 437 and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Description of the crystal structure of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>Cmcm</ce:italic>. The asymmetric unit contains 0.5 Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations, 0.25 TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, 0.25 <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH and 0.5 coordinated water molecular (). And the 0.25 (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH of guest comes from the hydrolysis of DMF under high pressure and temperature . TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand coordinates with six mental sites by the coordination mode which can be described as <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a). Its conformation is mode-b by the dihedral is 90.0° between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring (). Two kinds of zinc centers (Zn1 and Zn2) are found in the framework. The Zn1 atom is five-coordinated by three oxygen atoms which consist of two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> and one bridging oxygen atom from a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand in the equatorial plane, and two nitrogen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands distribution in the axial position, which forms triangle biconical ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> coordination geometry. While the Zn2 atom is six coordinate by four oxygen atoms from two <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands, two coordinated water molecules and two nitrogen atoms from two different TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands, forming an octahedral geometry. The Zn–O bond distances are from 1.962(4) to 2.128(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Zn–N bond distances are 2.110(5) and 2.362(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). For the interactions between metal sites and ligands described above, triangle [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] SBU are formed by <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH connecting three metal centers (b), these isosceles triangles connected by TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> spacers to form 1D strip-shaped chains further. Adjacent chains linked by <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate groups to form 3D frameworks with 1D rectangular channels (6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>) with taking van der Waals radii into consideration run along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (c). A better insight into the nature of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> can be achieved by the application of a topological approach, that is, reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets (the Topos4.0 program is a powerful tool for the analysis, comparison, and design of network structures) . As shown in , the trimetallic [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] SBU can simply be regarded as a 5-connected node since the terminal H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules do not contribute to the network topology. Likewise, each TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand coordinated to five [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)] clusters can act as a 5-connected node. On the basis of the simplification principle, the resulting structure of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> is a rare binodal five-connected net, and its Schläfli symbol is 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> (d).</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Inspired by the aforementioned above, we opted to use the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI) ligand to coordinate with Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and explore its potential in directing the assembly of extended frameworks based on its flexibility. Successfully, three new MOFs, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(TZI)(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH (<ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>), [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(TZI)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>) as well as [Cd(TZI)]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>) were constructed. It’s notable that for the rotation and bending of the mixed motifs in the ligand, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI behaved various coordination modes and different configurations in the three structures. <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> featured 3D frameworks including 1D rectangular channels with dimensions of 6.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, which performed (5,5)-connected frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> performed 2D sandwich-layer which further form to 3D supermolecular structure by H-bonds reactions, <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> exhibited 3D frameworks with a Schläfli symbol of 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8. Moreover, we describe the luminescence properties of the three MOFs materials measured at room temperature and the results reveal strong main emission spectrum peaks at 410, 437 and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st065">Description of the crystal structure of <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Single crystal X-ray diffraction of <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> reveals that it crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>. The asymmetric unit contains five Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations, three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>anion, one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH and seven terminal coordinated water molecular (). For the TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, three kind of coordination modes were found which can be described as <ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> (type (I)), <ce:italic>μ<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> (type (II)), and <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> (type (III)), respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a and b). It is worth noting that the dihedral between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 58.8°, 45.5°, and 2.2° of the three modes, respectively (). In this structure, there are five kinds of Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> sites. Among them, Cd1, Cd2, Cd3, Cd5 are all six-coordinated octahedral geometry. For Cd1, it is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from two terminal coordinated waters and one bridging oxygen <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand, and three nitrogen atoms from three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands. The Cd2 atom is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligands, two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands and three nitrogen atoms from three different TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands. Cd3 atom is coordinated by five oxygen atoms from one TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, three terminal coordinated waters and one <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand, and one nitrogen atom from one TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand. For Cd5, it is six-coordinated by four oxygen atoms of three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand. While the Cd4 is seven-coordinated which consist of five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, one terminal coordinated water oxygen atom, and one nitrogen atom from TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligand, forming a single-cap triangular prism geometry. The Cd–O bond distances are from 2.267(8) to 2.567(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Cd–N bond distances are 2.346(8) and 2.457(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (). The type (I) and type (II) linkers connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers to form two different 2D layers which are in the top and bottom, respectively. The two layers are like twins for they are very similar which form to a double-layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2 centers (c). In addition, the type (III) linkers as well as <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH ligand connect Cd1, Cd2, Cd3 and Cd4 centers to form another layer in the middle (d). And the intermediate layer is like a mirror which is caught in the middle of the twins-like layers (). Thus, the three monolayers form an overall sandwich-like 2D layer by sharing Cd1, Cd2, Cd4 and Cd5 centers. As we know, the sandwich-like tri-layer structure is rare . There are strong hydrogen bonding interactions (O6W–H⋯O1, O6W–H⋯O3 and O7W–H···O7 distance of 2.9350, 2.9136 and 2.7421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively ()) between adjacent 2D layers. The layers stack each other to form 3D supramolecular frameworks further (e).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st080">Flexible effects of the ligands on the frameworks</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI can be regarded as a partially flexible ligand, where the carboxylate group and the tetrazole/phenl ring can twist and bend freely. In theory, for H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI, there are two ultimate conformations (), the planar conformation (mode-a) and the non-planar conformation (mode-b) with the maximum torsion angle achieves to 90.0° of the two parts belong to the ligand. From the structure descriptions above, it exhibits mode-a conformation with the maximum torsion angle of 90.0° in <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>. However, two conformations are found in <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>, one is the approximative mode-a conformation with torsion angle of just 2.2°, and the other is mode-b conformation with torsion angle of 58.8°and 45.5°. And it is notable that the carboxyl gropes of the three types of linkers twist different angles around the benzene ring in this structure, and even the C–C bond which connect benzene and tetrazolyl rings bent 9.8° and 10.9° respect to the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate plane in type (I) as well as type (II) linkers, respectively (). Thus, H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI performs remarkable flexibility in the framework. In <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, the dihedral between the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-benzenedicarboxylate and tetrazolyl ring is 56.1° (mode-b). Obviously, the outstanding flexible effects of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI meet the complex of the various frameworks.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st085">Thermal analysis and PXRD results</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Thermal stabilities of three new MOFs materials have been measured (). For <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, it is found that there was a weight loss of 8.94% before 110<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponds to the departure of guest (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules (calculated: 9.23%), and the temperature range of 100–280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of the coordinated waters (experimental: 9.31%; calculated: 7.83%), and then the structure decomposed gradually. The residue was 34.73 % corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calculated: 35.38%). For <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 12.91% corresponding to the release of water molecules is observed from 30 to 252<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calculated: 13.56%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 45.08%; calculated: 43.93%). For <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 9.41% corresponding to the departure of guest (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH molecules is observed from 50 to 152<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calculated: 11.07%), and then the structure decomposed. The departure of the structure finally leads to the formation of CdO (experimental: 33.24%; calculated: 31.58%). The PXRD experimental and computer-simulated patterns of the corresponding complexes are shown in . The peak positions of the measured PXRD patterns are in good agreement with the simulated patterns.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st090">Luminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Luminescent properties of MOFs containing d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal centers have attracted intense interest due to their potential applications, such as in chemical sensors, photochemistry, electroluminescent display, and so on . In this work, the solid-state photoluminescent spectra of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI ligand, <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> have been carried out at room temperature (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). The main emission peak of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI is at 377<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>326<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), which can be attributed to the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π or π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n transitions. On complexation of the ligands with Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> atom, the emission peaks occur at 410<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>372<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, 437<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>337<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold>, and 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>. The Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions and Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions are difficult to oxidize or reduce because of the d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration . So the emissions of these compounds are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature. However, for the three complexes, the main emission peak is highly red-shifted by 33, 60 and 38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, relative to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI ligand. It is known that the replacement of the hydrogen proton by Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> or Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions decreases the π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>π or π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>n gap of the carboxylate ligands, resulting in a red shift of the emission peaks . So the emission can be assigned to the chelation of the ligands to the central metals.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st095">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">In conclusion, we have described three MOFs with the 5-tetrazolylisophthalic acid ligand (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI). <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> show different 3D frameworks: in <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, infinite strip-shaped chains in which Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH) triangles are interlinked by TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands into a 3D structure with the point symbol 4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> topology; in <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold>, the unique Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions are linked by TZI<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> ligands with the point symbol 4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>8 topology. And <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> performs a 3D supermolecular structure by strong H-bonds containing rarely 2D sandwich-like tri-layer. Meanwhile, we discussed the interesting flexibility features of this rigid ligand in details, the mixed-donor ligand exhibits wonderful characteristics coordinated with mental centers. Moreover, the luminescence of <ce:bold>JUC-165</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>JUC-166</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>JUC-167</ce:bold> indicated that these MOFs materials may be good candidates for functional materials.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on 10.7778 mg of a polycrystalline sample of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> from ambient temperature to 1100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The TGA data show that three obvious weight loss stages: (1) 100–164<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, weight loss 11.3% possibly corresponding to removing two moles of coordinating water molecules per formula unit (Calc. 11.4%). (2) 200–536<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, weight loss 21.7%. (3) 679–1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, weight loss 27.0%.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a zero-dimensional complex (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>(a)). The octahedral coordination sites of the Co(II) atom are occupied by six oxygen atoms from six different water molecules with CoO from 2.058(4) to 2.148(4) Å. There are many hydrogen bonds linking CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedra, 1,4-butylenediphosphonate ligands and free water molecules ((b)).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The structure of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> has been established previously by X-ray powder diffraction . Herein, we confirm the structure by X-ray single crystal data (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG4"></ce:float-anchor>). The measured CuO bond lengths are 1.942(6), 2.044(5) and 2.412(10) Å based on X-ray single crystal data, while they are 1.962(3), 2.048(3) and 2.293(10) or 2.635(8) Å based on X-ray powder data . In addition, the coordinated water molecules is disorder based on X-ray powder data, while it is not disorder based on X-ray single crystal data.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Using the pip in place of the 4,4′-bpy, the title 3-D compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with a different topology from the former was synthesized. With the pip, NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O forms a 1-D chained SU. The Ni(II) center with an octahedral geometry is coordinated by four Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions and two N atoms from the different pip. The Ni–N bond length [2.118(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] and the average Ni-Cl bond length [2.475<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] are similar to those found in reported [NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)] . Through the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-Cl bridges, all of the Ni(II) centers are linked into a zigzag chain, which can be described as an infinite extension of edge-shared NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> octahedra. The Ni(pip)<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> unit adopts a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-type arrangement. It is noticeable that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays the different porous shapes in different directions. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>, in [100] direction, it takes on a trigonal channel with base 6.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and height 6.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. While in [0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>1] direction, it displays a square hydrophobic channel with the size of 7.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Magnetic property</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Magnetic susceptibility data were determined on the basis of a 10.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg sample over the temperature of 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at a magnetic field of 1 kG on a Quantum Design MPMS-7 SQUID magnetometer. The μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> plot is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor> (left) [μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.83 (<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>)<ce:sup loc="post">1/2</ce:sup>]. The experimental μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> value at 300 K is 3.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>, comparable with the theoretically expected value of 2.83<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> for a d<ce:sup loc="post">8</ce:sup> Ni(II) ion with an octahedral geometry. Upon cooling down, μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> increases continuously up to a maximum of 4.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> at 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, then drops rapidly down to a value of 1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf> at 2 K. The 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve is close to be linear when <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K [see  (right)], being well fitted by using the Curie Weiss law with <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.014<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>emu<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>53.97<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. On the other hand, zero-field splitting is known to occur for Ni(II) ions, and for isolated ions may induce either an increase or a decrease of μ<ce:inf loc="post">eff</ce:inf> value at rather low temperature due to the site distortion of metal ion. Based on both stated above, the observed behavior is thus characteristic of the occurrence of ferromagnetic interactions within the NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> chains due to a plus <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> value, whereas the drop below 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K can be related to antiferromagnetic coupling between the chains as well as the effect of zero-field splitting. A 1-D chain model was used to fit the magnetic data of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, unluckily no ideal result was obtained .</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The plateau observed in the TG curve suggests that the phase stability is retained till 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, whose absorption spectrum is depicted in Kubelka Munk units in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor> (black trace), is a dual luminescent material. Upon irradiation with <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp><<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a strong and narrow band, confined in the UV region, appears. If <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is excited by wavelengths longer than 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, a broad band, included between 400 and 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, emerges (see ). The latter emission, located at lower energy is due to the bispiperidine diphosphonate ligand, since it is detectable also in the pure bispiperidine diphosphonic solid phase. The other emission, recorded only for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, is most likely due to a charge transfer (CT) transition from the oxygen atoms of ligands to the Ce<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> ions; Ce<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are produced that relax by emitting UV radiation. The CT nature of the transition is implicitly confirmed by the large Stokes shift (7138<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and the FWHM of the emission band (3480<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . It gives rise to a peaked band centered at 272<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, as inferred from the shape of the excitation spectrum (blue dashed trace of ).</ce:para>

</mml:math> complexes, we have recognized that there is a special class of cyclic diamidates that have no dicarboxylate analogues and that these could bridge 3 or 4 metal ions leading to coordination polymers. One such ligand, 1,4-dihydro-2,3-dioxyquinoxalinedione (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′), and its <ce:italic>diolate</ce:italic> dianion, 2,3-dioxyquinoxalinate (L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>), are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>; for simplicity the two ligands are shown in the tautomeric forms established by crystallography. Our primary goal in this project is to see how much synthetic chemistry can be accomplished by employing the neutral and anionic forms of this and related ligands (e.g. 2,3-dioxypyrazinate(−2) and 4,6-dioxypyrimidinate(−2)) as linkers for the construction of coordination polymers. A secondary goal is to test the antitumour activity and DNA properties of the <ce:italic>monomeric</ce:italic> (if any) metal complexes with the quinoxaline-based ligands H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ and L<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, since such complexes have a tradition in exhibiting such properties . In the preliminary work reported here, we have sought the answers to two main questions: (i) Can copper(II) coordination polymers be made containing the ligands shown in  (or tautomers thereof)? (ii) How effective will these linkers be in mediating magnetic exchange interactions between Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions?</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) pattern of JUC-188 was measured at room temperature. The characteristic peaks of the as-synthesized sample are closely matched well with those in the simulated patterns from the single crystal structure (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The results confirmed the phase purity of the as-synthesized bulk crystalline materials. From the thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) results, the as-synthesized JUC-188 showed a gradual weight loss before 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C about 19.78%, corresponding to the loss of one [H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] cation, two coordinated water and four DMF guest molecules (calculated 19.44%) (b). The main framework of JUC-188 began to collapse with the increasing of heating temperature. The as-synthesized samples were exchanged with MeOH about three days, and activated at room temperature to obtain the activated samples. However, the activated samples didn't have any N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption, which was mainly ascribed to the collapse of the skeletal structure after removing the solvent molecules (Fig. S2). In addition, the PXRD pattern further indicated that the main framework of the activated samples was collapsed (Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S4, the characteristic peaks of adenine and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligands were both found in the FT-IR spectrum of JUC-188, which undoubtedly exhibited that both organic ligands coexisted in JUC-188.</ce:para>

<ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">Preparation of [H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(ad)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>4DMF: A mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L (15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), adenine (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.06<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added in a mixture solution of DMF (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). Then 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was added in the mixture. The obtain mixture was sealed into a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 135<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for three days. The as-synthesized samples can be obtained after filtration at room temperature. Finally, the yellow block-shaped crystals were washed with fresh DMF and dried in air. Yield: 52.9% (based on the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L). Found: C, 46.57; H, 3.44; N, 16.41. Selected FT-IR data (KBr pellet cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3365 (br), 1714 (s), 1656 (s), 1572 (s), 1449 (s), 1344 (s), 1248 (s), 1157 (s), 1099 (s), 985 (s), 780 (s), 767 (s), 744 (s), 726 (s), 652 (s), 562 (s), 420 (s).</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Using the flexible ligand oxydiacetic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oda), nine heterodimetallic polymers [{Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu) were synthesized and structurally characterized. They are isostructural and possess a highly ordered structure with [CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> as building blocks. The charge is balanced with [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions which occupy the holes of the anionic framework. Magnetic susceptibility measurements of Yb and Eu complexes show deviations from the Curie law mainly owing to the split of the ground term due to the ligand field and to the depopulating of paramagnetic excited states in the Yb and Eu compounds, respectively.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0035">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">► We report the synthesis and structure of nine novel heteropolynuclear complexes. ► The solids have a highly ordered structure with [CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> as building blocks. ► The structures contain [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in the holes of the anionic framework. ► The magnetic properties show isolated paramagnetic ions.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">The change of structure (hexagonal to cubic) in the [Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O complexes also produces materials with different H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake after removing the crystallization water molecules. For example, [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·1.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (hexagonal) exhibits 1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt% of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, while [Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (cubic) does not show hydrogen uptake .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis of [{Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">(Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Dy (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), Tm (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), Lu (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>). The mixture of Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (0.10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) CaCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and 2,2-oxydiacetic acid (80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of water was placed in a Teflon-lined 45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL stainless steel acid digestion vessel and heated at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. The resulting clear solution was allowed to evaporate at room temperature. After some weeks, cubic crystals were obtained. Yield 30–50%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">44</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>Ca<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Ln<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 20.3; H, 3.1 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); C, 20.1; H, 3.1 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), C, 20.0; H, 3.1 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>). Found: C, 20.4; H, 3.3 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); C, 20.3; H, 2.9 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), C, 20.1; H, 2.9 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>)%. TGA diagrams show a single weight loss between room temperature and 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to all water molecules. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc.: 12.7 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); 12.6 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), 12.5 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>). Found: 13.3 (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>); 12.4 (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>), 11.7 (<ce:bold>9</ce:bold>)%. Decomposition point, <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>

<ce:inf loc="post">COC</ce:inf> at 1149<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>(free ligand) is also shifted to <ce:italic>ca.</ce:italic> 1120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> upon complexation.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Europium(III) ion is nine-coordinated, being surrounded by O atoms from three independent oda ligands. [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> building blocks are clearly distinguished in the structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). The Eu–O distances (2.406(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the alkoxo group and 2.469(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the carboxylate groups) are similar to those found in the simple salts of the complex [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> (2.395(2) and 2.495(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) . The angles subtended by the coordinated oda oxygens at the europium atom in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are 63.96(9)° and 73.03(10)°, again very close to those observed in the salts of [Eu(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> (63.4(1)° and 74.3(1)°). Therefore, the formation of the 3D structure does not represent a further strain in the atomic disposition of the building block.</ce:para>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for the χ<ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) and so, the free-ion approximation is good to explain the magnetic behavior at room temperature ().</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Structure of [Co(HPMB)](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·8MeOH·3.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">On complexing HPMB to cobalt(II), a metal ion that generally favours a higher coordination number than does copper(II), the hexadentate ligand utilises all six of its possible oxygen donor atoms in the formation of a contiguous 3D-network. The HPMB ligand is hexanucleating and has crystallographic <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> symmetry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG5"></ce:float-anchor>(a)), a conformation distinctly different from that seen in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The N⋯O vectors of the pyridone rings are inclined by approximately 58° to the central phenyl ring plane. The geometry at cobalt is also <ce:italic>S</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> symmetric ((b)), the <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> angles being 88.2(2) and 91.8(2)°; the CoO distances are all 2.075(4) Å. Relative to two of the opposite faces of the CoO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> octahedron, the triads of pyridone rings form a shallow, dish-like arrangement, with the aryl ring planes inclined by only 24° to the plane of the facial oxygen atoms.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">The furan-2,5-dicarboxyl acid (FDA) is firstly utilized to the construction of MOFs, and the pillars are enlisted in the structural formation by the method of ligand-to-ligand. The pillar properties play an important role in final structure. The flexible bpp (1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane) results in the robust porous [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·(FDA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·bpp·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) with high thermal stability (~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>270<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) and medium CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake (1.65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol/g, 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K), and the rigid bipy (4,4′-bipyridine) in 3-/3-D interpenetrated [Zn·(FDA)·bipy]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>).</ce:simple-para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The thermal stability is an important property for applying for catalyst or gas-storage. The thermogravimetric analysis can render the removal of the guest-molecule and the decomposition of linker and pillar. The in situ XRD discerns the framework change when the guest-molecule is removed and linker and pillar are decomposed.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The gas-storage of MOF is of very interest. In this work, the experiments of gas adsorptions (degassed at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) indicate that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can adsorb CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> instead of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, which is attributed to the strong quadrupole interaction of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas-sorption isotherms for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K indicate that the BET and Langmuir surface area are calculated to be 234.1 and 262.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>/g, and the median pore diameter calculated by H-K method is 4.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates the medium CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake about 1.65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol/g (Fig. S10).</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Two new MOFs — porous robust <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 3-/3-D interpenetrated <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> — have been synthesized and structurally determined. The structural difference is owing to the properties of ligand-to-ligand pillars (flexible bpp for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and rigid bipy for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). As a result, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses the permanent and stable pore which is able to uptake CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> forms the 3-/3-D interpenetrated net.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A novel cobalt(II) complex [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-oxybis benzoic acid, phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) has been synthesized by hydrothermal method and characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, IR, UV–vis, thermal stability and Surface Photovoltage Spectroscopy (SPS). Structural analysis indicated that the complex is a 3D structure with the trinuclear building unit of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] bridged by the oba ligands. The SPS of complex indicates that there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm showing photo-electric conversion properties. There are good relationships between SPS and UV–vis spectra.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Surface photovoltage spectra (SPS) technology, as a very sensitive characterization tool, has been used to detect the charge transitions of the functional semiconductor . Here we report the synthesis , crystal structure , thermal stability and surface photo-electric property of a novel three-dimensional Co(II) complex {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>. It is worthy to note that we used SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra to study the surface electron behaviors under light-induced, and there are positive response bands in the range of 300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm showing photo-electric conversion properties.</ce:para>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>342<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 377<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 568<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, one novel cobalt(II) complex was synthesized and the structure was determined by X-ray single-crystal diffraction. The surface electron behavior and photo-electric property were discussed by SPS. The SPS results of the complex indicated that it possessed clear photovoltaic response bands in UV–vis area (300–600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm), which is photoelectricity conversion. This means that the complex has a certain photo-electric conversion properties. And there are good corresponding relationships between SPS and UV–vis absorption spectra.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Two new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(bpta)<ce:inf loc="post">1/4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cd(tpt)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (tpt<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The results show that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a 3D bor network structure with 56.9% solvent-accessible volume, and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> reveals a novol 3,5-coordinated chiral topology with vertex symbol (4.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8) and 52.5% accessible void in the structure. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were investigated.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Two new three-dimensional (3D) porous metal-organic frameworks, [Ni(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(bpta)<ce:inf loc="post">1/4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cd(tpt)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bpta)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (tpt<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>(1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid) have been prepared, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. The resulted MOFs reveal highly accessible voids. Moreover, gas adsorption properties of desolvated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were investigated.<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0020">
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Among the multidentate pyridine ligands investigated in this field, 2,4,6-tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (tpt) is of specially interest in recent years. Its rigidity and triangular geometry can lead to MOFs bearing various structures and interesting topologies when employed in the reactions with metal ions  and the resulted compounds also show attractive properties such as host-guest functions, magnetic and drug delivery . However, in despite of the high solvent-accessible volume of the resulting frameworks or cages, none of the tpt constructed porous frameworks have been studied with their gas adsorption properties to the best of our knowledge. As the combination of tpt and carboxylic acid ligand resulted in MOFs with novel structures and interesting properties , our goal is to design and synthesize porous MOFs with tpt and various carboxylic acid ligands. Herein, we report two novel microporous metal–organic frameworks constructed by Ni(II)/Cd(II) and tpt associated with (1,1'-biphenyl)-2,2',6,6'-tetracarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta) (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The resulted MOFs were characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, IR spectra, PXRD, and TG analysis. Also, the resulted MOFs reveal high solvent-accessible volume and novel topologies. Furthermore, their gas adsorption properties were investigated.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) studies indicated that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> occurred significant peak broadening after the vacuum activation of sample and the only obvious peak show a movement toward high angle field. These indicated a decrease of cell volume and much smaller crystalline domains which might be attributed to the shrink of framework caused by internal tension and evaporation of solvent. It is interesting that the new PXRD pattern can be reverted to that of the pristine sample by soaking the activated sample in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. These results are indicative of a breathing phenomenon during the activate process . In the case of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the pattern recorded after vacuum activation show much smaller crystalline domains comparing with well crystallized sample due to the sensitivity of activated sample to oxygen and moisture in the air.</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">Preliminary gas sorption studies were performed with activated <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption isotherm of both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows type I gas sorption behavior indicative of microporous structure. The vacuum-dried sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibited a Langmuir surface area of 393<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (a S<ce:inf loc="post">A</ce:inf>BET of 299<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) whereas the sample of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> gave a Langmuir surface area of 442<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (a S<ce:inf loc="post">A</ce:inf>BET of 336 m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>g<ce:sup loc="post">-1</ce:sup>). Hydrogen adsorption isotherms measured at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K reveal an uptake of 65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmHg for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Similarly, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> afford an uptake of 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmHg. Both uptakes of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are relatively low considering the highly porous nature of these MOFs materials, presumably because of the blockage of the cavity and channel in the activated sample accordingly to the change of structure during the activation process. Better results were expected by the enhancement of porosity using proper activating method .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In summary, two porous MOFs were successfully constructed by Ni(II)/Cd(II), Tpt and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta. Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> display high solvent-accessible volumes, and their gas adsorption properties were investigated. The successful preparation of these coordination polymers provides a potential sense into the rational design and synthesis of metal–organic frameworks with interesting structures and properties in the future.</ce:para>

<ce:simple-para id="sp0050" view="all">Synthesis of [Ni(tpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2/3</ce:inf>(bpta)<ce:inf loc="post">1/4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)]⋅solve (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). Ni(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (58.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added to 18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL 1:1 (v/v) mixture of methanol and water containing tpt (15.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta (16.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg,0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) under stirring. The green suspension was then sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 140 °C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. Upon cooling to room temperature, octahedron green crystals were obtained (ca. 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 50% yield based on Ni). Crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected, washed with methanol, and dried in air. Anal. found: C, 42.24; H, 4.97; N, 8.66%.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st090">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new ligand 1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene was synthesized. Three cobalt complexes were obtained using different preparation methods. Both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have 3D structures by layering diffusion method. While complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has an infinite 1D chain structure under hydrothermal method. The thermal stability property of them are investigated. The absorption property of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is studied.<ce:display>

<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Following this approach and also as an extension of our work, we are carrying out the research on the coordination chemistry of 1H-imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand. A compound with two different substituted imidazole groups, 1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene (HL), was designed and prepared. Herein, we report three novel Co(II) complexes with the HL ligand, namely, {H[CoL<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·4.17MeOH·13.3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) based on the different preparation methods. The stabilities properties of the complexes are also investigated.</ce:para>

After four weeks, pink block crystals of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained with a yield of 29%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Co (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>): C, 48.78; H, 4.09; N, 18.96. Found: C, 48.80; H, 4.05; N, 18.95%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3453 (s), 3134 (ms), 1620 (ms), 1522 (s), 1454 (m), 1383 (m), 1310 (s), 1259 (s), 1162 (m), 1133 (s), 1073 (s), 964 (ms), 947 (ms), 835 (s), 746 (s), 645 (s).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st045">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st050">Description of the crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The result of X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in high symmetry of cubic form with space group of <ce:italic>Pn</ce:italic>-3 and the asymmetric unit has a one-sixth Co(II) atom sitting on a special position with a one-sixth occupancy, half of the deprotonated L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand, solvent water molecules and methanol molecules. Every Co(II) center in the framework is octahedral coordinated. Considering the balance of the charge, the anionic charge of framework is balanced by a proton H<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>, which could not be located by X-ray diffraction, but are probably bound to the nucleophilic N atoms of imidazole rings, or one of the solvent water molecules was protonated. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Co(II) atom is coordinated by six nitrogen atoms from six individual L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands with distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The Co–N distance of 2.141(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and N–Co–N bond angles of 91.77(1)°, 88.23(1)° and 180° are typical for the octahedral Co–N<ce:inf loc="post">im</ce:inf> coordinations . On the other hand, each L<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligand acts as a linear ligand to link two Co(II) atoms with a Co–Co separation of 13.66<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. It is noteworthy that only one of the two nitrogen atoms of the deprotonated imidazol-4-yl group coordinates with the Co(II) atom.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The results of X-ray crystallographic analysis revealed that complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in monoclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>/<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> (), its symmetry is far less than complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> which crystallizes in cubic space group. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> consists of a half of Co(II) atom, two-thirds of HL ligands, one coordinated water molecule, one solvent water molecule and a ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion. As displayed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Co(II) atom is six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from four different HL ligands and two oxygen atoms of water molecules. The Co–O bond length is 2.095(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the Co–N bond lengths are 2.145(2) and 2.147(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The N(112)–Co–N(112A) and O(1)–Co–O(1A) bond angles are 180°, the other bond angles are in the range of 88.24(9)–91.76(9)°.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0100" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is stable up to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, weight loss of 6.45% (calcd 6.09%) from 130 to 225<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is attributed to the dehydration of the coordinated water molecules, then the weight loss occurs in a consecutive step and does not stop until heating to 750<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (). The XRD patterns of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as-synthesized samples were consistent with simulated from crystal as shown in .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st070">Gas sorption property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">As we discussed above, the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable even up to 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Before gas adsorption tests, the activation for removing the guest molecules from the pores by heating in vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, approximately 22.0317<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (1.30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> per gram of solvent-free sample was adsorbed at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm with a pore volume of 0.09<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g (median pore width is 6.61<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), the sorption behavior is characteristic for the microporous structure .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Reported herein are two porous interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks tuned by the length of organic linker. Shorter BDC linker and [Cd(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] building blocks in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> generate a rare 4-connected 2-fold interpenetrating qtz network. But longer NDC linker in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> produces a self-penetrated 8-connected bcu framework with [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] SBUs. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both show selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption and significantly, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and P/P<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.95) among all the interpenetrated MOFs.</ce:simple-para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">More recently, we report a 3-fold self-interpenetrated Zn-carboxylate MOF, which presents an unprecedented 1D channel partition <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> interpenetration into polyhedral cages . The unique structural feature contributed to not only the highest CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake capacity but also strongest CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> affinity among the interpenetrated MOFs. As an extension of this work, we demonstrated herein two interpenetrated anionic Cd-carboxylate frameworks effectively tuned by the length of organic linkers, namely, {[(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cd(BDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(NDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (BDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>terephthalic acid, NDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid). As we expected, interpenetrated MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both have small pore sizes, and show selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption. Significantly, MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits the highest water vapor uptake performance (281<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>) at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.95 among the interpenetrated MOFs.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Notably, as mentioned above, penetrated Cd-carboxylate frameworks <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both possess 1D channel along <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-direction. PLATON calculations show that they have 61.8% and 48.6%, respectively, potential guest-accessible volumes. These prominent structure features provoke us to study their porosity. However, the N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption isotherms at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K indicate negligible uptakes for the MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> activated at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which is probably due to their small pore sizes introduced by the interpenetration and also blocked by the charge-balanced cations. It should be pointed out similar N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake results had also been found in an iso-structure of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> obtained in DMF solvent . Furthermore, the porosity of these two MOFs was supported by the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption at 195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S3a). The corresponding BET surface area is 372<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 154<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. It should be noted that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a pressure-dependent, stepwise CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption–desorption isotherms at 195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which further support the dynamic twofold interpenetrating frameworks.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The low-pressure CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Under 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar, the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptakes at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K reach 42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (1.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 8.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%) for MOF <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (1.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 4.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%) for MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). At 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar, MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can absorb CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> of 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (1.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 4.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%) and 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (0.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, 2.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>wt.%). Although such CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption capacity is not high, these values still outperform many previously reported interpenetrated MOFs such as SNU-71 , YO-MOF  and so on. Compared to the no-interpenetrated MOFs, the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption capacity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is also higher than a lot of famous MOFs such as ZIF-8 , MOF-2 , SNU-31 , and ZIF-100  at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm. Clearly, take the negligible N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption into account, interpenetrated porous MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit dramatically selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake performance, which may be due to the small pore size introduced by interpenetration and the charged frameworks of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To further understand the above adsorption properties, the isosteric heat (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>) of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption was calculated using the experimental isotherm data at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (Fig. S3(b)). The <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> value of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is similar to those of some classical porous materials. The high initial <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be mainly ascribed to the strong interactions between the charged framework and CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules. Then, the <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>st</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> falls to 17.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at loadings of 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, but increases up to 21.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> at maximum loadings, which was attributed to increasing CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> interactions. For MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, its value at zero coverage is estimated to be about 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and increases slowly with increasing CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> loading. Finally, the value got to about 21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ·mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. It is noted that these <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf> values are comparable to a lot of famous MOFs such as CuBTTri , MOF-253 , and MAF-26  even though no open-metal sites and Lewis base sites exist in the framework of MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The adsorption of water vapor by porous solids is important for many applications, such as dehumidification, thermal batteries, and requiring capture and release of water. More recently, MOFs have been demonstrated to be promising water vapor adsorption materials . Herein, we further show that high and steep water vapor uptake at low relative pressure can be achieved by our interpenetrated Cd-NDC MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The water vapor adsorption isotherm of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is shown in b. Notably, the maximum water uptake at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K reaches 281<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> under <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.95 (where <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> is the vapor pressure at saturation). The maximum water uptake of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is comparable to the values of Basolite A100  and another cadmium(II) MOF  reported by D. F. Li, which are 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 249<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>·g<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, respectively, Significantly, this value is much higher than a lot of MOF material, including CAU-10 functionalised by –NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, −<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and –OCH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> groups , DUT-84 (Zr) , and Fe-MOFs reported by Tapas Kumar Maji . To the best of our knowledge, the water vapor adsorption capacity of MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K outperforms all previously reported interpenetrated MOFs.</ce:para>
['property']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In conclusion, we demonstrated that the regulation of the bulk of linkers can lead to two 3D interpenetrated porous Cd-MOFs exhibiting 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>qtz and</ce:italic> self-penetrated <ce:italic>bcu</ce:italic> nets. The small pore size introduced by interpenetration and charged frameworks contribute a dramatically selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake. In particular, Cd-NDC MOF shows the highest water vapor uptake performance among all the interpenetrated MOFs. Further exploration of interpenetrated porous frameworks with selective adsorption ability is ongoing.</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Using monoalkyl substituted azoles 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), 2-ethylimidazole (Heim), 3-methyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hmtz), and 3-ethyl-1,2,4-triazole (Hetz) as starting materials, six binary MAFs, namely SOD-[Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-4), ANA-[Zn(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-5), SOD-[Zn(mtz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-7), <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold>-[Zn(mim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-31), <ce:bold>qtz</ce:bold>-[Zn(eim)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-32), and <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold>-[Zn(etz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (MAF-33) were obtained. Single-crystal structures of as-synthesized MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were first described in our previous communications . The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O sorption behaviors of isostructural MAF-4 and MAF-7 were also discussed, but the sorption property of MAF-5 has not been observed. Crystal structures of MAF-31  and MAF-32  were reported by other groups very recently, while MAF-33 has not been reported. To better understand the relationship among synthesis, structure, and property, single-crystal structures of guest-free MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7 were measured and compared with the nonporous compounds.</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:section-title>Thermal and chemical stability</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">As shown by the TG curves (), all obtained MAFs are stable up to at least 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, except that MAF-7 decomposed just above 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. It should be noted that there is virtually no observable weight loss below the decomposition temperatures, indicating that the as-synthesized powder samples of porous MAFs can be easily activated by routine drying procedures, which is a remarkable improvement as compared to the common solvothermal methods using amides as solvents . Thermal stabilities of the porous MAFs were further checked by variable-temperature PXRD analyses, which revealed that MAF-7 collapsed above 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (), being much lower than for MAF-4 and MAF-5 (>400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) .</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0165" view="all">The high thermal and chemical stabilities of MAFs are closely related to their unique structures such as strong coordination bonds and hydrophobic pore surfaces. The relatively low stability of MAF-7 should be attributed to the unbound nitrogen atoms close to the unsaturated Zn centers (Zn···N 2.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
