<ce:section-title>Sorption property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0170" view="all">Gas sorption isotherms (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 273 and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) were measured for the porous MAFs. The gas sorption data of the SOD frameworks are basically identical to our previous reports measured on the samples synthesized from soluble Zn(II) salts . According to their crystal structures, MAF-4 and MAF-7 show very similar and high porosity, while MAF-7 possesses much higher adsorption affinity for gas molecules. The porosity of ANA framework MAF-5 is lower than the SOD frameworks (), but still larger than most zeolites such as ZSM-5. The gas sorption affinity of MAF-5 is in between MAF-4 and MAF-7 (), because MAF-5 has smaller channel size and contains no pore surface active site.</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0175" view="all">Water, methanol, and benzene sorption isotherms were also measured at room temperature. Virtually no water adsorption can be observed for the MAF-4 and MAF-5, demonstrating they are very rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high porosity. In contrast, MAF-7 have been shown moderate hydrophilicity and interesting water sorption behavior () . The MeOH sorption behaviors of these porous MAFs are very different from those for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. As illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>, all the three materials can adsorb large amounts of MeOH corresponding to their pore volumes. All the sorption isotherms can be described as being type-IV, with abrupt increases of uptakes started at <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.13, 0.12, and 0.015 for MAF-4, MAF-5, and MAF-7, respectively. The type-IV isotherms indicate that the host–guest interactions are weaker than the guest–guest ones. In other words, at low relative pressures, the adsorbents form weak interactions with the hydroxyl group and methyl groups of MeOH. Capillary condensation above the onset pressures are ascribed to hydrogen-bonding interactions among the adsorbed MeOH molecules. The lowest onset pressure of MAF-7 should be ascribed to the presence of uncoordinated nitrogen donors on its pore surface.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0180" view="all">Despite that the static window sizes are much smaller than the size of benzene (3.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>), the SOD MAFs can readily adsorb large amounts of benzene (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>). Similar to the case of MeOH, the onset pressure of benzene for MAF-7 is also lower than for MAF-4. Interestingly, MAF-5 starts to adsorb benzene at very low pressure (not detected), which should be due to the strong host–guest interaction (hydrophobic pore surface for hydrophobic guest) and the suitable pore sizes (slightly larger than that of benzene). The good hydrophilic/hydrophobic selectivities of MAF-4 and MAF-5 are useful for organic solvent/water separation. Especially, MAF-5 may be used for the removal/recycle of trace benzene in water.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0185" view="all">The adsorption of larger molecules for MAF-4, -5, and -7 were semi-quantitatively monitored by TG analyses (). The activated samples of MAF-4, -5 and -7 were exposed in the saturated vapors of toluene (3.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) and <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-xylene (3.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) for 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days before TG measurements. Adsorption on the outer surface is excluded by the observed significant weight losses. The large adsorption of organic molecules for MAF-5 demonstrates its ability as a hydrophobic adsorbate with high organic/water selectivity. As the molecular sizes of toluene and <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-xylene are significantly larger than the aperture sizes of the SOD MAFs, structural transformation must occur . PXRD patterns of the solvent-loaded frameworks are reminiscent with the original host frameworks (), implying that the transformations occur during non-equilibrium states, i.e. the small windows only open temporarily to allow guest diffusion .</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0200" view="all">The obtained porous MAFs show higher chemical stability compared with other preparation methods, which is tentatively assigned to the impact of different impurity. Sample activation is also easier because no high-boiling point solvent is employed. Sorption behaviors of the porous MAFs can be explained by their pore size and surface properties. Due to the complete coordination of nitrogen donors and alkyl-lined pore surface, the imidazolate frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-5 are rare hydrophobic adsorbents with high pore volumes, which can easily adsorb large amount of organic solvent but do not adsorb water even at very high humidity. As the pore size is similar to small aromatic derivatives such as benzene and toluene, MAF-5 is suitable for removal of trace aromatic molecules from water. On the other hand, the large pore MAF-4 exhibits lower adsorption affinity for organic solvents, and significant adsorption arise from capillary condensation. While MAF-7 is isostructural with MAF-4, incorporation of uncoordinated nitrogen donor on the pore surface increases the sorption affinity and lowers the onset pressure of capillary condensation. Finally, the SOD frameworks MAF-4 and MAF-7 can readily adsorb guest molecules obviously larger than their aperture sizes via temporary distortion of their frameworks.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st070">Crystal structure of {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hdatrz)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents a wave-like two-dimensional (2D) layer with dimeric {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> subunits extended by three-branched NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligands. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains two Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> octahedra, one neutral Hdatrz molecule, two doubly deprotonated NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions in the same binding mode and half a free water molecule. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, both unique Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions are in the distorted N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> donor sets defined by one triazolyl group of Hdatrz ligand, one amino group from a NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, one bidentate chelating and two bidentate bridging carboxylate groups from three separate NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions. The Co–O and Co–N separations are between 2.0404(19) and 2.2704(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (), which are comparable with those cobalt(II)-based complexes with triazolyl and carboxylate ligands .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st090">PXRD and thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Experimental and computer-simulated PXRD patterns of the four bulk products were in good agreement with each other (), indicating their phase purity and the structural consistency as the synthesized samples. TG experiments of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were carried out in order to explore their thermal stability (). As a result, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displayed a slight weight-loss process between 60 and 145<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the release of the lattice water molecule, and was followed by a rapid weight-loss stage between 376 and 550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the decomposition of the layered structure. The remaining residue of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was calculated to be CoO above 550<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (expt. 25.5%, calc. 25.7%). Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibited one continuous weight-loss process above 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the continuous removal of methanol and the combustion of the mixed ligands. The final product of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> above 445<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C was calculated to be CoO (expt. 21.6%, calc. 20.4%). Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> showed a two-step weight-loss stage between 60 and 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the slow release of disordered lattice molecules (expt. 8.3%, calc. 8.4%). Once the temperature was higher than 427<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the polymeric backbone collapse of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> occurred, which was completely finished at the highest temperature measured. Complex <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was thermally stable up to 241<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and was accompanied by a continuous weight-loss process between 241<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 315<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for the remove of lattice water molecule (expt. 6.1%, calc. 4.7%). The second obvious weight-loss stage between 370 and 533<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C was resulting from the decomposition of the mixed ligands, leaving Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> as final product of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> (expt. 22.2%, calc. 21.6%).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st095">Magnetic properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Variable temperature (2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) magnetic susceptibilities of the crystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were measured under an applied direct current (dc) magnetic field of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe. As presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>a, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value for each binuclear subunit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is 6.20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which is much higher than the spin-only value (3.75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) expected for two high-spin Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> octahedra (<ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2, <ce:italic>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2) due to the significant orbital contribution. The <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> product decreases continuously with the lowering temperature and reaches a value of 1.47<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Furthermore, the plot of <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> above 26.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K obeys the Curie-Weiss law with <ce:italic>C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.33<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>θ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−6.73<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (). Because the spin–orbit coupling can contribute the negative value of <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>, the small <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may imply weak magnetic interaction between Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions. From the viewpoints of the magnetostructural relationship, the magnetic couplings of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> substantially occurred within the binuclear subunit due to the short intermetallic distance (3.6810(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) by one μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and two bidentate bridging carboxylate bridges. Thus, the experimental susceptibility of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was analyzed with an exchange-coupled high-spin cobalt(II) dimer consisting of the spin–orbit coupling (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>), low-symmetry (noncubic) crystal-field term (zero field splitting parameter <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>), magnetic exchange between Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>) and Zeeman interaction using a MagSaki software  in the whole temperature range, leading to <ce:italic>D<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>132<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>λ<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−82<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>J<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−1.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, Δ (axial-splitting parameter)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>543, <ce:italic>κ</ce:italic> (orbital reduction factor)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.92, <ce:italic>g<ce:inf loc="post">z</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.3, <ce:italic>g<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5.0. The parameters of <ce:italic>D</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>, Δ, <ce:italic>κ</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>g<ce:inf loc="post">z</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> and <ce:italic>g<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> are comparable with the reported binuclear Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes with the triple bridges . The small and negative value of <ce:italic>J</ce:italic> confirms the weak antiferromagnetic coupling in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> mediated by one μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz and two bidentate bridging carboxylate bridges. Additionally, a peak at 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K is observed in the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve under 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe, indicating an antiferromagnetic ordering of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at low field (a inset). Once the external magnetic field is higher than 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe, the peak in the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> versus <ce:italic>T</ce:italic> curve disappears (), suggesting a metamagnetic transition of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at high fields.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The magnetization of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> measured at 2.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K gives a sigmoid-shaped increase with the increased external magnetic field (b). The magnetization at the highest field (5.23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>Nβ</ce:italic>) is the same as that for two octahedral Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions with <ce:italic>S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1/2 and <ce:italic>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
</ce:italic>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.1–5.0, indicating a weak ferromagnetic state of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at high field. This behavior indicates a metamagnetic transition of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with critical field of <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic> 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe determined by the d<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>/d<ce:italic>H</ce:italic> curve (b inset). The metamagnetism of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be rationalized to be a result of the competition between magnetic coupling within the binuclear subunit and the external field. At the low fields, the anti-parallel alignment of the magnetic moments from the binuclear subunits can lead to an antiferromagnetic ordering. Once the field exceeds 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe, weak intra-subunit antiferromagnetic interaction can be overcome by the enhanced field to lead to a weak ferromagnetic state of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Four isostructural transition metal-based MIL-53 anologues, [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; Co, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; Zn, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; Cd, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>; ntd = 1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), are urothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), elemental analysis (EA) and Infrared Spectroscopy (IR). The results of TGA and PXRD for these isostructural compounds show that they exhibit distinct thermal behaviors, where the Zn- and Cd-forms are much easier to lose the ligated e-urea molecules from the frameworks than the Mn- and Co-forms. The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption properties and photoluminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were also investigated.</ce:simple-para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Herein, we report the urothermal synthesis, structures and properties of four new coordination polymers: [M(ntd)(e-urea)] (M = Mn, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; Co, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>; Zn, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>; Cd, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>; ntd = 1,4-Naphthalenedicarboxylate; e-urea = ethyleneurea), by using ethyleneurea hemihydrate as solvent. The most interesting point of this work is the distinct thermal behavior presented by four isostructural compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. The Zn- and Cd-forms can breathe out the ligated e-urea molecules at related low temperature; however it is difficult for the Mn- and Co-forms to lose e-urea. The reason for such difference is analyzed and discussed by considering the detailed bonding nature of these compounds.</ce:para>

C 50.72, H 3.41, N 7.89; found C 51.27, H 3.39, N 7.82. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3276(w), 3060(w), 1594(s), 1476(w), 1384(s), 1073(w), 920(w), 785(w), 648(w).</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were investigated under the flowing nitrogen atmosphere (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). Unusually, they exhibit two kinds of thermal behavior. The TG curves of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> only show one platform from room temperature to 370 °C, then the ligand decomposition makes the whole framework totally collapse. In comparison, there are two obvious platforms in the TG plots of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, The first weight loss of 24% from 280 to ca. 330 °C corresponds to the full liberation of e-urea molecules (calcd: 23.6%), and the remaining framework [Zn(ntd)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> shows no weight loss up to ca. 400 °C. The compared powder X-ray diffraction patterns further confirm that the framework [Zn(ntd)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> does not change at 300 °C, but it shifts to an unknown phase after full removal of the e-urea ligands at 350 °C (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). The total solvent-accessible volume of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is estimated to be 34.9% using the PLATON program . The TGA curve of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is similar to that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, but <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> has higher thermal stability than <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. As demonstrated by the powder X-ray diffraction patterns, the framework of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> does not change at 350 °C.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas adsorption measurements of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> at 273 K performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer were investigated, which further confirm the porosity in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Both samples of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were activated under vacuum at 300 °C for 2 days, respectively. A significant increase in the amount of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas adsorbed by each sample was observed as with an increase in the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> pressure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>), indicating the diffusion of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules into the channels. The CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake at 1 atm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were 6.7 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g and 13.6 cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>/g, respectively. The higher CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake capacity of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> than that of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> may be due to the higher framework stability of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The solid state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> have been investigated at room temperature. Both compounds exhibit similar intense fluorescent emission bands with peak maximum at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 400 nm for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 425 nm for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> upon excitation at <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 350 nm (). Considering the natural photoluminescent property of the free ntd ligand , the emission spectra of both compounds may be attributed to an intraligand emission state.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The thermal stabilities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are investigated through TGA experiments in the temperature range of 35–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C as shown in Fig. S7. An initial weight loss of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> below 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of N, N-dimethylformamide on the surface of the compounds. Upon further heating the organic ligand and the ammonium ions start to decompose and exhibit a weight loss of 73.30% between 165 and 393<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (calcd: 75.86%). The final product of 25.86% is attributed to the formation of CuO powder.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first step weight loss of 3.75% below 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the removal of water molecules (calcd: 4.70%). The second weight loss that occurred from 273 to 462<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (68.38%) can be attributed to the decomposition of the 1,2-diaminopropane and the HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> ligand (calcd: 70.24%). The final residuals of 30.85% are attributed to the formation of CuO powder.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Three new coordination polymers containing 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylate (pytac) with cobalt, vanadium oxide, or cadmium iodide have been synthesized solvothermally, isolated, and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction and powder X-ray diffraction. <ce:para view="all">
<ce:italic>[Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(pytac)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:italic>: Single-crystal X-ray structure analysis shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a unique 3D structure with 1D channels in the [101] direction that contain eight water molecules, comprising 14.4% (872.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) of the unit cell volume. There are three crystallographically distinct pytac ligands and two crystallographically distinct Co centers which have octahedral coordination spheres (Co1{N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} and Co2{N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}) with Co2 on a <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> axis. The asymmetric unit is shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>
. Co1 is coordinated to four pytac ligands (two chelating and two non-chelating). Both non-chelating pytac ligands coordinate axial or equatorially to the Co1 center via the pyridyl nitrogen atoms as shown in <ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>
a (Co(1)–N(4)#1 (axial pytac)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.1313(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Co(1)–N(6) (equatorial pytac)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.1267(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Two of the three remaining Co1 equatorial sites are occupied by two oxygen atoms (O1 and O2) from a chelating pytac ligand (Co(1)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.1059(12)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Co(1)–O(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.2656(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The remaining axial and equatorial sites of the Co1 center are occupied by the fourth pytac ligand which chelates via N3 (axial) and O3 (equatorial) (Co(1)–N(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.1863(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Co(1)–O(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>2.0303(12)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (a).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">To study the stability of the three compounds, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on polycrystalline samples in nitrogen atmosphere. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 4.08% from 160 to 279<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is equivalent to the loss of one free water molecule per formula unit (ca. 3.96%), indicating the presence of hydrogen bonding interactions. After 317<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the decomposition of the framework starts. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the thermogravimetric analysis shows that there is no weight loss up to 360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, where the entirely decomposition of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> starts. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the weight loss of 6.78% (calculated: 6.61%) from 45 to 134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, is attributed to the loss of two free water molecules per formula unit. Complete decomposition of the framework starts after 415<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Large size cadmium chalcogenido clusters with ruthenium complex cations are prepared.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Cation–anion charge-transfer property is found for these chalcogenido materials.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The intensity of photocurrent is related to the cluster size and the chalcogenido elements of the clusters.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="sectitle0030">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Cadmium chalcogenido quantum dots have attracted much attention because of their intriguing and unique optoelectronic properties. Synthetic challenges in this field include controlling the size and size distribution of the nanoparticles and modifying structure . Large nanosized cadmium chalcogenido clusters have not only the definite structures, but also the extremely low limit of the size distribution and high stability. Therefore, a ‘bottom-up’ approach to the synthesis of well defined large cadmium chalcogenido clusters has been recognized as a key to developing the semiconductor quantum dots technologically . These clusters generally fall into three series: supertetrahedral clusters (T<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>), pentasupertetrahedral clusters (P<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>), and capped tetrahedral clusters (C<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>) . The most exploited large size clusters CdQ (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic> = S and Se) are the C<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> clusters having 17 , 32 , and 54  cadmium atoms in the clusters (). Besides the potential applications as quantum dots, they could serve as model systems and provide synthetic and structural insights into the formation and properties of nanomaterials. The recent challenges in the CdQ clusters field include functionalizing the cluster materials with counterions or substituents having unique photo or electrochemical properties, such as metal 1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) complexes and methyl viologe .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0045">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">C2-CdSSeRuBpy (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">[Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>]. The precursor Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (3.0 mg, 0.010 mmol), selenourea (1.0 mg, 0.008 mmol), and Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0 mg, 0.0013 mmol) were mixed in 2 mL acetonitrile and the mixture was placed in a 10 cm long thick Pyrex glass tube. The sealed tube was heated under autogenous pressure at about 110 °C for 7 days to yield dark red block crystals. The crystals were washed by ethanol, dried, and stored under vacuum (35% yield based on Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). Elemental analysis: C<ce:inf loc="post">258</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">214</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>RuCd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf> (9420.49): calcd: C 32.89, H 2.29, N 0.89%; found: C 33.21, H 2.48, N 1.03%. Selected IR data (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3446(m), 3130(w), 1638(m), 1574(m), 1472(s), 1433(m), 1384(m), 1114(w), 1080(m), 1020(w), 741(vs), 689(vs).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0065">C1-CdSSeRuBpy (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">[Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>][Cd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]. The precursor Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (3.0 mg, 0.010 mmol), selenourea (1.0 mg, 0.008 mmol) and Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0 mg, 0.0013 mmol) were mixed in a 2 mL solvent of acetonitrile/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (3:1 in V/V), and the mixture was placed in a 10 cm length thick Pyrex glass tube. The sealed tube was heated under autogenous pressure at about 85 °C for 5 days to yield orange block crystals. The crystals were washed by ethanol, dried and store under vacuum (25% yield). Elemental analysis: C<ce:inf loc="post">174</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">144</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>RuCd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (5736.03): calcd: C 36.43, H 2.53, N 1.47; found: C 35.21, H 2.69, N 1.71. <ce:section-title id="sectitle0105">Description of charge-transfer property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0105" view="all">Optical diffuse-reflection UV–vis spectra were measured at room temperature using BaSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> as a standard reference. The absorption spectra of the compounds were calculated from the data of diffuse-reflectance and are depicted in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>. Spectra of three C2 compounds are showed in (a). The intense broad bands at about 3.4 eV for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (Se) and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Se) and 3.8 eV for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (S) with the onset energy about 2.85 eV for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and 3.20 eV for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are assigned to the cluster-centered excitation, which indicates that the selenide has the narrower energy gap than that of the sulfide. The band at about 2.75 eV is assigned to the metal-to-ligand charge-transfer (MLCT) absorption of the [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations , which is also the evidence of the presence of these cations in the compounds. The onset energy of the MLCT is about 2.1 eV, which extends the photo absorption to the visible range that significantly narrows the energy gaps of the materials. Based on the results of our previous studies, the shoulder peaks in above 2.9 eV are assigned to charge-transfer bands from cluster anion to [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation (ACCT) , which overlapped with the MLCT band. (b) shows the spectra difference of the C1 and C2 compounds with the same [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations. Comparing to C2 cluster, the onset energy 3.10 eV for C1 cluster <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> shifts to the blue side due to the decreased size of the cluster.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">The charge-transfer property of the compounds can be further illustrated by cyclic voltammetric study ((c)). The oxidation peak of the [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation is 1.29 V in acetonitrile (<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1/2</ce:inf>, vs. SCE, oxidation onset potential 1.15 V), while that of compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is observed at about 1.25 V (<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1/2</ce:inf>) (Δ<ce:italic>E</ce:italic> = 40 mV, oxidation onset potential 1.10 V) under the same experimental conditions. The negative shift of the Ru(III)/Ru(II) redox potential is due to the charge transfer from the cadmium chalcogenido cluster anion to the [Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation, considering also the charge-transfer band appeared in spectra. The negative scan of compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> under Ar atmosphere shows a reduction peak of the cluster at about −1.0 V with the onset potential −0.8 V ().</ce:para>

AbstractIn order to stabilise six-membered alicyclic ether guests through a hydrogen bond with an H2O ligand in the host, Hofmann-H2O-type [Cd(H2O)2Ni(CN)4] and Hofmann-H2O-Td-type [Cd(H2O)2Cd(CN)4] hosts were examined for accomodating 1,4-dioxane and morpholine as probable guests. The single crystal structures of the eventually obtained morpholine-ligated complex [Cd(C4H9NO)2Ni(CN)4] (1) and 1,4-dioxane-guest clathrates, [Cd(H2O)2Ni(CN)4]·2C4H8O2 (2) and [Cd(H2O)2Cd(CN)4]·2C4 H8O2 (3), are closely related in topology with previously known [Cd(py)2Ni(CN)4], [Cd(NH3)2Ni(CN)4]·2C4H8O2 and [Cd(NH3)2Cd(CN)4] ·2C6H6, respectively, but involve hydrogen bonds between the morpholine ligands in 1, and between the aqua ligand of the host and the guest 1,4-dioxane in 2 and 3. Complex 1 crystallises in the orthorhombic system, Pmna, a = 7.985(1), b = 6.695(2), c = 14.314(2) A ̊ , Z = 2, R = 0.048 for 1240 reflections; clathrate 2: monoclinic, P2/m, a = 7.3980(8), b = 7.6454(6), c = 8.0639(9) A ̊ , β = 93.703(9)°, Z = 1, R = 0.041 for 1040; 3: monoclinic, C2/c, a = 12.054(5), b = 11.334(6), c = 15.249(2) A ̊ , β = 91.62(2)°, Z = 4, R = 0.043 for 2129. The structure of a Hofmann-H2O-type hydrate [Fe(H2O)2Ni(CN)4]·4H2O, orthorhombic Pnma, a = 12.200(2), b = 14.028(2), c = 7.2327(9) A ̊ , Z = 4, R = 0.042 for 710, is also reported.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The three-dimensional coordination polymer [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) was synthesized by the hydrothermal reaction of 4,4′-bipyridine with CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8/3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 1:1 mole ratio in a sealed tube at 120°C. The compound was characterized by FT-IR, diffuse reflectance UV–Vis, X-ray powder diffraction and single crystal X-ray analysis. The structure features three-dimensional, interwoven networks. Semiquantitative Kurtz–Perry powder measurements showed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possesses a second-order harmonic generation efficiency of ca. 27% of potasium dihydrogen phosphate.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">To systematically investigate the influence of the positional isomeric effect on the structures of their complexes, we prepared two Zn(II) complexes [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O based on a couple of tetrahedral linkers (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene)methane; L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>tetrakis(3-pyridyloxymethylene)methane) in the presence of the carboxylate linkers (PDC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>pyridine-2,6-dicarboxylic acid). Their structures and properties can be tuned by variable N-donor positions of the tetrahedral isomers. The X-ray crystallographic analysis demonstrate three-dimensional ones of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and two-dimensional ones of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. This work indicates that isomeric effect of the couple of isomers play an important role in the construction of the Zn(II) complexes. In addition, their thermostability and photoluminescence are also reported in detail.</ce:simple-para>

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Colorless crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were grown from solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.3448<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.0444<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and PDC (0.0167<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in the mixed solvents of DMF and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (v/v<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1:5) in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL acid-digestion bomb at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d. The product was washed with water and dried under vacuum. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was isolated as a single-phase product (yield: 36.5% based on L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">64</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">19</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 54.7, H, 4.3 N, 9.9. Found: C, 54.8, H, 4.4, N, 10.1. FT-IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3461.29<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1641.95<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1574.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1491.19<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s 1430.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1369.39<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1271.11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m, 1194.28<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m, 1105.14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m,1005.79<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m, 907.52<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 807.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 770.03<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 728.79<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 700.82<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 671.63<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 635.74<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Thermal analyses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was performed in a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere on polycrystalline samples of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and the results are shown in . The TG curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the first weight loss of 5.32% (calcd: 6.1%) in the temperature range of 25–131.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which indicates the loss of lattice molecules per formula unit. The framework retains until 356.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then starts to decompose, with an accompanying loss of organic linkers. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the weight loss are attributed to the gradual release of the surface and included water molecules is observed in the range of 25–163.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (obsd: 16.7% and calcd: 3.6%), the framework retains in the temperature range of 163.1–523.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then decomposes. To confirm whether the crystal structures are truly representative of the bulk materials, PXRD experiments were carried out for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The peak positions of the experimental and simulated XRPD patterns are in agreement with each other (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:bold>)</ce:bold>, which shows that the synthesized bulk materials and the measured single crystals are the same.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Photoluminescence property</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In view of the luminescent properties of <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal complexes, Accordingly, the emission spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were measured in the solid state at room temperature (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). When excitated at 390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits one strong emission maximum at 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. In contrast, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows an weak fluorescent emission peak at 650<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with an excitation length of 466<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. No obvious photoluminescence was observed for the free L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and PDC linkers under the same experiment conditions. Thus, the photoluminescence in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be assigned to the emission of ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT). In particular, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] cores in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can make contributions to luminescent properties.</ce:para>

<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0025">

</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Research highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp050" view="all">► Three-dimensional coordination frameworks with different pore size and shape. ► Solvent effect on formation and structure of metal-organic frameworks. ► Selective sorption behavior of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp010" view="all">Two new three-dimensional (3D) coordination polymers [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Zn(INAIP)]·9H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) have been synthesized by reactions of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with 5-(isonicotinamido)isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP) in <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide (DMF) and <ce:italic>N,N</ce:italic>-diethylformamide (DEF), respectively. The change of solvent leads to the formation of neutral frameworks with different structure, topology as well as different pore size and shape. The X-ray crystallographic structural analysis revealed that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is an unusual 3D architecture with (3, 6)-connected rutile (<ce:bold>rtl</ce:bold>) topology containing two-dimensional (2D) (4, 4) networks, while the 3D framework in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has (3, 6)-connected (4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·6)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>) topology with 2D kagomé layers. In addition, the stabilities, luminescence and adsorption properties of the complexes were investigated.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Zn(INAIP)]·2DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">A mixture containing Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP (28.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) dissolved in 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF was sealed in a 16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. Pale yellow block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected by filtration and washed by DMF for several times with a yield of 36%. Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>: C, 48.45; H, 4.47; N, 11.30%. Found: C, 48.52; H, 4.42; N, 11.38%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3451(s), 1672(m), 1620(s), 1570(s), 1425(m), 1368(m), 1288(w), 1066(w), 1031(w), 851(w), 780(w), 731(m), 687(w), 610(w).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Zn(INAIP)]·9H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was synthesized in the similar way to that described for preparation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, except that the reaction solvent was changed to DEF. Light brown crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected by filtration and washed by DEF for several times with a yield of 42%. Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>: C, 32.86; H, 5.12; N, 5.47%. Found: C, 32.93; H, 5.21; N, 5.41%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3424(m), 1649(s), 1560(s), 1423(s), 1365(s), 1286(m), 1066(w), 1029(w), 851(w), 779(w), 725(m), 602(w).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>TGA, powder X-ray diffraction and photoluminescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The results of thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) indicate that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> lost its non-coordinated DMF molecules in the temperature range of 30–190<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C () . The weight loss of 29.75% is consistent with calculated one of 29.48%. After the loss of the DMF molecules, the 3D framework is stable up to 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, followed by further weight loss at high temperature. The end product of decomposition of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is ZnO with weight percentage 16.33% (calculated: 16.42%). A total weight loss of 31.11% was observed for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in the temperature range of 25–275<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 30.97%), and the decomposition of the residue takes place at about 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the end product of decomposition is also ZnO for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with weight percentage of 16.62% (calculated: 15.90%). PXRD was used to check the purity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> () .</ce:para>
['property']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , intense emission bands were observed at 465<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP, 481<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 468<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>390<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The emissions in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be attributed to neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) since the Zn(II) ions are in d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration and difficult to oxidize or to reduce. Therefore the emissions observed in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are tentatively assigned to the <ce:italic>π − π</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> intraligand photoluminescence due to its resemblance to that of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP. On the other hand, the emission band intensity for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is increased and decreased, respectively, in comparison to the one of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>INAIP, which may be ascribed to the quenching effect of water molecules in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The results suggest that the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> may be good candidate of potential blue-fluorescent materials, since they have high thermal stability and are insoluble in common solvents.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Gas sorption properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">As discussed above, the frameworks <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are stable up to 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, thus gas adsorption property of the complexes can be expected. Before gas adsorption tests, activation to remove the guest molecules from the pores by heating under vacuum is a required pretreatment and the as-synthesized crystal samples were heated at an optimized temperature of 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. To verify whether the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be sustained after the removal of the solvent molecules, PXRD patterns were measured (). The framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> still has crystallinity after removing the solvent molecules, but the PXRD pattern of the activated sample is different from the as-synthesized one which may be attributed to the framework dynamics of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The crystalline solid of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be re-generated by immersing the activated sample in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h as indicated by the PXRD measurements () . The results show that the host framework of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is flexible enough to change its structure depending on the nature of the guest molecules, and the framework transformations are reversible. While complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows good crystallinity after removing the guest water molecules and the PXRD pattern of the activated sample shifts and becomes broad compared with the as-synthesized one (), therefore, the gas sorption isotherms of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are investigated. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherms for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a and b, it can be seen that no N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake was observed at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, hysteresis was observed between the adsorption and desorption curves down to the lowest attainable pressure, which are characteristic for type-H3 sorption . However, significant amounts of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (195<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K) were adsorbed (c) and both isotherms present typical type-I curves , which is the characteristic of microporous material. The amounts of adsorbed CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> increase abruptly at the beginning and reach to 60.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (STP)/g (1.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol/g) at 1.0 atom for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 43.19<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> (STP)/g (0.82<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol/g) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, approximately 0.48 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and 0.23 CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> molecules per formula unit were adsorbed for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Fitting the BET equations to the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm gave estimated surface areas of 119 and 68<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>/g for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms show distinct hysteresis between the adsorption–desorption curves, which must be attributed to the intercrystalline voids . It is noteworthy that no N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were adsorbed in spite of the channel size larger than the kinetic diameter of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (3.64<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), thus, the selective sorption behaviors of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> are attributed to the significant quadrupole moment of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (−1.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">−39</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Cm<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>), which induces specific interactions with the host framework . Considering the great current interest of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption/separation, the present work provides nice example of selective sorption behaviors of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> that is not size-controlled, but quadrupole moment induced .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Significantly, the assembly of paddle-wheel clusters as rigid SBUs with polytopic carboxylate linkers could generate rigid porous frameworks with permanent porosity and open functionalized metal sites . As a consequence, Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> paddle-wheel subunits for different orientations act as square SBUs linking 1D chains to provide a 3D framework with regular 1D parallelogram nanosized channels along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (grid dimensions of 10.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.42<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, calculated from the neighboring Cu(II) atoms) (c). Furthermore, two different kinds of square apertures are present. The first one is polar owing to the effective pore surface occupied mainly by uncoordinate carboxylate oxygen atoms and coordinate aqua molecules, and the twisted benzenyl groups of bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> take up the second hydrophobic channels. When seen from <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>×</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>b</ce:italic> plane, the framework structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is closely compact (), and thus, show noninterpenetrating single network, which depends on the asymmetrical nature of the bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> molecules possessing long molecular backbone to stretch space and large metal clusters laterally to block the interpenetrating aisles. A calculation using <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> revealed that the potential total solvent-accessible void space of the framework is 1072.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, corresponding to the 43.5% of the unit cell volume 2466.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
. From the view of topology, the SBUs of dimer [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] subunit and tetranuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] cluster serve as 4-connected and 8-connected nodes, respectively. The bptca<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ligands show two kinds of coordinated modes, but both of them link four copper-based SBUs, and thus, the organic ligands act as 4-connected nodes. So, the whole 3D framework adopts an unusual tetranodal (4,4,4,8)-connected net with the point symbol of {4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>.10<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>}{4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>}{8<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>} (d).</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are air-stable and can retain the crystalline integrity at ambient conditions. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) show that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have onset weight losses within the temperature range of 125–240<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 110–205<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). The first steps of TGA curves correspond to the release of the unknown disordered solvent molecules. Almost without pause, the host MOFs begin to decompose continuously until the final products CuO obtained. Consequently, the final MOFs exhibit ordinary thermal stability, which can be attributed to the anion nature of the frameworks strengthened by charge-balancing guest cations.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Ladder type polymer</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Two compounds, [M(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>), M=Cu (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>); Zn (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), are isostructural with close geometric parameters. Coordination polyhedron is a distorted octahedron with meridionally disposed three nitrogen atoms of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> and oxygen atoms of a nitrate and two water molecules. As can be expected in case of zinc the octahedron is slightly distorted (ZnN and ZnO(water) are in the range of 2.098–2.129 Å with somewhat elongated ZnO(nitrate) bond of 2.295 Å) against of appreciable distortion in copper complex fully analogous to found for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>: four equatorial bond lengths within 1.194–2.005 Å and axial elongated Cu–O interactions with water molecule (2.241 Å) and nitrate ion (2.583 Å).</ce:para>

<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>

Similar to <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion also lies in a heteroleptic (4+2) coordination environment, and the only difference is that two HCO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions are replaced by the Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>
a). The coordination bond lengths that involve the Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion are 2.2761(13)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å for the Mn–N bond, and 2.1585(18) for the Mn–O bond, respectively.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand takes a bidentate mode to connect four Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions into a rhomboic lattice with long Mn···Mn separation of approximately 14.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which also further extends into a 2D (4,4) layer [Mn(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>∞</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (b). These 2D layers are arranged in a parallel pattern to present 1D parallelogram channels with the dimensions of approximately 6.0×6.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>
a). The overall void volume is about 315.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, i.e. 23.4% of the cell volume. However, the void space in the 1D aperture is occupied by the Ac<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterion, which destroys the porosity (b).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sect0110">{[Mn(bib)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">Compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> crystallizes in the triclinic space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>-1 with one Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion located at the inversion center. The asymmetric unit contains one half of Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion, one <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligands, one CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ion and two dichloromethane molecules. The Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion still lies in a heteroleptic (4+2) coordination environment, but the axial sites are occupied by two CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> oxygen atoms (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>
a). The Mn–N bond lengths are 2.234(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 2.242(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Mn–O bond length are 2.229(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0135" view="all">The <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand takes a bidentate mode to bridges the 4-connected Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion to finally form a 2D (4,4) layer if the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand is simplified as a linear linker (b). These 2D (4,4) layers are piled up together in a parallel pattern to exhibit a 1D parallelogram channel with the dimensions of approximately 10.2×12.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (). The 3D packing architecture shows large void space of about 711.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, i.e. 61.4% of the cell volume using the PLATON program. However, the available void space is greatly reduced by the CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterion, which locates in the 1D channel (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0050"></ce:float-anchor>
a). Interestingly, the overall void volume of the neutral supermolecular framework is still up to about 478.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, i.e. 41.3% of the cell volume, which is filled with the dichloromethane molecule (b). Unfortunately, when the as-synthesized crystals were taken out from the solution, and placed in the air at room temperature for about 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, the original shape was destroyed and large crystals gradually collapsed into a mass of powder. The XRPD reveals that the collapsed powder was not matched with the crystal sample (). Furthermore, the collapsed powder exhibits no gas adsorption for N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Thus crystals of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> may convert into another tight coordination polymer in the air, which is failed to be characterized by the X-ray crystallography although trying our best.</ce:para>

The Mn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> center maintains the heteroleptic octahedral coordination geometry, which is six-coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from individual <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligands and two oxygen atoms from distinct SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>

<ce:section-title id="st035">Synthesis of Ag(L)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Ligand L (19.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–MeCN (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, 1:1, v/v) in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL vial, to which an acetonitrile solution of AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (33.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was added upon stirring at room temperature. The resulting solution was allowed to stir for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and then filtered. Slow evaporation of the filtrate over 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days gave colorless crystals, which were suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. The product was collected by decanting the solvent and then washed with diethyl ether, and dried in the air. Yield: 30.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg (84% based on L). FT-IR (solid, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 2921w, 1432m, 1405s, 1277s, 1155w, 1083w, 1023m, 990w, 908w, 815s, 730s, 669w, 599w. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>AgNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·0.2CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 31.80; H, 3.77; N, 3.64. Found C, 31.79; H, 3.60; N, 3.87%.</ce:para>

Found: C, 27.12; H, 3.44; N 4.39%.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The reaction of L with two equivalents of silver nitrate in a CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–MeCN solution afforded after slow evaporation colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in high yield, that are suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis. Elemental analysis data reveals an empirical formula of Ag(L)NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, suggesting a 1:1 metal-to-ligand ratio in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is poorly soluble in common solvents, and slightly soluble in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>HH NMR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in DMSO-<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> reveals only signals identical to those of the free ligand, indicating the decomposition of the complex in DMSO. In the IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> a strong band at around 1405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> appeared due to the coordinated NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions. X-ray structural analysis confirmed the formation of a coordination network involving effective Ag–S binding in the solid state (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>mc2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> and in the asymmetric unit there contains only one half of ligand L, one silver ion and nitrate anion, and the second half of L was generated by symmetry (operation code: −x, y, z). The Flack parameter of crystal <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> having a acentric space group was refined to be −0.01(2), indicating <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes as an enantiopure form, although achiral ligand was used. It was noticed that as seen in a the ligand molecules in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> adopt the conformation I and type-A binding mode with two silver(I) centers related by a <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> symmetric axis (). Relevant bond parameters around metal centers are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. The silver(I) center is tetracoordinate with two sulfur atoms from symmetry-related ligands and two oxygen atoms of the bridging nitrate ions, being in a slightly distorted tetrahedral environment. The Ag-S bond distances are almost identical (2.5185(6) and 2.5186(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively), falling in the range of Ag–S bond lengths reported in the literature , yet the Ag–O bonds are slightly different in length (2.357(3) and 2.533(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Propagation of the repeat structure unit along the silver(II) centers results in the formation of an infinite 2-D coordination network which is composed of 20-membered macrocycles containing two ligand units, two silver(I) centers and two bridging nitrato-O atoms (b and c). In each macrocycle, the Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance between two silver(I) centers bonded to the same ligand is approximately 10.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, while the O-bridged Ag⋯Ag nonbonding distance is approximately 4.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The two phenyl rings of ligands in the macrocycle are arranged in an edge-to-face fashion and thus effective C–H⋯π interaction is observed between the rings. The C–H⋯ π (centroid) distance as illustrated in c is as short as ca. 2.85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (c). It is worth mentioning that previously a silver(I) perchlorate complex based on a similar thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(phenylthiomethyl)benzene has been reported, where a structurally related grid-like network was observed . However, the structure of the repeating macrocyclic motif in this network is essentially distinct with that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. In the structure reported previously , the silver centers are bridged by two oxygen atoms of the perchlorate anion, and the Ag–O bond distances are relatively longer (2.556(10) and 2.719(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively), indicating weaker bonding interactions. In addition, the phenyl rings in the macrocycle are arranged in a face-to-face mode by π⋯π stacking interaction (the distance between two aromatic planes is ca. 3.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), in sharp contrast to the C–H⋯π interactions found in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (c)</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st070">Synthesis and characterization of Ag<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·0.25(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The critical role played by the counter anion (nitrate ion) in bridging the silver(I) center to form the 2-D network in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> encouraged us to investigate the impact of other silver salts on the self-assembly process. We next examined the reaction between L and silver tetrafluoroborate under the same conditions as for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and colorless crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained in moderate yield. IR spectrum of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows strong absorption as a broad band at around 3565<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, indicating the presence of water molecules. In addition, peaks appear at ca. 1028 and 519<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, consistent with the inclusion of BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> in the coordination compound. X-ray structural analysis identifies the main silver(I) network in the solid state, although several disorders were found (see Section  for details). <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>mma and the asymmetric unit contains only one half of the ligand molecule. Unlike the case in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, two independent silver(I) centers that bind to the same sulfur atom through a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-S bridging coordination are observed in the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a). The silver binding mode resembles the type-C mode in , whereas the ligand belongs to the conformation II (). Ag1 is two-coordinate with two symmetry-related sulfur atoms from distinct ligands and adopts an almost linear geometry (the S–Ag1–S angle is 172.12(4)°). In contrast, Ag2 is tetra-coordinate with not only two symmetry-related sulfur atoms, but also oxygen atoms from two water molecules that were involved in the structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> during the reaction through a bis-μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O bridging mode. The counter anions BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> that are, as expected, non-coordinated exist in the lattice. Thus, the coordination chemistry and the extended supramolecular structure in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are completely different from that in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, highlighting the drastic influence of counter anions.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st085">Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Thermal stability of four silver(I) coordination compounds were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere. The corresponding TG curves for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>. As shown in , compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 179<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and then experiences decomposition in two stages (179–365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 500–645<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C) with a total weight loss of ca. 54.8%, owing to the removal of ligand molecules from the complex (calcd. 54.0%). Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> undergoes a small weight loss (ca. 4.2%) between 50 and 147<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, accounting for the loss of water molecules from the 3D silver framework of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (ca. 1.5 H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O per unit, calcd. 4.4%), which is in agreement with the data of elemental analysis, indicating <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is hygroscopic in the air. <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is then decomposed upon heating to 196<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C by removing the ligand molecules. Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> proves to be less thermostable and begins to decompose gradually from 163<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. In contrast, 4 is stable up to 212<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at which temperature a slight weight loss (ca. 1.25%) is observed, consistent with the removal of two coordinated CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN molecules per structural unit (calcd. 1.3%). Again, upon further heating major decomposition of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> occurs at 234<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The magnetic property of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated over the temperature range of 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at an applied field of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kOe (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>). At 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value of 4.402<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (5.934 μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>) is much higher than the spin-only value of 1.875<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> (3.873 μ<ce:inf loc="post">B</ce:inf>) expected for one isolated Co(II) ions (S<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3/2, g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.0) (a), which can be ascribed to the orbital contribution to the magnetic moment of Co(II) centers . Upon cooling, the <ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>T</ce:italic> value decreases monotonically and reaches a value of 2.043<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K at 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which can be attributed to spin-orbit coupling and/or crystal field effect and/or zero-field splitting (ZFS) . The Curie-Weiss fitting of 1/<ce:italic>χ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">M</ce:inf> in the temperature range of 36–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K gives a good result with C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.460<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and <ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>47.289<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">A mixture of Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (85.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.222<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole (34.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, .236<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 556<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in the mole ration 1.00:1.07:2500 was stirred briefly before heating to 180<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h (initial and final pH values of 3.2 and 2.8, respectively). Purple crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 10% yield. <ce:section-title>Synthesis of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">A mixture of Co(C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (41.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole (34.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, .236<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10.00<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 556<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (50μL 0.860<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), in the mole ratio 1.00:1.43:3370:5.20 was stirred briefly before heating to 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h (initial and final pH values of 2.3 and 2.1 respectively). Purple crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, suitable for X-ray diffraction were isolated in 5–10% yield. Found: C, 19.4; H, 2.22; N, 18.9%.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The basic framework of Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is constructed by bridges in the two-dimensional layer in the <ce:italic>bc</ce:italic> plane composed of pillars of bpe ligands. The effectively longer Zn⋯Zn bond distances bridged by oba and bpe groups (about 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 13.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively) construct the highly porous framework. The density of the [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)] framework is only 0.53<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, reflecting the high porosity of the framework. Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> has channels that are connected in three dimensions. The largest channels are directed along the (<ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>c</ce:italic>) vector, as shown in c, with an effective area of about 13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. In addition, three channels are observed along each axis, with areas of: 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3, 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4, and 11<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-, <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>-, and <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axes, respectively. The channels are filled with two DMF molecules per dinuclear unit.</ce:para>
['property']
