<ce:para view="all">The thermal stability of the highly porous framework of Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> was estimated using thermogravimetric analysis (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). The removal of the guest DMF molecules was observed below about 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (observed 18%, calcd 21%). Any ensuing weight loss due to deformation of the resulting dry sample was not observed until 310<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, implying a high stability of the guest-free framework of Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. A similar stability was reported in the three-dimensional coordination polymer [M<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(1,4-benzenedicarboxylate)L] (L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>triethylenediamine, 4,4′-bipyridine) , which has similar network motifs to Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Characterization of the functionalities based on the highly porous framework of Compound <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is currently in progress.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st0015">Highlights</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">
<ce:list id="l0005">
<ce:list-item id="u0005">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">A new acylamide ligand is reported.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0010">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="u0015">
<ce:label>•</ce:label>
<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para>
</ce:list-item>
</ce:list>
</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">A new acylamide ligand is reported.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">An unprecedented (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A highly rare self-penetrating (3, 4)-connected net is reported.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">During the past decade, the construction of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is the current interest in the field of supramolecular chemistry and crystal engineering, and more and more people have paid considerable attentions to research it, due to its extensive potential applications in catalysis, separation, ion-exchange, magnetism, as well as their fascinating architectures and topological frameworks . Currently, several extreme interests on MOFs were focused on designing new topological architectures, and pioneers have disclosed many kinds of topological structure, such as NbO, PtS, CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> net, diamond net, rutile net, boracite net, sodalite net, etc.  Carefully checking the structure characters of MOFs, most of them were constructed from the single type of node, and the MOFs assembled from the double type of nodes are relatively less developed, such as the (3, 4) and (3, 6)-connected MOFs . To achieve this goal, the key factor is the choice of suitable organic ligands and metal centers; that is, to achieve the (3, 4)-connected net, one of the best ways is to choose metal centers with a low coordination number such as Zn, Cu, Co as 4-connected nodes and trigonal organic ligands as 3-connected nodes . Fortunately, herein, we report a novel MOF, namely [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(BTC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L)] [(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">·</ce:inf>DMF (Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>dimethylamine cation, BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate, L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>N<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>,N<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-bis (pyridin-3-ylmethyl)cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide)), with (3, 4)-connected (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10) topology and self-penetrating motif .</ce:para>
['property']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Topologically, if Zn(II) centers and the BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>units are viewed to be the 4- and 3-connected nodes, respectively, [
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>] and then this framework becomes a (3,4)-connected net with (6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>8<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10) topology built on four-connecting metal centers and three-connecting organic nodes. In the literature, there are a large number of (3, 4)-connected net such as Pt<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, jph, C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>, and twisted boracite net . In contrast to them, the present topology matrix is obviously different and holds self-penetrating motif that is still very rare in the literature. Moreover, the self-penetrating manner is described as catenations of the eight-membered circuits and ten-membered circuits [
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>].</ce:para>
['property']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">As show in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>, thermogravimetric analysis of the compound reveals that the weight loss (6.8%) in the temperature range of 20–200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C is derived from one DMF molecule (calc. 6.9%). And then there is no further weight loss until 400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, after that temperature, the process of chemical decomposition was performed. In addition, the solid-state photoluminescence properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>, an intense emission occurs at 409<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm with the excitation wavelength at 322<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. As we know, the emission is mainly derived from the π–π* transition of organic ligands.</ce:para>

<ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">
<ce:display>
<ce:figure id="f0035">
<ce:link id="lk00035" locator="fx1" xlink:href="pii:S0277538716306817/fx1" xlink:role="http://data.elsevier.com/vocabulary/ElsevierContentTypes/23.4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
</ce:display>
</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">A lanthanide-organic framework constructed from a new π-electron rich ligand 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) and Tb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, namely, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), has been synthesized under solvothermal condition. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a 3D porous framework featuring a (4,8)-connected <ce:italic>sqc</ce:italic> net. The solid sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits strong green fluorescence in the visible region upon excitation at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The fine grinding particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in ethanol shows good sensitivity for picric acid (PA), which can be reused at least five times for detecting PA. The good sensitivity and recyclability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> make it a potential fluorescent sensor for explosives detection.</ce:simple-para>
['property']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Here, we designed and synthesized a π-electron rich polycarboxylates ligand 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L). Considering that most of the Ln-MOFs exhibit excellent luminescence properties, lanthanide Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> was choosed as the metal connector to synthesize fluorescent MOFs. We employed this ligand to react with lanthanide Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> to construct a new luminescent 3D Tb-MOF [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). Because the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand can effectively sensitize the emission of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>, the solid sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> emits high bright green light upon excitation at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. The fine grinding particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in ethanol exhibit selective sensing of nitroaromatic explosives, indicating the Tb-MOF can be a good candidate for fluorescent sensor.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st035">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalic<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) ()</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>3,6-Dibromo-9H-carbazole was prepared according to the literature .</ce:para><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Under a nitrogen atmosphere, to a solution of 3,6-dibromo-9H-carbazole (325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in DMF solvent (30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) were added dimethyl 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalate (640<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Pd(PPh<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (93<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (324<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). After the mixture was stirred at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 18<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, then filtered and concentrated. The crude product was purified by column chromatography on silica gel with dichloromethane/methanol (100:5, V:V) to give pure tetramethyl 5,5′-(9H-carbazole-3,6-diyl)diisophthalate as a gray solid. Yelid: 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 60%. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR (600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MHz, DMSO-<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>): <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> 11.557 (s, 1H), 8.858 (s, 2H), 8.559 (s, 4H), 8.439 (s, 2H), 7.832 (d, 2H), 7.645 (d, 2H), 4.519(s, 12H). MS <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> 550.2 (M+H<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup>).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st045">Synthesis of [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">A mixture of Tb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (45.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L (24.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and NaOH (8.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of the component solvent (DMF:CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN:H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3:1:1) was sealed in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and heated to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. After the mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained with a yield of 65% (based on Tb). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Tb (%): C, 51.74; H, 3.04; N, 4.02. Found: C, 51.80; H, 3.08; N, 4.03%. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, KBr): 3423s, 1771w, 1734w, 1715w, 1698w, 1650w, 1620w, 1557w, 1539w, 1522w, 1508w, 1456w, 1287w, 849m, 820w, 785m, 718m, 595m.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Crystal structure description</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Single-crystal X-ray analysis indicates that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the tetragonal crystal system with space group of <ce:italic>I-4</ce:italic>2<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>. The asymmetrical unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains half a Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, half a L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and the negative charge of the framework is balanced by half a (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> cation, which was generated from the decomposed DMF. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>a, the central Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion possesses an eight-coordinated square antiprism coordination mode, being linked to eight carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligands. The Tb–O bond lengths vary from 2.260(5) to 2.501(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are similar to those reported in other Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> compounds . Two symmetry related Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions are bridged by carboxylate groups to form a noteworthy paddle-wheel [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit with a Tb⋯Tb distance of 4.2938(17)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anion coordinates to 8 Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, with carboxylate groups adopting two kinds of coordination modes: μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> mode. Finally, each binuclear [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit are linked by L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anions to generate a fascinating 3D porous framework (b). The solvent-accessible volume in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is 2206.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, equal to 36.6% of the volume of the unit cell calculated by the <ce:small-caps>platon</ce:small-caps> program. Topological analysis was carried out to get insight into the structure . As shown in c, the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> anions and the [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunits can be defined as 4- and 8-connected nodes, respectively. Therefore, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be simplified as a (4,8)-connected <ce:italic>sqc</ce:italic> network with Schläfli symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>)(4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6<ce:sup loc="post">16</ce:sup>).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st065">PXRD patterns and thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The PXRD patterns of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are shown in . The peak positions of experimental PXRD patterns are in line with the simulated ones, showing the pure phase of the complex. As shown in , the TGA of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows an initial gradual weight loss of 6.12% between 85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 242<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the release of (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> (Calc.: 6.62%). The compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> begins to decompose upon further heating and underwent a rapid weight loss of 64.58% from 242<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 563<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the destruction of the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligands.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st070">Fluorescence behaviors and sensing properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The lanthanide coordination polymers have displayed excellent fluorescence properties in the respect of their high color purity . So we investigated the ligand-assisted fluorescence properties of powder samples of the lanthanide complex at room temperature (). When excited at 354<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits the characteristic emissions of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions in the visible region. The emission peaks at 490, 545, 585 and 621<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm can be attributed to the transitions of <ce:sup loc="pre">5</ce:sup>D<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>–<ce:sup loc="pre">7</ce:sup>F<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">J</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6, 5, 4, 3) from Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, respectively. Upon excitation at 243<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, the free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand exhibits a luminescent emission band at 388<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which is attributed to the π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> transition. The luminescent investigation on the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> suggests that H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand may sensitize the luminescence of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions. The strongest emission in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> appears at 545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm which can be easily observed as bright green light by the naked eye. The remarkable fluorescence offers the possibility of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> being a fluorescence sensor.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">To explore the potential photoluminescence sensing properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the fine grinding sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) was dispersed in 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of various solvents (EtOH, MeCN, DMF, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, THF, acetone, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, toluene (TO), benzene (BZ), nitrobenzene(NB)) sonicated for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min and the emission was observed. The fluorescence intensities are mainly dependent on the solvent molecules, which present different fluorescence quenching degree (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Among the chosen solvents, the severe quenching of fluorescence intensity was observed in NB, indicating that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has a selective response to NB. The mechanism of fluorescence quenching might be attributed to the photoinduced electron transfer from an excited MOF to the highly electron deficient NB adsorbed on the surface of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
. The fluorescence quenching of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is similar to that reported for many other fluorescent MOFs in order to account for their highly selective sensing behavior towards NB .</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The sensing properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for NB prompted us to investigate its application in detecting different electron-withdrawing nitroaromatics. The nitroaromatics such as 4-nitrotoulene (4-NT), 2,4-dinitrotoluene (2,4-DNT), 4-ni-tro-chlorobenzene (4-NC), 2,4-dinitro-chlorobenzene (2,4-DNC), picric acid (PA) were added to a suspension of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) in ethanol (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL). As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>, upon the addition of the same amount of nitroaromatics ([nitroaromatics]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm), different degrees of fluorescence quenching of the suspension were tested. The descending order of quenching efficiency was PA<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-NC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,4-DNC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2,4-DNT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-NT<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>NB. About quenching efficiency (QE<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>(1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>100% (<ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf> and <ce:italic>F</ce:italic> are the fluorescent intensities before and after the addition of nitroaromatics, respectively.)) of 76.9% for PA is observed, which is significantly more than that of 4-NC (29.2%), indicating that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a high selectivity for PA.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0075" view="all">To further study the sensing capacity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for PA, the emission spectra are monitored by gradually increasing PA contents of a suspension of 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL ethanol. The fluorescent intensity obviously decreased with the increasing PA concentration (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). When the concentration of PA reached 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ppm, the quenching efficiency was 94.2% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, which is higher than or comparable to other MOF sensors, polymeric nanocomposites  and conjugated polymer sensors for PA. For example, the micrometer-sized MOF [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(TPT)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf> show an 82.5% quenching efficiency for PA . The quenching efficiency of the reported carbon and silver nanocomposites for PA is 99% . The fluorescence intensity of conjugated polymer flim only decreased with 77-fold fluorescence quenching . After immersing into the PA solution (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM in ethanol) for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are collected by filtration, washed with EtOH and air-dried. Then the PXRD measurement was performed. The PXRD result indicates that the crystallinity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was still remained after the experiment ().</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">The reusability of a sensor is a critical problem for the long-term practical applications. So, the recyclability experiments of the particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for sensing PA were carried out up to five cycles. The particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> could be recovered by centrifugation of the dispersed solution and washing three times with ethanol. The luminescent intensity and quenching ability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are essentially retained in 1–5 cycles (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). The results demonstrated that the complex has high reproducibility for explosive detection.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized a novel fluorescent Tb-MOF [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][TbL] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) with a new π-electron rich tetracarboxylic acid H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L. The complex exhibits a 3D porous framework constructed via paddle-wheel [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>] subunit. The solid-state fluorescent measurements indicated that the ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L can sensitize the fluorescence intensities of Tb<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ions, resulting in the strong fluorescence emission of Tb-MOF. The fine grinding particles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> dispersed in ethanol exhibits a high quenching efficiency for PA. The application of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may enable further development of new chemosensors for explosives.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:section-title id="sect0045">Synthesis of [Zn(L)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>(4,4′-bpy)]·2(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (1)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">A solution of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>·</ce:bold>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> (0.0145<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and a solution of 4,4′-bpy (0.0096<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL)were added with stirring to a solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L (0.0104<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.025<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in DMF (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), then 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was added to this mixture solution. After the mixture solution was stirred for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min, 2 drops of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol/L HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> solution was added to this reaction solution, and then the reaction mixture solution were stirred for another 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. The colorless solution had been obtained and then sealed in a 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL sealing glass vessel. The vessel was heated to 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and held at that temperature for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, then slowly cooling to room temperature, block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for single crystal X-ray diffraction were obtained by filtration and dried at air. yield:80%. Anal. Caled.(%): C 52.09, H 4.08, N 6.02. Found (%): C 52.62, H 4.17, N 5.94. EDX El. AN. (wt%): Zn 11.41, O 26.07, C 54.95, N 7.57. (at%): Zn 2.52, O 23.55, C 66.12, N 7.81. FT-IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3455(s), 3101(w), 2951(w), 2907(w), 2870(w), 1615(s), 1570(s), 1491(m), 1453(m), 1411(s), 1377(s), 1351(s), 1317(m), 1259(m), 1221(m), 1121(m), 1070(m), 1048(s), 923(w), 874(w), 816(s), 777(s), 731(s), 638(m), 543(w), 469(w).</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The tetrahedral [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] geometry around the Zn(Ⅱ) metal ion is comprised of two oxygen atoms from two different L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand units, and two nitrogen atoms from two different 4,4′-bpy ligands (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>
(a)). The bond distances of Zn-O and Zn-N are in the range 1.952–2.079<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and the bond angles around the Zn (Ⅱ) centre are in the range 95.38–132.51°. In the compound 1, on the one hand the 4,4′-bpy ligand connects two tetrahedral [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] centres in the 1D metal-pyridyl chains through the N atoms of the pyridyl rings with a separation of 10.9588<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å resulting in the formation of a V-shaped chain as shown in (b). In the 1D metal-pyridyl chain, the dihedral angle between two pyridyl rings is 13.022°. Therefore, two pyridyl rings of 4,4′-bpy are not coplanar. On the other hand each L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand connects to four [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedrons at four orientational positions by a μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> monodentate modes forming a 2D network, characterized by the C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> torsion angle of 180° in the central part of the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand, and the torsion angle of C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> O-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>… O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> is 178°, 179°, 180°, 179°, and 178° in the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand, and the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings of L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> is 0°, hence all oxygen and carbon atoms of the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>are mainly coplanar((c)). Finally, the 2D network structures formed by L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and [ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedra were interconnected by the 1D metal-pyridyl chains to form a 3D framework with channels (15.0977<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×22.2255<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>
(a)). The 3D grid allows each frameworks to be penetrated by two other independent frameworks to form the interesting 3-fold interpenetrating 3D frameworks, with isolated water molecules occupying the neutral channels ((b)).</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) and Differential thermal gravity (DTG) for the H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L and the crystalline samples of compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were recorded under air atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0040"></ce:float-anchor>
, ). The TGA curves of all three compounds have released the lattice water before 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, reflecting the fact that the lattice water in the framework is unstable and easy to separate from framework at low temperatures. The first weight losses corresponding to the release of water molecules are observed before 365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (observed 9.12%, calculated 7.83%), 323<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (observed 11.36%, calculated 13.69%), 325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (observed 16.34%, calculated 13.84%). The anhydrous compositions begin to decompose at 365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and ending above 490<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, at 323<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and ending above 497<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, and at 325<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and ending above 417<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, due to the decomposition of the organic part of the framework. The remaining weight may correspond to the formation of ZnO for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (observed 18.14%, calculated 17.72%) and compound 2 (observed 20.12%, calculated 15.39%), CoO for compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (observed 15.63%, calculated 14.42%).</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:section-title id="sect0090">UV–vis absorption spectra of compound 1-3</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The UV–vis spectra of compound <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> together with the free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand in the solid state at room temperature were measured. The Kubelka-Munk functions  converted from the diffuse reflectance data were plotted in <ce:float-anchor refid="f0045"></ce:float-anchor>
. The H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L exhibits strong absorption with a maximum at 316<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in the range of 280−352<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which probably corresponds to the π-π* and <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>-π* transitions centered on the benzene ring. The absorption of 4,4′-bpy is strong in a similar range with one peak at 290<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . Compared to the free H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L ligand, compound <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> exhibit absorption with maxima at 307<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 308<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 305<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively, and the absorption peaks of compounds <ce:bold>1, 2,</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have slightly blue-shifted in the same range. In compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the absorption peak is more stronger than other compound at 280<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, which may be attributed to the effect of 4,4′-bpy. In compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the characteristic absorption bands of UV–vis spectra around 580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm are correlated with the d-d transitions of tetrahedral coordinated Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>
.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sect0100">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">In summary, we successfully designed and synthesized three coordination polymers based on flexible multicarboxylic acid 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L), and one rigid ancillary bridging pyridine linkers 4,4′ -bipyridine (4,4′-bpy) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, one flexible ancillary imidazole linkers 1,4-bis (1H-imidazol-1-yl)-butane (bib) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. These compounds display interesting and versatile coordination features from 3D to 3D parallel entangled frameworks. Topological analysis reveals that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are 3D (4,4)-connected <ce:bold>bbf</ce:bold> topology net with the (6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>·8<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>) topology. The adjustable channels size of individual 3D framework is realized by using different lengths of co-ligands from byp to bib with keeping similar architectures of compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>. In compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the assignment of characteristic absorption bands of UV–vis spectra at 580<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm correlated with the d-d transitions of Co<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions in field of tetrahedral coordination is confirmed by the result of the single-crystal X-ray structure analysis. The solid-state photoluminescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were investigated, and the emission bands were assigned to the intra-ligand charge transfer (ILCT), and the different emission wavelength due to the effect of co-ligands. The solid-state thermal stabilities were investigated. The frameworks of <ce:bold>1, 2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are stable under 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>

</ce:simple-para><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">Presented here is a microporous formate framework.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The HCOO<ce:sup loc="post">-</ce:sup> was in situ generated from the decomposition of DMF.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The desolvated framework shows highly selective CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st025">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">A metal–organic framework [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·DMF <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> with in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) solvent has been solvothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), Infrared Spectroscopy (IR) and Elemental analysis (EA). Each formate ligand acts as μ3-bridge to link three octahedral Mn(II) centers to form a neutral three-dimensional (3D) framework with interesting 1D zigzag channel along the <ce:italic>b</ce:italic> axis, in which the DMF fill the free spaces. The desolvated samples exhibit interesting adsorption properties and show high selectivity for the adsorption of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> under ambient conditions.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or porous coordination polymers (PCPs) are a class of crystalline solid-state material featuring regular and designable channel structures with permanent porosity . Porous MOFs with high surface areas and tunable structures have recently attracted considerable interest not only for their fascinating architectures and intriguing topologies, but also for their potential applications in sensing, heterogeneous catalysis, gas storage and separation . Flue gases consist of nitrogen (typically more than two-thirds), carbon dioxide, water vapor, oxygen, and minor components such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and sulfur oxides. Economical and efficient CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture and storage (CCS) has been attracting tremendous attention due to the culprit for causing the greenhouse effect . Several technologies have been considered for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture and separation from nitrogen-rich streams, including absorption, adsorption and membranes separations . In particular, for separation of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, because of the relatively similar kinetic diameters of the molecules (3.3 and 3.64<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively), it would require materials operating on a size-selective mechanism to possess very small pores, which may limit the diffusion of gases throughout the material. Therefore, to find a suitable pore size material is a necessary condition for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> separation. Herein, we report an compound [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), synthesized by Mn salt and in situ generated formate ligand from the decomposition of DMF solvent , which exhibits high CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption and selectivity of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> under ambient conditions.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">To study the thermal behavior of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> were performed on polycrystalline sample to determine its thermal behavior from 25 to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. TGA on the as-synthesized sample of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicated weight loss of 14.72% before 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which corresponding to the release of solvent (DMF) molecules. The TGA curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> indicates that the framework is stable up to ca. 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (Fig. S1). After that temperature, the framework begins to decompose. We notice that the compound 1 has less thermal stability than that of [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·[1,4-dioxane] reported by Kim et al. . We also check the PXRD patterns between the desolvated and as-synthesized samples, and find that the main peaks of the desolvated one shift to high angles (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>). Interestingly, after immersing in DMF or MeOH again, it will restore to its original look. We deduce that the guest DMF in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is irregular, and has higher boiling point and bigger spatial volume than that of 1,4-dioxane, so the framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows a little expansion to encapsule big guest molecule and less thermal stability after releasing the guest.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">The permanent microporosity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> degassed under a dynamic vacuum at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, was established by reversible gas sorption experiments using N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Gas adsorption measurements (N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and pore size analyzer. The experiments shows typical type I behavior (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>), which is characteristic of microporous materials. The maximum N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is 28.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (STP). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are estimated to be 78.1 and 113.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake is higher than those for [Mn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(HCOO)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·dioxane previously reported at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, mainly due to the flexibility of the framework mentioned above.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Considering its low adsorption amount of N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and the difference between it and the former reported one, low-pressure hydrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at 77 and 87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K were furtherly measured (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>a–d). No hysteresis was observed in these isotherms at both temperatures. The adsorption isotherms revealed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can adsorb 4.29<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and 3.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (75.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 77 and 87<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. These results are almost equal to the former one , also suggest that the samples are fully activated. The isosteric heat of adsorption (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf>) of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was also calculated. At zero coverage, the <ce:italic>Q</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">st</ce:inf> is 6.66<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ/mol (Fig. S3). This value of the isosteric heat of adsorption is moderate compared with the many famous porous materials, such as ZIF-8, MIL-100, PCN-10, HKUST-1, MOF-5, IRMOF-1 and IRMOF-8 .</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Since the samples were fully activated, what attract us is its CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture and storage. The adsorption isotherms of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were measured up to 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>bar at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. As shown in e–h, the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> uptake values are 2.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (57<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, and 1.92<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (43<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively. The carbon dioxide uptake values of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are higher than that of many famous porous materials at 273 and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, respectively, such as ZIFs, SNUs, MOFs, BIF-9-Li, and MILs (Table S1) . Virial analysis of the CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherms revealed that the isosteric heat of adsorption of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> at zero surface coverage is 24.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>kJ/mol (Fig. S5). The potential of this rigid framework material in CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> gas separation was also explored. As shown in i and j, N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was hardly adsorbed at all at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (3.96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K (3.73<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). We employed the Henry’s constants to estimate the adsorption selectivity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
, which has been shown to be valid for calculating the gas selectivity of MOFs, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is calculated to exhibit an adsorption selectivity of 36.6 for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 25.3 at 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K respectively, which indicated that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has excellent CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption selectivity. To our knowledge, these selectivity values are the particularly well reported to date for MOF materials .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In summary, we report a microporous Mn-formate framework via solvothermal method with in situ generated formate ligand decomposited by DMF solvent. The desolvated framework of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits high CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption and excellent selectivity of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 273<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K and 298<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K, which suggests that this simple framework can also be as the suitable CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> capture material because of its excellent size-selective effect.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">A copper molybdate coordination polymer has been synthesized.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The coordination polymer was used as an epoxidation catalyst.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">The catalyst showed good activity and selectivity in the epoxidation reactions.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st015">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">Through exploitation of hydrothermal synthesis, a mixture of crystals containing blue [CuMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and yellow ([Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine and 1,10-phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) were obtained. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a new 1-D coordination polymer while compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is a known metal–organic framework. The obtained crystals have been further characterized by means of powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), FT-IR and inductive coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). The catalytic properties of the prepared mixture were investigated in the epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) or cumene hydroperoxide (CHP) as oxidants. It was found that the crystals could serve as an active and selective catalyst for the epoxidation of the olefins and allylic alcohols. The catalyst can be recovered easily and reused in the reaction without considerable decrease in activity or selectivity. Moreover, the influence of the type of oxidant and solvent on the conversion of the olefins was studied.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st055">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st060">Structure of [CuMoO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">The crystallographic details for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are provided in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> consists of a Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation, a molybdate anion, 1,10-phen ligand and one free water molecule (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>). The coordination environment of Cu1 ion exhibits a {CuN2O3} distorted square pyramidal geometry. The Cu1 ion is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms from 1,10-phen (with the bond distances of Cu1—N1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.038(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Cu1—N2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.005(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and bond angles of N1—Cu1—N2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>81.67(9)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å), two μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O groups at basal position (Cu1—O1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.927(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Cu1—O3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.906(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and one μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O group at apical position (Cu1—O2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.269(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Each Mo1 site has a distorted tetrahedral geometry and is surrounded by three μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O atoms (Mo1—O2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.756(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Mo1—O3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.763(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å; Mo1—O1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.773(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and one terminal O<ce:inf loc="post">t</ce:inf> atom (Mo1—O4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.726(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The bond lengths and angles are in agreement with those reported for other copper molybdate coordination polymers (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>) .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0115" view="all">The catalytic activity and stability of the prepared compounds was compared with the other catalysts immobilized on various supports (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0020"></ce:float-anchor>). As seen, the catalytic activity of the prepared self-supported coordination polymer is comparable to the other heterogeneous oxidation catalysts obtained by using different supports such as active carbon (AC), graphene oxide (GO), MOF (UiO-66) and silica coated magnetic nanoparticles (SCMNPs). Moreover, the molybdenum content for the fresh and recycled self-supported catalyst that is determined by ICP-OES analysis is 26.43% and 23.08%, respectively. The recycled catalyst showed little change (about 3%) in the molybdenum content compared to that of fresh catalyst. Similar to the other supported catalysts in , no significant leaching for the molybdenum content was observed after recycling indicating the stability of the catalyst in the epoxidation reaction.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">A new three-dimensional terbium-carboxylate framework [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) [(H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)diphthalic acid)] has been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized. The framework contains Tb<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Tb<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> clusters, and exhibits an unprecedented 4-nodal (3,4,5,8)-connected topology. In addition, the thermogravimetric analysis, luminescent and magnetic properties were investigated.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">TGA shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> releases seven water guests and seven aqua ligands below 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a total weight loss of 10.0% (calc. 10.7%), following a plateau observed from 200 to 295<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (Fig. S6). The further heating leads to two residual aqua ligands escaping within 295–360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a weight loss of 1.4% (calc. 1.5%). The high releasing temperature of these two aqua ligands can be attributed to their short Tb–O<ce:inf loc="post">water</ce:inf> bond lengths of 2.367(6)–2.372(7) Å, on the contrary, the other seven aqua ligands are released under lower temperature arising from their longer Tb–O<ce:inf loc="post">water</ce:inf> bond lengths of 2.391(6)–2.468(6) Å. Beyond 360<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, an abrupt weight loss is followed by the departure of L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> up to 620<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, leaving a residue of Tb<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf> (observ. 32.5%, calc. 31.8%) . The TGA result basically agrees with the formula of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>

The aryl hydrogen atoms were added to their geometrically ideal positions, the hydrogen atoms on the coordinated water molecules were located from the electron density. However, the hydrogen atoms of water solvates can not be located from the difference Fourier maps.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Therefore, we have studied the possible formation of network coordination compounds with Cu(II). Herein, we report the synthesis of three new copper(II) compounds with different anions, i.e. [Cu(<ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cu(<ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>btb</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Their single-crystal X-ray structures, physical and electronic properties are described and the differences with the Cd analogs are discussed.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the data of the ligand field and EPR measurements are shown.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The ligand-field transitions measured as a solid with the diffuse reflectance technique are observed for all four compounds as broad band with a maximum from 15.5 to 16.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> with a shoulder at 10.2 to 11.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. These bands are in agreement with the distorted octahedral geometry for all four compounds .</ce:para>

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of NaVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (122<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (222<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Ni(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (177<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 4,4′-bipyridine (50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HF (40%, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred for ca. 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in air until it was homogeneous, and adjusted by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COOH to pH 4.6, and then transferred and sealed in a 16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. After heated to 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under autogenously pressure for 4d, the bomb was cooled down to room temperature. Black octahedron block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> along with an amorphous grey impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor, washed by distilled water and air-dried at room temperature. The crystals were mechanically separated from the powdery grey impurity to give a yield of 61% (based on V), and were stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. </ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A mixture of NaVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (183<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (220<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Ni(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (177<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 2,2′-bipyridine (50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), HCl (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>OH (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stirred for ca. 45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air until it was homogeneous, and adjusted by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COOH to pH 5.5, and then transferred and sealed in a 16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. After heated to 170<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under autogenously pressure for 4 days, the bomb was cooled down to room temperature. Black block crystals of <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> along with an amorphous grey impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor, washed by distilled water and dried at ambient temperature. The crystals were mechanically separated from the grey impurity to give a yield of 51% (based on V), and were stable in air and insoluble in water and common organic solvents. <ce:section-title>Thermogravimetric analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Thermogravimetric analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> reveals a continuous weight loss (36.7% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 35.5% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 36.1% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 35.8% for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) until 429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, 431<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and 428<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, respectively, corresponding to the removal of water molecules, the guest 4,4′-bpy molecule and four coordinated 4,4′-bpy molecules (calc.36.1% for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 36.2% for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 36.9% for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and 36.3% for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>). In compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the TG curve shows four weight loss steps, which suggests a multiple-stage decomposition process. Heating from about 25 to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C leads to the loss (weight loss of ca. 2.03%) of three crystal H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per formula unit (calc. 1.79%). The next three weight loss steps (45.23%), occurring between 180 and 596<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, correspond to the loss of three 2,2′-bpy molecules per formula unit (calc. 46.68%).</ce:para>

</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0055">Preparation of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(1,4-bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·2DMF (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">A mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30 mg, 0.1 mmol), <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> (16.6 mg, 0.05 mmol), 1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc (16.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) was put in a reaction vessel (10 ml) and DMF (3 ml) was added to it, then sealed, with ultrasonic processing for 30 min the solid completely dissolved in DMF giving a clear solution. The reaction solution was heated at 70 °C for five days then cooled to room temperature and filtered, after the solid was washed with DMF and dried to obtain many yellow petals crystals (ca. 51.2% yield based on <ce:bold>L</ce:bold>). <ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Description of the crystal structure</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0090">Structure of {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(1,4-bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·2DMF}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">X-ray crystallographic analysis shows that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the monoclinic space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2/<ce:italic>c</ce:italic> and features a 3D framework structure, and it consists of three Zn(II) ions (Zn1, Zn2 and Zn1<ce:sup loc="post">#5</ce:sup>, symmetry code: #5 -x+1,-y,-z+1), one <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand, three bdc<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anions and two uncoordinated DMF molecules. The Zn(II) ions show different coordination geometries. The Zn1 (Zn1<ce:sup loc="post">#5</ce:sup>) ion is five coordinated with a distorted pentahedron coordination geometry, which is fulfilled by four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O4 and O5) originating from three independent 1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc ligands and one nitrogen atom (N1) of the <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand with the coordination angles varying from 99.9(9)° to 121.9(6)°. The Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond length is 2.004(3) Å, and the lengths of Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonds are 1.975(3) Å, 1.955(3) Å and 1.930(3) Å, respectively, four oxygen atoms and one nitrogen atom are located on the five vertices of pentahedron, and the Zn1(Zn1<ce:sup loc="post">#5</ce:sup>) is located in the center of pentahedron <ce:bold>(</ce:bold>

<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>a<ce:bold>)</ce:bold>. The Zn2 center is six coordinated by six O atoms from six 1,4-bdc<ce:sup loc="post">2-</ce:sup> ions to complete an octahedral geometry with the coordination angles varying from 81.9(6)° to 120.0(0)°. The Zn<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths are 2.036(3) Å, 2.058(3) Å and 2.181(3) Å, severally. The four oxygen atoms (O3, O3<ce:sup loc="post">#5</ce:sup>, O6, and O6<ce:sup loc="post">#5</ce:sup>) are located in the equatorial plane location of octahedral and the two oxygen atoms (O1, O1<ce:sup loc="post">#5</ce:sup>) are located in the axial location of octahedral <ce:bold>(</ce:bold>
b<ce:bold>)</ce:bold>. Three Zn(II) ions (Zn1, Zn2 and Zn1<ce:sup loc="post">#5</ce:sup>) are bridged by <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-1,3-carboxylate and <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-carboxylate oxygen atoms to form a trimer <ce:bold>(</ce:bold>
c<ce:bold>)</ce:bold>, with the Zn⋯Zn distance is 3.205 Å. The dihedral angle between one pyridine ring and one anthracene ring in the same <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> is 63.9°. The trimers are joined through the scaffolds of 1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc ligands, leading to the formation of a 4<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>

</ce:bold> coordination layer and two trimers in a diagonal position are linked by 1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc <ce:bold>(</ce:bold>
d<ce:bold>)</ce:bold>. The <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand adopts bidentate bridging coordination, linking the 2D layers to form a 3D framework <ce:bold>(</ce:bold>

Thus, the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be simplified as a 3D 8-connected framework with the point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>) <ce:bold>(</ce:bold>

<ce:para id="p0110" view="all">For the sake of researching the framework stability of the complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were shown in Supplementary 2 . The TG shows that the complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> undergoes decomposition in two stages, and the complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> undergoes decomposition in three stages . For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, in the whole process of stepwise decomposition until the temperature rise to 500 °C, the final residual of 19.05% may be the mixture of ZnCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and ZnO (Calcd 20.17%). For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first loss of 39.34%, occurs between 25 °C and 150 °C, corresponding to the loss of three lattice DMF molecules and two <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> molecules (Calcd 38.49%). The second that occurs between 300° and 475° are ascribed to the collapse of the framework. The final residual of 9.08% may be the mixture of ZnCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and ZnO (Calcd 7.33%). For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the first loss, of 9.42%, occurs between 25 °C and 80 °C, corresponding to the loss of one lattice DMF molecule (Calcd 9.02%). The second occurs between 130 °C and 240 °C, amounting to about 10.09%, corresponding to escape of one lattice DMF molecule (Calcd 9.02%), and the third weight loss between 350 °C and 500 °C amounts to about 60.02%, which is ascribed to the collapse of the framework (Calcd 60.35%), and the final residual of 19.37% may be CdCO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (Calcd 20.84%).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0110">Fluorescent properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0115" view="all">It is known that many d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal complexes exhibit luminescence properties. The coordination complexes with the rational selection and design of conjugated organic spacers with metal centers can be efficient for obtaining new luminescent materials . To investigate the luminescence properties of complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>, the solid-state fluorescent properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> as well as the ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> have been studied at room temperature under the same experimental condition and their emission spectra are given in Supplementary 2 . When excited with 390 nm light, the free <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> ligand exhibited an emission peak at 470 nm, which originated from ligand internal change transfer. Upon excitation with 390 nm light, complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> all display intense photoluminescence, with emission maxima at 474, 440 and 440 nm, respectively. Compared with the free <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> Ligand, the introduction of Zn(II) and Cd(II) to ligand <ce:bold>L</ce:bold> led to a weak blue-shift for complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. On the one hand, because the N atoms coordination to the metal center, the electron transfer to the metal ions and occurs Ligand-to-Metal Charge Transition (LMCT). Moreover, the ligand π* track as the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the metal <ce:italic>d</ce:italic> track for the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), the electron transfer when subjected to external excitation, resulting in the maximum absorption wavelength of the compounds blue shift. On the other hand, the differences of the peaks for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> may be resulted from different coordination environments around Zn(II) and Cd(II) centers . In addition, the high-dimensional structures of complexes <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> lead to significant enhancement of fluorescence intensity compared to that of the free ligand. The enhancement of fluorescence intensity of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be attributed to the following aspects: firstly, anthracene is a kind of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons with strong fluorescence emission; secondly, the ligand coordination to the metal center and increase plane conjugated system of ligands, which the intraligand π → π* transition occurs more easily; on the other hand, the ligand rigidity enhancement and thus reduces the loss of energy through a radiationless pathway , however, fluorescence enhancement of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0115">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0120" view="all">In summary, three new Zn(II)/Cd(II) complexes with 9,10-di(pyridine-4-yl)anthracene have been successfully constructed and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, element analysis, IR and PXRD. Complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> have the 3D network structure. The central metals, reaction solvents and temperatures play crucial roles in the formation of complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>. The X-ray powder diffraction (PXRD) of the complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> demonstrate that they have high phase purity. In addition, we studied thermal stabilities and fluorescent properties of complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>. We believe that this study reveals the effectiveness of general solvothermal processing methods which are influenced by the nature of the solvent and reaction temperature. Because of the multi ring structure of the ligand molecule, the solubility of the ligand is reduced and the difficulty coefficient is enhanced. Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> has a novel structure and strong fluorescence properties, which indicated that those complexes can be used as a potential functional materials, for example used in LED lamps. For another, the coordination of the carboxylate group from auxiliary ligand to metal center effectively increase the dimension of the coordination polymers, which provides a potential guiding significance for the synthesis of coordination polymers with multi dimensions.</ce:para>

<ce:simple-para view="all">The thermal properties of compound [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> have also been studied and are reported here.</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">For a few years, lanthanide-based coordination polymers have deserved a special attention due to their ability to combine specific physical properties and original crystal structures. There is currently a renewed interest in that field because of the nanotechnologies emergence. Actually, the design of nanoporous open frameworks is a factor of this revival  because these compounds are anticipated to exhibit good efficiency as far as size selective separation, catalysis and gas storage are concerned . These potential applications require materials that do not decompose or collapse upon the removal of the guest molecules. Such materials can be obtained by using aromatic poly-carboxylate ligands. Several lanthanide-based coordination polymers involving benzene-poly-carboxylate ligand have already been described , but potentially porous materials are still rather uncommon . In order to increase the intermetallic distances in these materials, we have undertaken the study of naphthalene-poly-carboxylate-based coordination polymers . The two new lanthanide-containing coordination polymers reported below are part of this study. Both have been obtained by reacting in aqueous gel media a lanthanide chloride with the sodium salt of naphthalene-tetra-carboxylic acid (1,4,5,8-naphthalenetetra-carboxylic acid) (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>), hereafter symbolized by H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>ntc.</ce:para>

Six out of them come from four (ntc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>) ligands and the four others come from the coordination water molecules. All carboxyl groups of 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylic acid are deprotonated, in agreement with the IR spectrum in which no strong absorption peak around 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for –COOH is observed. Two of the four carboxylate groups of (ntc<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>) adopt a bidentate chelating mode, while the other two adopt an unidentate chelating mode, chelating four La(III) ions (see ).</ce:para>

The partial dehydration has been checked and confirmed by thermogravimetric measurements.</ce:para><ce:para view="all">At last, the partially dehydrated compound reversibly binds water when exposed to moisture.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Estimated porosity of compound [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In order to evaluate the porosity of [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf>, we have formally removed the crystallization water molecules from the crystal structure of [LaNa[(C<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">∞</ce:inf> and applied a computational method  based on Connolly’s algorithm . Thanks to this method, the porosity of a partially dehydrated material can be calculated on the basis of its crystal structure. Furthermore, this method allows obtaining the maximal kinetic radius a guest molecule can present for being hosted by the structure. In this case (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig8"></ce:float-anchor>), it appears that the compound can host molecules with a kinetic radius smaller than 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, for instance, He (1.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) or H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The estimated potential porosity, calculated with 1.45<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å as probe sphere radius, is actually 757<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is very stable in air at ambient temperature and almost insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, acetonitrile, chloroform, methanol and acetone. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is also stable in air at room temperature but soluble in methanol. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The samples were heated up in air at 1 atm pressure with the heating rate of 20 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The TGA curve shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 120 °C. A total weight loss of 16.3% occurred in the temperature range 120–230 °C, presumably due to the removal of the guest methanol molecules and the bonded H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 16.4%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 230–320 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. The TGA curve shows that <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is stable up to 100 °C. A total weight loss of 5.6% occurred in the temperature range 100–150 °C, corresponding to the removal of the guest H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 5.9%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 380–420 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. Their <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf> values have been measured by using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and these are 107.2° and 134.9° for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The self-assembly process of coordination polymer can also be influenced by some subtle effects (reaction temperature, solvent, et al.), and counterions may show coligand effects. For example, thiocyanate anion has extraordinary varieties in the binding of complexes and shows great potential in building coordination frameworks. It can adopt end-on and end-to-end fashions via the nitrogen and sulfur atoms to bind metal ions. In particular, the end-to-end bridging fashion increases the dimensionality of the coordination network by the interlinking of the 1D chains or 2D networks, and meantime it enhances the interactions between paramagnetic metal-ions. It is worthy to note that cadmium thiocyanate adducts of organic ligands are an important class of complexes for the design and preparation of functional coordination frameworks since Cd(II) ion can form stable double SCN bridged chains .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complexes</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Preparation of [Cd(DPBA-3)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">A mixture containing Cd(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), DPBA-3 (16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml EtOH was sealed in a Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. After cooling to room temperature, the solution was filtered into the tube. After several days, colorless block crystals were obtained by the slow diffusion of diethyl ether into the reaction solution. Yield: 64%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>CdCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>: C, 39.96; H, 3.35; N, 13.71.
