The filtrate was diffused by diethyl ether for several days, during which time colorless crystals appeared. Found: C, 39.39; H, 3.58; N, 13.97%. Then a solution of Cd(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (20.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in acetone (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was layered over the buffer layer. Single crystals appeared after one week. <ce:section-title>Luminescence properties of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Inorganic-organic hybrid coordination polymers, especially those with <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal centers, have been investigated for fluorescence properties and for potential applications as fluorescence-emitting materials, such as light-emitting diodes (LEDs) . The luminescent behaviors of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were studied at room temperature in the solid state. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>, intense emission bands were observed at 421<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>338<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for DPBA-3, 422<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>345<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 431<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>349<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 437<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>349<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, 437<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>399<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm) for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, respectively. Compared to the DPBA-3 ligand, the emission bands of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are 1, 10, 16 and 16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm red shifted, respectively, which was considered to mainly originate from the influence of the coordination of metal atom to the ligand. The similar emissions between the ligand and the complexes are also probably contributed by the π–π<ce:sup loc="post">∗</ce:sup> intraligand fluorescence .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental section</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Materials and measurements</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">All the reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. TG–DSC measurement was performed on a PYRIS DIAMOND from room temperature to 800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> under atmosphere. FT-IR spectra (KBr pellets) were taken on a Bruker Vertex 70 spectrometer. Elemental analysis for C, H, N was recorded on a VarioEL instrument. N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption measurement for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M automatic volumetric instrument.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st040">TG measurement</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Thermal gravimetric (TG) curves of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits two-step weight loss below 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>). The weight loss from room temperature to about 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be assigned to the release of all coordinated water, DMF molecules and lattice solvent molecules. The second weight loss from 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C to 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C can be attributed to the decomposition of the compound, which is indicated by an exothermal peak at 413<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DSC curve. The residue value is of 20% due to the formation of CoO. Later, the weight increases a little with the increasing temperature, which might be caused by the oxidation of the CoO intermediate product.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st045">Gas sorption of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The porosities of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were evaluated by measuring N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> sorption at 77<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K. Before the gas sorption measurement, the samples of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were vacuum dried at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. The N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> adsorption isotherm (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>) exhibits a type-I adsorption behavior, which suggests that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> possess permanent porosity. From the adsorption branch of the isotherm, the Langmuir and BET surface areas were calculated to be 347.6 and 267.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>m<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. A whole hysteresis of desorption was observed in the isotherm. The sample also exhibits some gas adsorption toward H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. A similar hysteresis of desorption was also observed in the isotherm of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>.</ce:para>
['property']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:section-title id="st050">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In conclusion, a cobalt-organic compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> featured with interpenetrating MOFs and 12-connected Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> cluster nodes was obtained by solvothermal synthesis. By soaking <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in methanol, another compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained through single crystal-to-single crystal transform. Interesting, the network of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was nearly kept unchanged but the space group of the crystal structure was changed from <ce:italic>C2/c</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>2<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>/c</ce:italic> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The gas sorption measurements indicated permanent porosity in the extended structures.</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Two new Zn(II) compounds, namely [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bptc)(datrz)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>·n(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc = biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, Hdatrz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole), have been obtained by the self-assemble reactions of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole, aromatic polycarboxylate ligands under solvothermal conditions. Single crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that both compounds display three-dimensional (3D) frameworks. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a trinodal (3, 4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {4.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8}{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>}. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a binodal (4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}{3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>}. In addition, the thermal stabilities and luminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were also investigated in the solid state at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0015">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0015" view="all">Presented here are two new Zn(II) compounds, [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bpt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bptc)(datrz)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>·n(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt = biphenyl-3,4′,5-tricarboxylic acid, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc = biphenyl-3,3′,5,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, Hdatrz = 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a trinodal (3, 4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {4.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>{4.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8}{4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.8<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>}. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a binodal (4, 6)-connected topological network with the point symbol of {3<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>}{3<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.4<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>.7<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>}.<ce:display>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0050">Synthesis of [(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bptc)(datrz)]<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>·n(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">The synthesis of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was similar to that of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, but with H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc (0.093 g, 0.1 mmol) in place of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt. Colorless crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained in 38% yield based on Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Elemental analyses calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (617.18): C, 38.89; H, 2.92; N, 13.61%. Found: C, 38.86; H, 2.97; N, 13.67%. IR data (KBr pellet): 3450(s), 3179(m), 1652(m), 1626(m), 1550(s), 1478(s), 1431(m), 1182(s), 1135(m), 1034(m), 826(w), 807(m), 787(w), 610(m), 550(m), 519(m), 486(w).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermal analyses of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The phase purities of bulk samples of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been confirmed by the powder X-ray diffraction analyses. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>, the major peak positions of the bulk solids of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> match well with those of the simulated patterns based on respective single crystal X-ray diffraction data, indicating that the synthesized compounds are in pure phase. In addition, the thermal behaviors of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were also investigated by thermalgravimetric analysis (TGA) under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere in the temperature range of 30–800 °C. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, there is no obvious weight loss in the temperature range of 30–270 °C, and after 270 °C, the framework started to collapse accompanied by the decomposition of the organic components. The residue of the powder may be ZnO (obsd: 24.98%, calcd: 24.18%) (c). For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the weight loss corresponding to the departure of the lattice water molecule is observed from to (obsd: 2.72%, calcd: 2.92%). The framework can be stable up to 271 °C, where the framework begins to collapse owing to the decomposition of the organic ligands. Finally, the remnants are 27.52%, corresponding to the formation of ZnO (calcd: 26.24%) (d) (see ).</ce:para>
['property']

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">Photoluminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks with d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> transition metal ions have attracted intense interest from chemists owing to their potential applications in photochemistry, chemical sensors, and electroluminescent displays . In this work, the luminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> as well as the free ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc and Hdatrz) were investigated in the solid state at room temperature. The free H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc and Hdatrz ligands display intense emission peaks at 388 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 345 nm), 402 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 345 nm), 435 nm (λ<ce:inf loc="post">ex</ce:inf> = 340 nm), respectively, which can be assigned to the <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*-<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> or <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>*-<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> transitions (b). Under the excitation light of 340 nm, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> show broad emission bands centered at 442 nm and 445 nm, respectively (a). Notably, the luminescent emission peaks of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are similar to that of free Hdatrz ligand with red-shifts of 7 nm and 10 nm, respectively. The absence of the carboxylate-based ligands (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>bpt and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptc) emission bands further indicates that the luminescence of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be attributed to Hdatrz intraligand charge transfer .</ce:para>
['property']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">In summary, two new luminescent Zn(II) compounds based on 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole mixed with two different aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been prepared under solvothermal conditions. The two compounds both possess 3D frameworks but with different topologies. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> displays a trinodal (3,4,6)-connected topological network, and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> displays a binodal (4.6)-connected topological network. The high thermal stabilities and intense luminescent properties of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> indicate that they can be used as new photoactive materials.</ce:para>

A mixture of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.21<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), LaCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (792<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 2.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KCl (130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 1.75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and water (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was sealed in a 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel after adjustment of the pH to 5 with 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M KOH. The mixture was heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hours, followed by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C hour<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>. Dark green crystals were obtained (210<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, yield 60%).</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para view="all">The compound [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) was prepared using a similar procedure to that used to prepare Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. A DMF solution (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba (5.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and bpe (3.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was allowed to diffuse into a DMF solution (200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of Zn(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (2.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). Colorless cubic crystals were formed within a period of one week, and these were collected by filtration under a nitrogen atmosphere because of the highly moisture sensitivity. One crystal of each compound was used in the single crystal X-ray analysis, and the residual crystals were used for other measurements. Elemental Anal. </ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Synthesis of {(cation)[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>x</ce:italic>(solvent)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>). A mixture of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptca (0.082<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.121<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and two drops of concentrated HNO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (63%, aq.) in distilled water (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and DMA (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was placed in a 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL screw-capped vial, heated to 105<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The pH value of mother solution is about 6. Blue block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were obtained in 36% yield based on copper. Elemental analyses (%): C, 45.09; H, 2.79; N, 3.94. IR/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (KBr): 3422(s), 3245(m), 2934(w), 1622(s), 1384(s), 1294(m), 1270(m), 1097(w), 1018(m), 939(w), 772(m), 733(m), 694(m), 664(w), 595(w), 556(w), 487(m). {(cation)[Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·<ce:italic>y</ce:italic>(solvent)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) was obtained by the same procedure as that for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> except that different ratio of the reactant was employed (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bptca (0.082<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.060<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol)). Yield: 42% based on copper. Elemental analyses (%): C, 47.35; H, 2.96; N, 4.37. IR/cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> (KBr): 3426(s), 3253(m), 2804(w), 2483(w), 1610(s), 1429(s), 1369(s), 1028(m), 938(w), 848(w), 777(m), 727(s), 667(m), 596(w), 557(w), 496(m).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The reaction of 4,4′-bipyridine with CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8/3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in water in 1:1 mole ratio in a sealed tube at 120°C gave <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> as pure crystalline product in 57% yield. A sample of 256 mg (1.0 mmol) CdSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·8/3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 156 mg (1.0 mmol) 4,4′-bipyridine was mixed thoroughly and loaded into a thick-walled Pyrex tube. After ∼1.0 ml H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was added, the tube was frozen with liquid N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, evacuated under vacuum and sealed with a flame. The reaction was carried out at 120°C for 24 h to afford colorless single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The product was isolated by acetone washing in 57% yield. The compound is insoluble in common organic solvents such as THF, acetone, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN or water. The single crystal X-ray structure analysis showed that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in the C-centered, noncentrosymmetric space group <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2 (No. 5). Crystallographic data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, C<ce:inf loc="post">20</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, monoclinic <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2 (No. 5), <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>=24.624(1), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>=9.7554(5), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>=13.5956(7) Å, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>=120.663(1)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>=2809.2(2) Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>=4, <ce:italic>ρ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">calc</ce:inf>=1.980 g cm<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>=1.740 mm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>=295 K, structure solution and refinement based on 5239 reflections including Friedel mates (3254 unique) with <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">o</ce:inf>≥3.0<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">o</ce:inf>) converged at <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>=0.0342, <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf>=0.0481 and goodness-of-fit=1.85. Data were collected on a Siemens SMART diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073 Å). An empirical absorption correction based on redundant reflections was applied to the data set. The absolute configuration was unambiguously assigned based on the analysis of the Bijovot pairs and the refinement of the Flack parameter. The absence of inversion center in the structure was also confirmed by MISYM. The refinement of Flack parameter for the chosen configuration gave 0.00020(9) with 5239 reflections where <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>(H) and <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">c</ce:inf>(–H) differ by more than 0.0001. The asymmetric unit contains two Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ions, two 4,4′-bipy ligands, two SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions, and three coordinate and three crystallization water molecules. The metal centers are first linked by the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions to form the one-dimensional arrays of fused 12-membered rings containing three cadmium, three sulfur and six oxygen atoms (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor>). The arrays are drawn together by hydrogen bonding between the coordinate water molecules and the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions from the adjacent net. The two SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions are split into μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging ligands. Thus, Cd(1) is coordinated by a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup>, a μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> and two <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules while the Cd(2) is linked by a μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup>, two different μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions and a water. The 4,4′-bipy ligands act as ‘posts’ that connect the cadmium centers to form the one-dimensional [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4+</ce:sup> chains. The coordination of both Cd atoms can best be described as slightly distorted octahedral with four O atoms situated in the square plane and two N atoms occupying the axial positions. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor> depicts the coordination environments of the two Cd atoms. Rather than being parallel, these chains run across each other from two different directions. Thus, the compound forms three-dimensional interwoven networks as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG3"></ce:float-anchor>. The most common coordination modes of the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> ion are monodentate, bidentate and μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging, while μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging is much less frequent . The combination of both μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- and μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-bridging in the same structure is hitherto unreported. The fact that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric space group can perhaps be attributed to this unusual combination of the two different bridging modes for the SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anion. We have noticed that the use of simple, weaker coordinating anions such as NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> results in centrosymmetric more often than noncentrosymmetric crystal packing.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Two interpenetrating coordination polymers are assembled from Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and 4-(2-ethyl-1<ce:italic>H</ce:italic>-imidazol-1-yl)benzate.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The synthetic methods include solvothermal condition and layer diffusion.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">They display 3-fold <ce:bold>pcu</ce:bold> and 4-fold <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> interpenetrating networks.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Interconvertible structural transformations between them are studied.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Long-standing interest in the area of coordination polymers (CPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) stems from their tectonic aesthetics of crystalline architectures and potential functions in fields of optical, magnetic, electronic, catalysis, chiral, and microporous crystalline materials . At this stage, design of the target materials is based upon the sophisticated selection and utilization of specific organic and inorganic building tectons . Furthermore, some accessorial reaction parameters, such as pH , solvent , anion , and additive , are also critical for the fabrication of well-defined CPs. In comparison, studies on the regulation effect of CPs and their reversible structural transformations, via tuning distinct synthetic approaches, have been rarely reported . As a continuation of our research , we will present herein two distinct Zn(II) CPs of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Zn(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) via solvothermal synthesis and layer diffusion method, respectively.
<ce:footnote id="fn0005">
<ce:label>1</ce:label>
<ce:note-para id="np0005" view="all">Synthesis of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(OH)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>. Mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (29.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and 2-Heiba (21.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. Colorless block single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were collected by cooling to room temperature at a rate of 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h (yield: 15.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg). Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">34</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C,54.49; H,4.32; N,10.59%. Found: C, 54.68; H, 4.29; N, 10.39%. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3401m, 3146m, 3058m, 1617vs, 1561m, 1513m, 1466m, 1379vs, 1307w, 1254w, 1176m, 1149w, 1107w, 1053s, 1009w, 960w, 879w, 849m, 788s, 743w, 722m, 644w, 617w, 584w, 547m, 524w, 504w, 458w, 411w. Synthesis of {[Zn(2-eiba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>
<ce:bold>(2)</ce:bold>. A methanol solution (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of 2-Heiba (21.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was carefully layered onto a water solution (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (29.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in a glass tube. Colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained by slow evaporation of the solvent at room temperature after three days (yield: 18.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg). Anal. Calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>Zn: C, 52.42; H, 5.13; N, 10.19%. Found: C, 52.46; H, 5.18; N, 10.11%. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>): 3405b, 1632vs, 1575w, 1510m, 1462m, 1361vs, 1308m, 1251w, 1172m, 1147w, 1110w, 1053s, 1012m, 874w, 843m, 787m, 704m, 574m, 546m, 513m, 442w.</ce:note-para>
</ce:footnote> Single-crystal X-ray structural analyses reveal that they display different entangled architectures, 3-fold and 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4-fold types, respectively. More interestingly, interconvertible structrual transformations between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be achieved with intensive rearrangement of the overall crystalline lattice. Thermal stability and fluorescence properties of these complexes have also been studied.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">4,4′-Bipyrazolyl originally was synthesized by Trofimenko in a laborious nine step procedure starting with diethyl succinate via 3,4-diformylfuran and 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide intermediates . Unfortunately, bipyrazolyls are inaccessible through Ullmann coupling of 4-halogenated pyrazoles . A more efficient way to 1,1,2,2-ethanetetraaldehide, that is the closest precursor to <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>, is hydrolysis of bis-trimethinium salts [(R<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NCH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC(CHNR<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Solid [(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NCH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CC(CHNMe<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (22.71 g, 0.05 mol)  was added to a solution of NaOH (10.06 g, 0.25 mol) in 60 ml water and the mixture was heated for 12 min on water bath with external temperature at 80–82<ce:hsp sp="0.5"></ce:hsp>°C. Total dissolution of perchlorate and evolution of dimethylamine was observed within minutes; slightly yellow solution was acidified with HCl (1:1) to pH 3 and excess of hydrazine hydrate (8.0 ml) was added at once with stirring. Resulting yellow–brown mixture was left overnight, the deposit of <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> was filtered off and recrystallized from aq. DMF to yield 5.51 g (82%) of colorless crystals. They are stable on air and did not melt up to 300<ce:hsp sp="0.5"></ce:hsp>°C (!) and very poorly soluble in all usual solvents. Solubility in DMF at r.t. is 0.73 g/100 ml. <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR (Bruker, 400 MHz, DMSO-d<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic> ppm): 7.78 (4H, CH), 12.74 (2H, NH).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Zinc and cadmium complexes with <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> are sparingly soluble in alcohols. Crystallization of coordination polymers was conducted under slow diffusion of CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> vapors into solutions of the components in MeOH. Colorless prismatic crystals of the nitrate complexes possess different stoichiometry: [Zn(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Cd(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), while metal perchlorates form isomorphous compounds [M(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>8</ce:bold>: M=Cd, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=4; <ce:bold>9</ce:bold>: M=Zn, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=3.5).</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Cobalt(II) chloride complexes were synthesized using the layering technique. A typical procedure was as follows: in a glass tube the solution of 0.040 g (0.3 mmol) <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> in 6 ml DMF (first layer), 5 ml of 1:1 DMF/methanol mixture and solution of 0.036 g (0.15 mmol) CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 5 ml MeOH were layered each on the top of the other avoiding interfusion. The crystals of the product grew on walls of the tube as the solutes slowly interdiffused for the period of 7–10 days. The product consists of two complexes, crystals of which were separated manually: [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2DMF (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>), light-pink blocks and [Co(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>), pink prisms.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">An easy, but specific procedure was employed for crystallization of copper(II) coordination polymers. Thus, solutions of 0.110 g (0.35 mmol) CuSiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in 2 ml water and 0.088 g (0.72 mmol) KClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in 3 ml water were combined and precipitate of K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SiF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf> was filtered off. To the resulting copper(II) chlorate solution 0.094 g (0.70 mmol) of solid <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> was added and the mixture was stored at room temperature for about 50 days that effected total dissolution of the ligand and crystallization of the complex [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>10</ce:bold>) as large deep cyan–blue blocks. The yield was 0.14 g (70%). In similar conditions, reaction of solid <ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic> ligand with aq. solutions of copper(II) salts afforded well-crystalline products: [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), light-green and [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)](NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), green–blue. This procedure, under presence of water soluble aromatics, also allows the preparation of inclusion compounds, cf. [Cu(<ce:italic>bpz</ce:italic>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O·C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>OH (<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>), blue prisms.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Heating a solution of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CMe)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>], CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′ (3:1:3) in DMF at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in a sealed tube for 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, followed by slow cooling down to ambient temperature, gave dark green crystals of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) directly from the reaction solution; the yield was ca. 50% . With the identity of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> established by crystallography , a convenient synthesis of the pure material was sought under alternative reaction conditions. Thus, the reaction of three equivalents of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with two equivalents of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>L′, in the presence of four equivalents of LiOH<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, in DMF and layering of Et<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1:1 v/v) onto the resulting olive green solution gave dark green crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; the yield is ∼70%.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the ligand</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The ligand was synthesized according to a procedure described earlier . All other chemicals were commercially available and used without purification.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the coordination compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0035" view="all">The compounds were prepared following the present general procedure: 1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol of the copper(II) salt (Cu(BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, (Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and 1.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol of the ligand were each dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of water. The copper(II) salt solution was subsequently added slowly to the ligand solution and the resulting mixture was filtered to remove any non-dissolved material. After a few days to a week the products separated as very small crystals. The yield for all three compounds is in the range 70–80%. Elemental analysis: <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>B<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuF<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): C, 29.2; H, 4.3; N, 25.6. Found: C, 29.1; H, 4.2; N, 25.6%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>): C, 31.6; H, 4.6; N, 32.2. Found: C, 31.5; H, 4.6; N, 32.3%. <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CuN<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>): C, 37.0; H, 4.7; N, 32.4. Found: C, 36.9; H: 4.6; N, 32.4%.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of the complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were grown from solvothermal reactions of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.3448<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> (0.0444<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and PDC (0.0167<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in the mixed solvents of DMF and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (v/v<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3:3) in a 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL acid-digestion bomb at 90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>d. The product was washed with water and dried under vacuum. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was isolated as a single-phase product (yield: 45.3% based on L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>). Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">53</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">54</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">25</ce:inf>Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>: C 43.5, H 3.7, N 7.7. Found: C 43.4, H 3.5, N 7.8. FT-IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3436.44<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1414.27<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1511.31<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1442.32<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1365.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1302.85<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1212.80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1062.56<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 1032.92<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 916.60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s, 853.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 769.16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 737.90<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 691.71<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w, 538.54<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>w.</ce:para>

<ce:simple-para id="sp0080" view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: The mixture of CoSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Ni(Ac)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), Htpba (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), distilled water (9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) and DMF (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) were stirred about 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air, then transferred and sealed in a 17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave, which were heated at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 96<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under autogenous pressure. After the autoclave was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h, purple block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and green block crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained, washed with distilled water several times, and dried at ambient temperature. We speculate that the DMF and/or (CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NH may act as bases during the preparation procedures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, yield: 51% based on tpba. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>CoMo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>: C, 36.15; H, 3.29; Co, 7.39; Mo, 24.07; N, 7.03%. Found: C, 36.24; H, 3.21; Co, 7.35; Mo, 24.12; N, 7.09%. For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, yield: 55% based on tpba. Elemental analysis (%) calcd for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>NiMo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>: C, 36.17; H, 3.29; Mo, 24.07; N, 7.03; Ni, 7.36%. Found: C, 36.22; H, 3.25; Mo, 24.11; N, 7.12; Ni, 7.31%.</ce:simple-para>

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">A mixture of Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.012<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>TZI (0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol, 0.012<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), DMF 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was stayed at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 48<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. Light yellow block crystals were obtained and dried in air (70% yield based on Zn). EA (%) <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. <ce:simple-para id="sp0055" view="all">All reagents were of analytical grade and were used as obtained from commercial sources without further purification. H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba (0.13<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL deionized water and the pH value was adjusted to 8 with 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M NaOH. Under constant stirrer, CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O(0.12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml aqueous solution was added in the mixture, then light pink turbid solution was obtained, and then phen(0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml ethanol solution was added in the mixture. The mixture was placed in Teflon–lined stainless reactor and heated at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 4 d. The resulting solution was cooled to room temperature. Pink crystal of complex was obtained. (the yield is ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>50%). for C<ce:inf loc="post">66</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>: anal. calcd, %: C, 60.69; H, 3.07; N, 4.29; O, 18.39. Found, %: C, 60.57; H, 3.32; N, 4.21; O, 18.45. <ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">
<ce:display>

<ce:caption>

</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="mmc1"></ce:link>
</ce:e-component>
</ce:display>
</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">The phosphonic acid with formula (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)-NC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N-(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>), was prepared according to Moedritzer Irani method. The crude product was dissolved in THF to obtain a white precipitate, that was triturated (stirred) overnight, the white solid was then filtered, washed with fresh THF and oven dried to yield the title compound (86%). Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained under solvothermal conditions by mixing 0.404<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of Ce(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) with 0.328<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of bispiperidine diphosphonic acid (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml of distilled water and the mixture was placed in closed Teflon bottle and maintained at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for two days. A pale-yellow powder precipitate was recovered in 86% yield.</ce:simple-para>

Dark red block crystals of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were obtained by following a similar procedure to those of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, but thiourea (1.0 mg, 0.013 mmol) was used instead of selenourea and Ru(Phen)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (1.0 mg, 0.001 mmol) was used instead of Ru(Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (20% yield). </ce:para><ce:section-title id="st0040">Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Supplementary data to this article can be found online at <ce:inter-ref id="ir0005" xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2013.10.034" xlink:type="simple">http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.inoche.2013.10.034</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para><ce:simple-para id="sp0060" view="all">
<ce:italic>Synthesis of polymer 1</ce:italic>: Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC(0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and L ligand(0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were sealed in a Teflon reactor with 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF and 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, and heated at 115<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>day, and then cooled to room temperature at 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/h, and colorless crystal was obtained in the yield of 79%, based on Zn. EA analysis (%): calc. C/50.86, N/9.23,H/5.03; exp. C/50.97, N/9.34, H/5.12. (All regents are analytically pure, and water is distilled water).</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>[{Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">0.2095 g (0.7453 mmol) CoSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 0.1036 g (0.4751 mmol) 1,4-butylenediphosphonic acid were dissolved in 10 ml distilled water. A small amount of precipitate appeared after the pH of the solution adjusted to 3.21 with 1.000 mol l<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> NaOH. Dimethylsulfoxide (2 ml) was added to the solution with vigorous stirring. Then the solution was filtered into a 25-ml beaker and left at ambient temperature. After 70 days, red block crystals were obtained in poor yield.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>[{Ni(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">0.1731 g (0.7283 mmol) NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 0.1041 g (0.4773 mmol) 1,4-butylenediphosphonic acid were dissolved in 10 ml distilled water. A small amount of green precipitate appeared after the pH of the solution was adjusted to 4.31 with 1.000 mol l<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> NaOH. The mixture was stirred homogeneously after 2 ml DMSO was added to the solution. Green cuboid crystals were obtained after the solution was filtered into a 25-ml beaker and left at ambient temperature for 40 days. The green crystals were filtered, dried at ambient temperature and yielded 36% based on 1,4-butylenediphosphonic acid. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: C 11.47, H 6.26, Ni 14.01%; Found: C 11.64, H 5.45, Ni 13.59%. A small amount of blue precipitate appeared after the pH of the solution was adjusted to 1.75 with 1.000 mol l<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> NaOH. Blue flake-like crystals were obtained after the solution was filtered into a test tube, layered with 2-ml isopropyl alcohol and left at ambient temperature for 110 days. The pH of the solution was slowly adjusted to 2.00 with 1.000 mol l<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> NaOH. Then 0.100 g (1.67 mmol) urea was added to the solution and dissolved. Colorless block single crystals were obtained after the solution filtered into a 50-ml flask and kept at 55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24 h. The crystals were filtered, washed with distilled water, dried at ambient temperature and yielded 18% based on 1,4-butylenediphosphonic acid.</ce:para>

Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>⋅4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (30.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), tpt (15.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, 0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>bpta (16.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg,0.05<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was mixed in 14<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL DMF in a vial. The vial was sealed and allowed to stand at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. As the reaction progresses, light yellow rod shape crystal formed. Homogeneous crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected, washed with DMF, and dried in air (yield: 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg). Anal. found: C, 50.83; H, 4.19; N, 13.52%.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In a typical procedure pytac (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), cobalt nitrate or cadmium iodide (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and ammonium vanadate (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), were placed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon-lined autoclave with 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min and held at that temperature for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. At the end of this period, the autoclave was cooled to 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C at 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min and held at that temperature for 12<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h before cooling to room temperature at the same rate. Cobalt nitrate and pytac were utilized for the synthesis of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. An irregular orange crystal fragment was cleaved from a multi-crystalline mass and used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cobalt nitrate, ammonium vanadate, and pytac were used in the synthesis of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. An irregular, orange-red crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis. Cadmium iodide and pytac were used to synthesize complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. A yellow bar-shaped crystal was used for the single-crystal X-ray analysis.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st040">Synthesis of the catalyst</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">A mixture of (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.124<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.052<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 4,4′-bipy (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.047<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), 1,10-phenanthroline (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.036<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g), KF (0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol, 0.017<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml) was stirred for 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min in air. The starting pH value of the mixture was adjusted to 5.5 by the addition of diluted ethylenediamine solution followed by transferring it to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and keeping it at 165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days. After slow cooling to room temperature, the resulting product containing 0.162<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g of a mixture of blue (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and yellow ([Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (4,4′-bipy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-bipyridine and 1,10-phen<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,10-phenanthroline) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)  crystals, was filtered off, washed with distilled water and dried in air.</ce:para>

<ce:bold>[NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pip)]</ce:bold> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)<ce:bold>.</ce:bold> To a 16<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL ethanol, NiCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this work, our strategy for constructing framework was to combine the chalcogenide cluster [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> with La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup>. The wide variety of applications that lanthanide complexes have in many fields is well-known , such as contrast agents or luminescent chemosensors, and explains the growing interest to the coordination and supramolecular chemistry of trivalent lanthanide ions . Researches in this field are mainly focused on efficient light converting devices. In a precedent work, we described a new hybrid layered compound La<ce:inf loc="post">0.75</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">0.25</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>18H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O obtained at room temperature and ambient pressure in acidic solution starting from the cluster [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation . In this compound, the hanging carboxylate functions of the nitrilotriacetic acid ligand were still available for further coordinations. We thus attempted to engage the free remaining carboxylate functions and hydrothermal conditions proved to be the best strategy for functionalisation.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Herein, we describe a 3D network resulting from the direct connexions between the preformed building block [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation, obtained by hydrothermal synthesis La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">In a previous work , the pHmetric titration of the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion revealed that the three hanging carboxylates deprotonate quasi-simultaneously at pH ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>4.5 (pKa ~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>3.5), leading to [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>. In the presence of the La<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>+</ce:sup> cation and at a pH above 4.5, a green precipitate formed at room temperature. All attempts to get crystals from this precipitate under deprotonation conditions (pH<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>4.5) invariably failed as a result of the high insolubility of the La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in these conditions. Crystals of La<ce:inf loc="post">0.75</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">0.25</ce:inf>[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(HNTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>18H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O were only obtained by working in acidic medium. Thus, hydrothermal synthesis was envisioned as a possible alternative to conventional synthesis and crystals of La<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl[Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>17H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold> were finally obtained at pH 5 by heating at 100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>hours, followed by a slow cooling rate . Interest of hydrothermal syntheses compared to traditional aqueous reactions is that the reaction conditions are shifted from the kinetic to the thermodynamic domain and thereby provides a powerful tool for the synthesis of hybrid materials.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In summary, this work shows that the free hanging carboxylate functions of [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>S<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(NTA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">5<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anion can be bounded to La(III) ions by hydrothermal synthesis to build a new 3D-network. Our strategy of synthesis reveals to be appropriate to exploit the overall potentialities of this cluster to isolate 3D networks. In further work we will attempt to modify the free carboxylate functions by using a longer alkyl chain to see for instance if 3D networks with interesting properties such as porosities could be achieved.</ce:para>

<ce:simple-para id="sp0065" view="all">Intensity measurements were carried out on a Bruker X8 diffractometer equipped with a CCD bidimensional detector using monochromatised Mo-Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). An absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program  based on the Blessing method . The structures were solved by direct methods followed by Fourier difference syntheses using the SHELXTL package. All atoms except hydrogen atoms were anisotropically refined. H atoms were fixed in calculated positions. Selected interatomic distances (Å) are given in  for <ce:bold>(1)</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Four 3,5-diamino-1,2,4-triazole (Hdatrz)-based cobalt(II/III) coordination polymers, {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(Hdatrz)(NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·0.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Co(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)(Hdatrz)(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip)]·2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and {[Co(datrz)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) (NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-aminoisophthalate, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-methylisophthalate and NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-nitroisophthalate), were hydro-/solvothermally synthesized by changing the substituents attached on the isophthalate coligand, which were structurally and magnetically characterized. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a corrugated layer with dimeric {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> subunits extended by three-connected NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> connectors. Constructed from the same mixed ligands, both <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit robust three-dimensional (3D) frameworks consisting of helical {Co(μ-N1,N4-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> chain and corner-sharing triangular {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-N1,N2,N4-datrz)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> layer, respectively. By contrast, two bis-monodentate NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> and two μ-N1,N4-datrz<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions connect tetrahedral Co(III) sites into a (4, 4) grid-like layer of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. Thus, the substituent of the isophthalate coligand is observed to virtually influence the overall structures of the resulting complexes by changing the binding modes of the coligand and coordination polyhedra. Additionally, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a metamagnetic transition from antiferromagnetic ordering to weak ferromagnetic state. Instead, typically antiferromagnetic interactions are respectively mediated by the cyclic triazolate ligand along the helical chain of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and in the distorted triangular layer of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st060">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st065">Syntheses and IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> bearing different 5-substituted isophthalate coligands were solvo/hydrothermally synthesized by significant varying the reaction temperatures of the reactant mixture. Other experimental conditions, such as the cobalt source, solvent medium, pH and reaction time, can also influence the formation of the crystalline products of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>. In addition, the preparations of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with the same mixed ligands and different structures depended also on the molar ratio of Hdatrz and CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ip (1:1 for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and 2: 1 for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). In the IR spectra, a broad absorption centered at <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 3400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is resulting from the stretching vibration of O–H, confirming the presence of water molecule. One (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) or two weak bands at 3349–3070<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> should be ascribed to the stretching vibrations of N–H, suggesting the occurrence of exocyclic amino group of triazolate ligand. Characteristic weak absorptions for aromatic C–H vibration is observed at approximately 3100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. As compared with the free organic acids, the disappearance of a strong band at 1698, 1702 and 1719<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is an indicative of the full deprotonation of the three substituted isophthalate coligands. Correspondingly, the multiple bands for the asymmetric (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">as</ce:inf>) and symmetric (<ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">s</ce:inf>) stretching vibrations of the carboxylate group are observed between 1670 and 1348<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and their different separations suggest the variable coordination modes of the carboxylate group .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The unique Co1 and Co2 octahedra are hold together by one neutral μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz ligand, generating a dimeric {Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz)}<ce:sup loc="post">4+</ce:sup> subunit with the intermetallic separation of 3.6810(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Acting as a three-connected connector, the doubly deprotonated NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> coligand present its amino and two deprotonated carboxylate moieties to extend the dimeric subunits into a corrugated 2D layer with the inter-dimeric Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>⋯Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> separations of <ce:italic>ca</ce:italic>. 11.7, 9.0 and 10.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (b), which are much longer than that bridged by μ-N1,N2-Hdatrz ligand. The isolated 2D sheets of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> interact with each other <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> N–H⋯O hydrogen-bonding interactions between the triazolyl moiety of Hdatrz ligand and the carboxylate group of the NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> anion, leading to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular architecture of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with the interlayer distance of 8.85069<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å ().</ce:para>

Furthermore, the individual layers of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are stacked together into a 3D supramolecular network through O–H⋯O hydrogen bonding interactions between the lattice water and the nitro/carboxylate group of NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-ip<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ligand ().</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">We have investigated coordination polymers with chalcogen atoms in the organic bridging ligands , and have reported on two coordination polymers, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2DMF (oba<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-oxybis(benzoate)) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Zn(oba)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) in a recent communication. These two compounds show reversible structural transformations depending on the present solvents. In ongoing work, we have successfully created two new zinc coordination polymers constructed from heteroorganic bridges: oba- and bis-pyridine-type ligands, i.e., <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene (bpe) and 4,4′-azopyridine (azpy). Despite the similar structures of the two ancillary ligands, the structures of the resulting compounds, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(azpy)(dmf)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6DMF (azpy<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′-azopyridine) (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(oba)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bpe)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>), show different network structures. The network motifs of these compounds are illustrated in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>. This paper describes the synthesis and crystal structures of coordination polymers <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Diffusion of a DMF solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>oba and azpy into a DMF solution of Zn(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O yielded single crystals of Compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. An ORTEP view around the zinc centers is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>a. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. The carboxylate ligands of the oba group bind to the zinc center via a four-membered chelation, in which the two Zn–O bond distances differ significantly: Zn(1)–O(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.091(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Zn(1)–O(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.231(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Zn(1)–O(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.283(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and Zn(1)–O(4)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.096(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. In addition to the four carboxylate oxygen atoms, an additional oxygen atom of a dmf molecule and a pyridine nitrogen atom of an azpy group are coordinated to the zinc center. The above coordination center is based on the markedly distorted octahedron observed. This is due to the four-membered carboxylate chelation, in which the N(1) atom of the azpy group and the O(3) atom of the oba group occupy the axial positions at the N(1)–Zn(1)–O(3) group with a bond angle of 151.2(1)°.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">A MOF is changed into another one by soaking in methanol.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Both extended structures consist of two interpenetrating MOFs.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Both structures are featured with 12-connected Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> clusters as the nodes.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st090">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">A novel Co(II)-based metal–organic framework, namely {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(DMF)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (BTE)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>} (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>; BTE<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4,4′,4″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyltris-(ethyne-2,1-diyl))tribenzoate) was obtained by solvothermal synthesis and structurally determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction, TG–DSC analysis, elemental analysis and IR spectroscopy. After soaked in methanol, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was turned into another compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, namely {[Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(OH)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] (BTE)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}, through single crystal-to-single crystal transform. These two structures are featured with some 12-connected Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> nodes which are bridged by tripod BTE ligands into the interpenetrating frameworks. The gas sorption behaviors were examined.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted increasing attention due to their intriguing architectures and potential applications in the areas of gas adsorption/separation, catalysis, nonlinear optics, magnetism and so on . Much effort has been devoted to the construction of MOFs with tunable properties using metal clusters as secondary building units (SBUs) and organic ligands as linkers . Compared with the way to rationalize novel network topologies and improve the properties by designing the linkers, it is a rather complex process to build MOFs with in situ generated polynuclear units as SBUs . The creation of anticipated cluster, especially high-connected cluster SBUs, is still a challenge. Some compounds based on polynuclear Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>
<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2–8) clusters and multicarboxylate have been reported . Dietzel et al. reported a MOF compound with 1D pores containing some Co(II) chains as infinite-rod SBUS and 2,5-dioxido-1,4-benzenedicarboxylate as the linker . Recently, Han and co-workers prepared two 6-connected 3D frameworks with Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> or Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> cluster SBUs .</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Here we present two novel MOFs based on the pentanuclear Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> clusters as the nodes and 4,4′,4″-(benzene-1,3,5-triyltris-(ethyne-2,1-diyl))tribenzoate (BTE<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>) as the linker. More precisely, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> we obtained one by solvothermal synthesis and compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was obtained by soaking <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> in methanol to replace the bonded/adsorbed DMF solvent with methanol. Both structures consist of two interpenetrated 3D metal–organic frameworks. It should be noted that all the Co<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> clusters exhibit a rarely reported 12-connected coordination mode while the Co sites in these two structures show different coordination modes. The gas sorption of the extended structure was investigated.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The rational synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has attracted considerable attention because of their structural diversity and potential application in catalysis, gas storage and separation etc. . Chemical synthesis of MOFs is largely dependent on the use of solvents, and the well-known synthetic methods include hydrothermal, solvothermal and ionothermal synthesis . Recently, urothermal synthesis that use urea derivatives as solvents opened a new approach toward the creation of porous framework materials with promising applications . One particular feature of urothermal method is that urea derivatives exhibit a range of binding affinity for various metal cationic sites, which is strong enough to allow them to bond competitively to metal sites during crystallization, and yet weak enough to be readily removed after synthesis to generate porosity and open metal sites.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Simple urothermal synthesis were performed by mixing different metal salts, naphthalenedicarboxylic acid and ethyleneurea hemihydrate in the vials at 120 °C for 3 days. Four kinds of crystals (compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) were obtained and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, respectively. Interestingly, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> are isostructural and exhibit similar structural feature as the well-known MIL-53 .</ce:para>
