<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The structures are reported of three coordination polymers formed by the hexadentate O-donor ligand hexakis(<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-pyridin-4-one-methyl)benzene (HPMB). The structure of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPMB)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·HPMB)(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>·8H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O comprises chains of 32-membered rings cross-linked by hydrogen bonds to tapes of protonated HPMB ligands. Crystals of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPMB)Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·10H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O form chains of larger, 62-membered, rings with neighbouring chains cross-linked by hydrogen bonds to form sheets. In [Co(HPMB)](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·8MeOH·3.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O all six oxygen atoms of each HPMB ligand coordinate to a cobalt atom resulting in the formation of a contiguous 3-D network emulating the sodium chloride lattice, and containing substantial cavities and channels.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st050">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st055">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">MOFs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are built from almost the same reaction conditions, except for the metal/ligand ratio. The reactant ratio seems to play a key role for the construction of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, because our attempts of the reactant ratio variation under the certain external experimental conditions have led to these complexes rather than any other interesting products formation. The experiments with variation of the reactant ratio also disclosed the critical value of stoichiometric ratios of used precursors on the formation of the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. The result suggests that the reaction is sensitive to the reactant ratio.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st065">IR spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">The characteristic bands observer at 3422<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 3426<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> suggest the stretching vibrations <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>OH) of hydrogen bonds. There is no absorption peaks around 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>, which indicates that all carboxyl groups (<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>COOH) of the organic ligands are deprotonated completely<ce:italic>.</ce:italic> The asymmetric and symmetric vibrations peaks of the carboxylate groups can be found at 1622 and 1384<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and 1610 and 1429<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">In summary, through careful consideration of asymmetrical carboxyl-rich ligand, biphenyl-2,3,3′,5′-tetracarboxylic acid, two distinct nanoporous Cu-MOFs are constructed by modification of reactant ratio. The asymmetrical “short axis – long axis” nature of the ligand possessing long molecular backbone and inclined carboxyls leads to the noninterpenetrating features of the synthesized complexes with high porosity. It also shows a rare example of clusters-based framework with the coexistence of triple polynuclear cluster SBUs of tetranuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(<ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] clusters, dinuclear [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] clusters surrounded by cage-like units, and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>] paddle-wheel fragments. Whereas, the MOF <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the structural changes with less complicated mononuclear Cu(bptca)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and paddle-wheel Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>. The results reveal the importance of synthetic strategy and external factors such as reactant ratio for structural designing of porous MOFs. Thus, it could be predicted that more porous MOFs with fascinating structural merits and adsorption properties are to be designed and constructed under control.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">We herein utilize 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)diphthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) for the construction of cluster-based Ln-MOF from the following reasons: 1) besides versatile coordination modes generated by multicarboxylate groups, H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L has three configurations (
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>) caused by the rotation of C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C bonds between the <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>C(CF<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> group and two end benzene rings , which can satisfy the complex coordination geometry of lanthanide center; 2) the adjacent arrangement of the carboxylate groups on each benzene ring can allow the neighboring carboxylate groups to bind different lanthanide centers, generating metal-carboxylate cluster; 3) H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L has recently been utilized to construct MOFs with transition metal ions Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, respectively, which display well luminescent, magnetic and sorptive properties , however, Ln-MOF containing H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L is still unexplored. In our latest work, a microporous Cd-MOF has been assembled with H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L, in which the unique structural character of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L makes the MOF have hydrophilic/hydrophobic channels and excellent sorption capacity for CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
. Ongoing with our interest in structural and functional investigations of metal multicarboxylate frameworks, a new dinuclear- and tetranuclear-based terbium framework [Tb<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>]·7H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) with L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> as linkers has been synthesized.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Hydrothermal reaction of Tb(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 4,4′-(hexafluoroisopropylidene)diphthalic anhydride and NaOH in a 2:1:4 molar ratio in water at 150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C afforded colorless needle-like crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, with a high yield of 82.7% , which was characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction , elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The phase purity of the bulk sample was identified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) (Fig. S1). In the IR spectrum of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, there is no carbonyl C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching peak at around 1700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> from <ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>COOH group, indicting H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L is fully-deprotonated in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st095">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0010" view="all">Three cobalt(II) complexes with the formulas: {H[CoL<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·4.17MeOH·13.3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), and {[Co(HL)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), were obtained by self-assembly of the cobalt(II) salt with HL (HL<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1-(imidazol-1-yl)-4-(imidazol-4-yl)benzene) under different conditions. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 2-fold interpenetrated porous <ce:bold>crs</ce:bold> framework filled with water molecules and methanol molecules, in which the metal atom has distorted octahedral coordination geometry and the ligand was deprotonated. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the HL without deprotonation links two different Co(II) atoms to form an infinite 1D chain. While complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with octahedral Co(II) atom is a 4-fold interpenetrated <ce:bold>dia</ce:bold> framework with chloride as counteranions and no deprotonation of the ligand occurred under room temperature condition. In addition, the stability properties of the complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were studied.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="st075">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">On the basis of a rational designed rigid imidazol-1-yl- and imidazol-4-yl-containing ligand HL, three novel cobalt complexes have been synthesized from different synthesized conditions. Both <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have 3D structure by layering diffusion method, but complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with octahedral metal center was obtained as 2-fold interpenetrated <ce:italic>crs</ce:italic> coordination framework with water molecules and methanol molecules filled in the vacancy, while complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with octahedral metal center displays 4-fold interpenetration with Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions as counteranions and filled in the vacancy. Meanwhile, complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has an infinite 1D chain structure under hydrothermal method using the same materials as complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The results indicate the reaction conditions have remarkable impact on the structure of the complex. TGA data showed that complexes have thermal stability.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The hydrothermal reactions of 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid (OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC) and different metal ions gave rise to three coordination polymers, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) [Ni(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Cd(bpp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). The long flexible bpp ligands adopt different conformations to take part in coordination in the three compounds.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:para view="all">In this regard, our synthetic strategy was to select an analogue of bpe or dpe: 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), and introduce benzenedicarboxylic acid (5-hydroxyisophthalic acid, OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC) as an auxiliary ligand into the reaction systems, with the following considerations: (1) Bpp, compared to bpe or dpe, has a longer and more flexible conformation. Accordingly, it possesses TT, TG, GG and GG′ conformations (<ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>, G<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>gauche</ce:italic>) owing to the free twist of the propyl group (–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>–). Thereby it can adopt different conformations to take part in coordination . (2) The aim of combining OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC into the reaction system is to simplify the control and modulation of the final results, because the deprotonated carboxylate groups, which possess rich coordination modes (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig11"></ce:float-anchor>), may act as anionic groups and afford neutral metal-organic frameworks. (3) The hydroxyl group (–OH) can provide hydrogen bonding interactions with other groups and further stabilize the structures. On the other hand, the architectures from mixed ligands of bpp and di-or poly-carboxylate ligands, to our knowledge, are still rare to date , although some metal-organic frameworks from the direct assembly of bpp and metal ions have been investigated . Herein, we wish to report the syntheses and characterizations of three interpenetrated coordination polymers, {[Co(bpp)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Ni(bpp)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Cd(bpp)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(OH-BDC)]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O}<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), assembly from bpp, OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC with Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions, respectively. All of the three compounds display interpenetrated structures. Exo-bidentate bpp in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> adopts a TG conformation, while bpp in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> acts as a terminal and exo-bidentate ligand with TT and TG conformations, respectively.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Syntheses and characterizations</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were synthesized through the hydrothermal reactions of bpp, OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC with Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Ni<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> salts, respectively. Similar to the previous reports by us and some other groups, the –OH group of HO-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC is not involved in coordination to the transition metal ions and only serves as a donor for hydrogen bonds to stabilize the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (see below), however, the –OH group as an electron-donating group may influence the self-assembly process although the reaction mechanism still remains unclear, because the expected results were not obtained when using <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-isophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC) instead of HO-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BDC under the same hydrothermal condition. The IR spectra of the three compounds exhibit strong characteristic vibrational bands of the carboxylate groups. For <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the characteristic bands of the carboxylate groups are shown at 1575<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the antisymmetric stretching band and 1401<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the symmetric stretching band. The separation (<ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic>) between <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">asym</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">sym</ce:inf>(CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) is 174<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, one antisymmetric stretching band (1562<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) and two symmetric stretching bands (1412 and 1357<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) are exhibited, the <ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic> values are 150 and 205<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively. For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups are at 1564 and 1387<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, with a <ce:italic>Δ</ce:italic> value ca. 177<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The results are consistent with the different coordination modes of the carboxylate groups in the three compounds, one coordination mode in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, two coordination modes in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> () .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0045" view="all">It is interesting to note that just by using different solvents under the same reaction conditions two compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with different structures have been obtained by the same ligand and metal salt. More interestingly, both compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have neutral 3D porous frameworks with different shape, and the former one is constructed by 2D (4, 4) metal-carboxylate network, while the later one contains a 2D Kagomé net connected by the benzenebicarboxylate of the ligand. The difference between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> implies that the reaction solvent plays crucial role in the formation of the porous frameworks.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">In summary, we have successfully synthesized two porous Zn(II) coordination frameworks with INAIP<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> by simply changing the solvent in the reaction system. The resulting compounds give neutral frameworks with different pore size and shape tuned by the solvent molecules, which imply that the solvents play a crucial role in the synthesis of various kinds of frameworks. In addition, the adsorption of complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> indicate that they have selective adsorptions of CO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> over N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> after the removal of the guest molecules within the pores.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">In conclusion, we have synthesized and structurally characterized a novel three-dimensional coordination polymer [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. Although molecular self-assembly approaches have been explored by Fujita et al. , Yaghi and Li , and several other groups  for making metal 4,4′-bipyridine coordination polymers containing non-coordinating anions such as NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>, the use of the coordinating anion SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> gives rise to a three-dimensional interwoven network structure because of the complex coordination mode of the anion. Such a novel molecular architecture is hitherto unknown. To the best of our knowledge, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first example of coordination polymers to show second-order nonlinear optical effects. The other known noncentrosymmetric coordination polymers include [Cu(pyrimidine)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), also a three-dimensional metal-pyridyl compound , [Cu(4,4′-bpy)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Cu(bpe)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) (bpe=<ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene),  both consisting of linear cationic chains with SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2−</ce:sup> anions as either spacers or cross-linkers between the chains. If a chiral ligand is used, noncentrosymmetric crystal packing can also be generated as in the case of [Zn(sala)]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>; H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>sala=<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-<ce:small-caps>l</ce:small-caps>-alanine) and [Zn(sala)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>) . It should be noted that all these coordination polymers could also display second-order NLO effects. The crystallization of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> in the noncentrosymmetric space groups seems to represent a useful way of influencing acentricity in the structure, i.e. in analogy to organic polymer chemistry, a coordinating anion can be used as a cross-linking agent to increase dimensionality and structural complexity. This may open up a new avenue to a potentially large class of second-order nonlinear optical materials.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In general, self-assembly reaction by varying distinct synthetic approaches could result in kinetic or thermodynamic products, respectively, which may be readily interconvertible . CPs <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be obtained from solvothermal and layered diffusion methods, respectively, and thus supposed to be kinetic and thermodynamic products . In order to study the structural transformation behaviors between <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, we dipped <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> into CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution under ambient stirring or placed <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> into Teflon-lined autoclave under solvothermal condition. On one hand, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can transform to <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at ambient stirring condition after one day, as determined by PXRD patterns (a<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). During this process, the shapes of crystals kept intact, but SC-XRD studies could not be performed despite repeated attempts, due to weak diffraction. On the other hand, transformation from <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> cannot be achieved only by dipping <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> into solution upon heating. If placing crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> in solution under solvothermal condition, white powders are generated which are proved to be <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> through PXRD patterns (b). However, the detailed mechanism of such process cannot be determined due to the black-box effect of solvothermal reaction.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0015" view="all">The hydrothermal reactions of a cobalt(II) salt and 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole in the presence of phosphate provided two three-dimensional materials of the M(II)/azolate/anion family [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) (M(II)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Co; azolate<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole or 4-Hpt; and anion<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and HPO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)). The structures are characterized by the incorporation of metal cluster secondary building units (SBU). The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> features a variant of the common {M<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-O)} sbu with the central bridging ligand provided by a phosphate oxygen rather than the more common oxo- or hydroxy-ligand. These trinuclear units are bridged through the remaining phosphate oxygen donors into chains which are in turn linked through the pyridyltetrazolate ligands into the framework structure. In the case of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, {Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">6+</ce:sup> linear trinuclear secondary building units are linked to four adjacent clusters through {HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> tetrahedra to generate cobalt(II)-hydrogen phosphate layers, which are linked through the 4-pt ligands into the overall framework.</ce:simple-para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">As an extension of these studies, materials of the M(II)/azolate/X system have recently been explored (where M(II)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Ni, Cu, Co, Mn, etc.; azolate<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>triazole and tetrazole, and X<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>a variety of anionic components including halides, pseudohalides, SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, MO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, Mo<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">x</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>O<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">y</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">n</ce:sup>
</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, etc. [M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>V, Mo, W]) . In the course of these studies, it was found that the identity of the anion can have dramatic effects on the structure and properties of the composite material, specifically when the anion was SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>. These results encouraged us to continue our investigations into the structural chemistry of systems featuring PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup>, a structural analog of sulfate, as a coordinating anion. The structures of two three-dimensional materials [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(PO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Co<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(4-pt)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HOPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) are reported (4-Hpt<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">All chemicals were used as obtained without further purification: cobalt(II) phosphate hydrate, cobalt (II) acetate tetrahydrate, and phosphoric acid were purchased from Aldrich. 5-(4-pyridyl)tetrazole was prepared by the “click” chemistry approach using zinc catalysis in aqueous solution or by the use of modified montmorillonite K-10 . All hydrothermal syntheses were carried out in 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL poly-(tetrafluoroethylene)-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. The reactants were stirred briefly, and the initial pH was measured before heating. Water was distilled above 3.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>MΩ in-housing using a Barnstead model 525 Biopure distilled water center. The initial and final pH values of each reaction were measured using color pHast sticks.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:section-title>Results and discussions</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Syntheses</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">Compounds were synthesized using conventional hydrothermal methods, which are routinely applied in the isolation of organic–inorganic composite materials. At these temperature ranges, typically 120–250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, the reactants are solubilized while retaining their structural features in the product phases, exploiting the self assembly of products from these soluble precursors . Under these crystallization conditions, problems associated with different solubilities of organic and inorganic starting materials are minimized, allowing for introduction of a variety of different organic and/or inorganic precursors, as well as organic and/or inorganic structure-directing or charge-balancing reagents. Such conditions may also allow for the isolation of kinetic rather than thermodynamically favored products.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Recently, great effort has been devoted to the self-assembly of organic and inorganic molecules in the solid state because it extends the range of new solids with desirable physical and chemical properties . The range and variety of self-assembled inorganic structures that can be constructed relies on suitable metal–ligand interactions and hydrogen bondings, and the various types of polymeric structures include 1-D, 2-D and 3-D network structures . Chiral coordination polymers containing nicotinate ligands , which display optical properties , were the subject of several studies during recent years. Despite some recent progress for the synthesis of chiral coordination polymers, the ability to predict and control the supramolecular assembly of these molecules remains an elusive goal, and much more work is required to understand the effects of the metal center and ligand on the patterns of the molecular structure in the solid state. During our investigation on the reactions of transition metal (II) complexes with nicotinic acid, we have obtained two chiral polymeric complexes which show 3-D and 2-D framework structures. The syntheses and crystal structures of Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (nic=nicotinate) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), and Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), form the subject of this report.</ce:para>

<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with nicotinic acid in refluxing methanol while the complex Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), was prepared by reaction of Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

<ce:para view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> make interesting comparisons with the mononuclear complexes Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
 and the three-dimensional Cu(II) coordination polymer Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
. The complexes Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> were prepared by the reactions of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, respectively, with nicotinic acid in NaOH solution (pH=6) at 60 °C. The coordination spheres of these two mononuclear complexes are octahedral, with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two aqua oxygen atoms in the equatorial positions and two aqua oxygen atoms in the axial positions. The complex Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was synthesized by treating copper nitrate with nicotinic acid under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions, and the Cu(II) centers adopt a coordination geometry intermediate between square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal. The tridentate nicotinate groups (with bridging carboxylate) link doubly carboxylate bridged Cu(II) dimers into a pleated-sheet structure through the coordination of their pyridyl nitrogen atoms, while the bidentate nicotinate groups link adjacent Cu centers to form zigzag chains along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis and thus cross-link the pleated sheets formed by the Cu centers and tridentate nicotinate groups to result in a complex 3-D framework structure . A complex of the same formula of Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> has also been prepared by reacting Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with nicotinic acid in the mole ratio of 2:1 for three days at 170 °C under hydrothermal conditions .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The synthesis of Porous Metal–Organic Frameworks (PMOFs) has gained much attention in recent years because of a variety of regulated and interesting structural topologies and many-potential applications . The successful preparation of porous materials is mainly dependent on the self assembly of metal ions and multi-dentate linkers with specific coordination geometry. The self-assembly process has been affected by many factors, involving coordination modes, the nature of linkers and reaction conditions . In fact, the key to synthesize these porous materials is the careful design of organic linkers. The nature of organic linkers can directly affect the structure diversity and properties of these materials due to the difference in the size, the flexibility, positions of functional groups and coordination modes to various metal ions . To date, extensive research efforts have been focused on the preparation of new organic linkers and their use in the assembly of new coordination polymers. However, the combination study on positional isomeric effect of organic linkers and the diversity of structure in these solids is of great importance in understanding the relationship between their structure and intrinsic properties.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">To evaluate the influence of positional isomeric effect on the formation of the coordination frameworks, we have introduced a couple of tetrahedral linkers as the tectons in this work. Among the N-donor tetrahedral linkers, tetrakis(4-pyridyloxymethylene) methane (L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>), is a good candidate for the construction of MOFs, due to their specific configurations and flexible conformers . In view of the structural similarity to L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>, we select another N-donor positional isomers and tetrahedral linker tetrakis(3-pyridyloxymethylene) methane (L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>). However, MOFs based on tetrahedral linker L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> remain largely unexplored so far. Here in, A couple of complexes based on metal ions, L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> or L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and PDC have synthesized under hydrothermal conditions: [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (1) and [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(PDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (2). These complexes are characterized by X-ray crystallography, elemental analysis, infrared spectra (IR), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. In addition, their photoluminescence and positional isomeric effect of the tetrahedral linker for the metal complexes have been discussed .</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Two coordination polymers have been successfully isolated under hydrothermal conditions by reactions of L<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf> or L<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Zn(II) salt, together with auxiliary linkers PDC. Our present discovery indicates that differently oriented N-atoms in the tetrahedral isomers play a significant role in assembly of their final topologies and luminescence-tuning. The successful synthesis of these complexes will provide a new means of luminescence-tuning through the selection of suitable organic building blocks.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">With the above stated aspects in mind, we purposely focused our attention on a rigid ligand, 4-([4,2′:6′,4′′-terpyridin]- 4′-yl)benzoic acid (tpba), based on the following considerations: (i) Take the advantages of a rigid backbone and a directional extending ability, which are beneficial for building up microporous framework. (ii) It has many potential coordination modes, allowing for the construction of topologically diverse coordination network. In addition, the small-sized polyoxomolybdate anion can be obtained from [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> under alkaline conditions. The integration of small-sized polyoxomolybdate anion and large-sized tpba ligand, which could surmount the steric hindrance of POMs in self-assembling processes, makes it possible to acquire POM-based microporous interpenetrated frameworks.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">In conclusion, two POM-based organic-inorganic hybrids featuring microporous interpenetrated frameworks, which are built up from metal–organic layers pillared by the [Mo<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> anions, were synthesized. The successful isolation of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> not only provides the first POM-based hybrid materials featuring twofold interpenetrated <ce:bold>hms</ce:bold> net, but also indicates that the integration of small-sized POM anions and large-sized ligands may be a promising strategy for the construction of POM-based interpenetrated frameworks, thus opening a new avenue in the exploration of multifunctional POM-based entangled frameworks.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0025" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), as a new sort of crystalline materials, have attracted lots of interest in many applications during the past decades. Recently, many efforts have been focused on the development of MOFs as heterogeneous catalysis. In this communication, we selected adenine (ad) and tetracarboxylic acid, namely 5,5′-(1,3,6,8-tetraoxobenzo[<ce:italic>Imn</ce:italic>] Li et al. (1999), He et al. (2016) phenanthroline-2,7-diyl)bis-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L), as organic linkers to assemble with Zn(II) ions to construct a novel adenine-based porous MOF. There are three different inorganic clusters in the framework, including ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, and ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N clusters. Interesting, the resultant porous MOF, namely [H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(ad)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>4DMF, retains free amino groups in the framework, which can be served as Lewis basic sites to catalyse Knoevenagel condensation reaction. The catalytic study exhibits that the as-synthesized MOF with free amino groups can be used as heterogeneous catalysis with remarkable catalytic efforts and good recycle.</ce:simple-para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">A novel adenine-based MOF has been obtained by mixing ligands.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">The resultant MOF retains free amino groups in the framework,</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">It can be used as heterogeneous catalysis for the Knoevenagel condensation reaction.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) , as a burgeoning sort of crystalline materials, have attracted lots of interest in the past decades, not only due to their diverse structures, but also because of their widely potential applications, including magnetism , gas sorption , drug delivery , chemical sensor , optical device , and heterogeneous catalysis 
<ce:italic>etc.</ce:italic> To date, lots of structures have been successfully prepared through different ligands, metal ions, and synthetic conditions. From the previous investigations, most of organic ligands in MOFs are multicarboxylic acids. Nevertheless, more and more scientists pay attention to the aromatic N-heterocycles, such as adenine, imidazole, triazole, and tetrazolate, because they are able to generate lots of interesting structures and unique properties . Particularly, adenine can be mixed with multicarboxylic acid ligands to prepare many available materials, such as bio-MOFs in Rosi's group . However, only two previous researches have been reported to obtain adenine-based porous MOFs by mixing adenine and tetracarboxylic acid ligands . Therefore, it remains a significant challenge to develop and synthesize such adenine-based MOFs.</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Inspired by the investigations on MOFs with basic functional groups, they always can be applied as catalysts for the basic catalytic reactions, such as Knoevenagel condensation reaction. Recently, some MOFs have been reported to catalyse Knoevenagel condensation reaction . Adenine, as an aromatic N-heterocycles, not only has lots of nitrogen atoms to coordinate with metal ions, but also contains amino groups as Lewis basic sites. As we know, no previous investigations have been reported to explore adenine-based MOFs to catalyse the Knoevenagel condensation reaction. Evidently, it is a quite interesting and big challenge to form new adenine-based MOFs as basic catalysts for this reaction.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">Herein, we selected a tetracarboxylic acid ligand as an organic ligand, namely 5,5′-(1,3,6,8-tetraoxobenzo[<ce:italic>Imn</ce:italic>] phenanthroline-2,7-diyl)bis-1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L) . H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L and adenine (ad) are both successfully connected with Zn(II) ions to obtain a novel adenine-based porous MOF, namely [H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]⋅[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(L)<ce:inf loc="post">1.5</ce:inf>(ad)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)]⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>4DMF (denoted as JUC-188, DMF<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide). As we expect, the resultant MOF retains free amino groups (<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>NH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>) as Lewis basic sites in the framework, which can be used as heterogeneous catalysis to catalyse Knoevenagel condensation reaction. In addition, there are three different inorganic clusters in JUC-188, including ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>, and ZnO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N clusters. The yellow crystals of JUC-188 were successfully obtained <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> heating these organic ligands and Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>⋅<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O in a mixture of DMF and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O at 135<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C after 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>days .</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">Moreover some new zirconium amino-phosphonates have been recently presented by some of us .</ce:para><ce:para view="all">The synthesis of lanthanide phosphonates has drawn the scientist’s attention for their possible optical properties. At the present it exists a large number of lanthanide derivatives obtained using different polyphosphonic and mixed carboxylate–phosphonate groups and their structures and properties has been recently collected in a review from Mao . The reaction of lanthanides with different building blocks containing polydentate phosphonic and/or carboxylic groups has led to a class of layered and open-framework materials with a remarkable high structural variability and with luminescent properties . In that review it has been pointed-out that the number of structurally characterized lanthanide phosphonates is relatively low because of the general high insolubility of these derivatives in water and organic solvents, making difficult the obtainment of single crystals.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The topic of this communication is the preparation, characterization and a preliminary study of the properties of a new pillared cerium(IV) mixed sulfate–amino diphosphonate with formula Ce<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)[(O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)–NC<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">18</ce:inf>N–(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (hereafter <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) . <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been obtained under hydrothermal conditions as pale-yellow microcrystalline powder starting from Ce(SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and N,N′-bisphosphonomethyl bipiperidine acid (see

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Large cadmium chalcogenido clusters C2 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>) and C1 (Cd<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf>) CdQ (<ce:italic>Q</ce:italic> = S, Se) with photoactive dye cations [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> are prepared under solvothermal conditions (Phen = 1,10-phenanthroline, Bpy = 2,2′-bipyridine). All the C2 compounds are 3-D polymeric structures, while the C1 compounds are discrete Cd17 clusters. Two of the 3-D C2 clusters can be considered as homosized nano CdSe@CdS core–shell particles (2.0 nm radius) with Cd<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>Se<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf> core. Charge-transfer interaction is found between [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations and CdQ cluster anions. The photocurrent behaviors indicate that (1) the current intensities are greatly increased for the dye cation functionalized C<ce:italic>n</ce:italic> clusters, (2) the current intensities of the 3-D C2 clusters are larger than those of the discrete C1 clusters, and (3) the current intensities of the selenide clusters are larger than those of the sulfide clusters.</ce:simple-para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0085">Electrode preparation and electrochemical measurement</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">All the solvents used in electrochemical measurements were dried by a standard method and distilled before use, or the chromatographically pure reagent. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were performed on a CHI650 electrochemistry workstation, using a three-electrode system with a Pt plate working electrode, a Pt wire auxiliary electrode and a saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as reference electrode (in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN with 0.1 mol L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> Bu<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>NClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>). The photocurrent experiments were performed using a quartz cell equipped with the sample coated ITO glass working electrode, a Pt plate auxiliary electrode and a SCE reference electrode, An aqueous solution of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (100 mL, 0.1 mol L<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) was used as the medium in a quartz cell. The photoelectrodes of the compounds were prepared by powder coating method. As a typical procedure, the crystals of compounds (0.005 mmol) were ground and pressed uniformly on an ITO glass (100 Ω/□) with 0.785 cm<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> effective area (Ø 1.0 cm). A 150 W high pressure xenon lamp, positioned 15 cm away the surface of the ITO electrode, was employed as a light source. The lamp was kept on continuously, and a manual shutter was used to block exposure of the electrode to the light. The electrode was typically irradiated over 0−400 s with interval 20 s. The applied voltage is 0.0 V for photocurrent measurements. Band-pass filters (380, 400, and 420 nm) were used to cut part or all of the UV light for the study of the effect of wavelength.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0090">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0095">Synthesis and characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">All materials reported here were synthesized under solvothermal conditions from the Cd(SPh)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The S(-II) and Se(-II) sources were thiourea and selenourea, respectively. The reaction temperatures and solvents for the synthesis of C2 clusters were different from those for the synthesis of C1 clusters. In general, high condensed phase is obtained at high temperature and high volume ratio of the acetonitrile/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (modifying the solubility of the clusters). To be specific, the C1 cluster was obtained from the mixed solvent of acetonitrile/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (3:1 in volume) at 85 °C, while pure acetonitrile and 110 °C were suitable for the growth of C2 crystals. The optimized conditions of crystallization of these compounds are described in experimental section. The anion structures of all the six compounds were accurately characterized by X-ray single crystal diffraction. Because there are too many heavy atoms in the large clusters (the largest volume of the cell is about 130 thousands) and the serious disorder of the organic moieties, the cations are not completely solved. The [Ru(Phen/bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cations or Ru<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> (fragment) are found in all the structures of the compounds. The cations have been further characterized by spectra (460 nm MLCT band of [Ru(Phen/Bpy)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> cation) and electrospray mass spectrum analysis (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>: 321.25, ).  shows the TEM images of the aggregated nanoclusters. The XRD patterns of the microcrystal bulk samples along with those simulated from the data of single-crystal analysis are give in .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this work, we selectively chose dipyridyl-amide ligands {[N<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>,N<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-bis(pyridin-3-ylmethyl) cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxamide)(L)} as organic linkers and polydentate O-donor H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid) to construction of MOFs, based on the following considerations: (i) up to date, the L ligand has not been utilized to construct MOFs until this work; (ii) the ligand L possesses a flexible backbone containing bifunctional binding sites (both pyridyl groups), as well as a strong capacity for hydrogen bonding from amide groups, which is anticipated to play a vital role in the assembly of flexible MOFs;  (iii) deprotonation of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC can produce multiple products of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>BTC, HBTC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>, and BTC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup>, with the number of potential donor oxygen atoms varying from one to six, are all versatile ligands for the construction of novel high-dimensional metal–organic hybrid compounds ; (iv) the high symmetry that it exhibits may be useful for the crystal growing of the product formed .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">To extend our understanding on the silver(I) coordination chemistry of thioethers, we focus on an acyclic bidentate thioether ligand, 1,3-bis(methylthiomethyl)benzene (L), which adopts three types of ligand conformations while coordinating with metals (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>), and herein wish to report on the versatile self-assembly of this ligand with various silver(I) salts. It is revealed that new, diverse silver-thioether coordination networks could be attained based upon the use of different silver salts, and the counter anions (NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, PF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> and SbF<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>) were found to significantly affect the coordination modes (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>) and hence the supramolecular structures of the products.</ce:para>

L was chosen in this work, owing to its diverse molecular conformations and coordination versatility to silver(I) (), and that the ability of this type of ligands to form network polymers with silver(I) has been previously demonstrated from its structural analogs .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sect0075">X-ray data collection and structure determinations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Suitable X-ray single crystals diffraction data of <ce:bold>1–6</ce:bold> were selected and mounted on a Rigaku MM-007/Saturn 70 with graphite monochromatic Mo-<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles . All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL . Metal atoms in each complex was located from the <ce:italic>E</ce:italic>-maps and other non-hydrogen atoms were located in successive difference Fourier syntheses and refined with anisotropic thermal parameters on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. The hydrogen atoms were generated theoretically onto the specific atoms and refined isotropically. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in <ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
, and selected bond lengths and angles are listed in .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sect0130">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0195" view="all">In this work, a series of coordination polymers based on equatorial 2D (4,4) layers have been successfully synthesized from reactions of the <ce:bold>bib</ce:bold> ligand with six kinds of manganese salts. Owing to the diversities on the coordination affinity of counterions, the equatorial 2D layers are further bridged by different linkers to form a 3D homoleptic α-Po framework (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), unchanged 2D (4,4) layer (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>) and 3D heteroleptic α-Po framework, respectively. Thus the coordination affinity of counterion directly controls the final topological framework, especially the dimensionality. Furthermore, parallel and incline interpenetration is exhibited in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively, which shows that the small counterion is liable to the entanglement. Finally, different porosity of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> reveals that the large counterion is beneficial to porous coordination polymers. Moreover, magnetic studies display that weak ferromagnetic coupling is conducted by the μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> ion within the 1D SO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>–Mn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> chain of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Continuing our interest in the construction of coordination polymers containing pyridinylcarboxamides and thiocyanate anions, we have used the known ligand <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-di(pyridin-3-yl)pyridine-3,5-dicarboxamide (DPBA-3) (Scheme S1) to probe the formation of supramolecular structures. The relative flexibility of DPBA-3 ligand may make the coligand effects of thiocyanate possible and facilitates the formation of high dimensional architectures. The metal ions with <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration, for example Zn<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, usually have potential application in optical areas, such as fluorescence probe and nonlinear optical materials . Herein, we report the syntheses, structures and photoluminescence of four complexes, [Cd(DPBA-3)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cd(DPBA-3)(DMF)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·DMF (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(DPBA-3)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·2DMF·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) and [Zn(DPBA-3)(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:section-title>[Cd(DPBA-3)(DMF)(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·DMF (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Crystallographic analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> consists of one Cd(II) ion, one DPBA-3 ligand, two nitrate, one coordinated and one non-coordinated DMF molecules. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a, the central Cd(II) atom is seven-coordinated with distorted pentagonal bipyramid geometry by three oxygen atoms (O4, O7 and O8) from two different nitrate anions, one oxygen atom (O3) from a DMF and three nitrogen atoms (N1, N3B, N5A) from three distinct DPBA-3 ligands. The atoms N1 and N3B occupy the apical positions of the pentagonal bipyramid and the other five coordinating atoms form the basal plane. It is noteworthy that the two nitrate ions in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have different coordination modes: one is <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup>-monodentate and the other one is <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-chelate. The Cd1–N bond distances are ranging from 2.328(5) to 2.450(5)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with the N–Cd–N bond angles varying from 79.9(2) to 160.9(2). The Cd1–O bond distances are ranging from 2.313(5) to 2.631(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with the O–Cd–O bond angles varying from 49.2(2) to 163.2(2) (). In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> all three pyridine units of each DPBA-3 participate the coordination with Cd(II) atoms; while in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> only two pyridine units in one DPBA-3 ligand take part in the coordination with the metal atoms. In <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> each DPBA-3 bridges three Cd(II) atoms to form a 2D structure (b). If both DPBA-3 ligand and Cd1 atom are considered as 3-connected nodes, the 2D layer can be simplified into a (6,3) net  as shown in Fig. S2a. The adjacent 2D layers are linked together by N–H⋯O hydrogen bonds between amide function groups and the nitrate anions to generate a 3D structure (Fig. S2b and ).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(DPBA-3)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]·2DMF·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">When thiocyanate salt was introduced to the reaction with cadmium(II) nitrate and DPBA-3 ligand, complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was isolated. There are two crystallographically different Cd(II) atoms, in which one is sitting on an inversion center, one DPBA-3, three thiocyanate anions, one non-coordinated DMF and two water molecules in the asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>a, each Cd(II) atom is six-coordinated with distorted octahedral coordination geometry by two nitrogen atoms from two DPBA-3 ligands, two sulfur atoms from two thiocyanate anions and two nitrogen atoms from other two thiocyanate anions. The coordinating nitrogen atoms from DPBA-3 ligands occupy the apical positions of the octahedron and the other four coordinating atoms from the thiocyanate anions form the basal plane. In complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, each DPBA-3 ligand coordinated to three Cd(II) atoms, leading to the formation of a 1D ladder chain structure along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> direction (Fig. S3). On the other hand, the thiocyanate anions in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> adopt an end-to-end μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-bridging mode, and link Cd(II) atoms together to form a doubly SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> bridged 1D chain structure, which is composed of eight-membered Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> rings. The macrocycle constructed by two Cd1 and two SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions (S3 and S3A) shows stable chair conformation, and the centroid of this ring is the center of inversion. The macrocycle containing Cd1, Cd2 and two SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions (S1 and S2) has half-chair confirmation (b) since Cd2 and these two SCN<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> are essentially coplanar with a deviation of 0.039 Å.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">From 1970s onward much research has been concentrated on metal organophosphonates due to their potential or practical applications in ion exchange , diagnostic agents  and optics . Particularly, numerous porous materials have been produced using organodiphosphonate ligands (O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PRPO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, R=organic units) with variable lengths and shapes of the organic units . Recently, Clearfield et al.  used nitrilotri(methylphosphonic), <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-(phosphonomethyl)imniodiacetic and <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-bis(phosphonomethyl)aminoacetic acids to produce some novel compounds. Metal alkylenediphosphonate (O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>n</ce:italic>=1–3) have been extensively studied in previous work . However, among metal 1,4-butylenediphosphonates only the structure of Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>[(O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PC<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O has been determined by X-ray powder diffraction . Herein, we report single crystal structures of five transition-metal 1,4-butylenediphosphonates: zero-dimensional [{Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [{Ni(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), stepped chain [{Cu(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}{HO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>H}]<ce:inf loc="post">
<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>

<ce:italic>n</ce:italic>
</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>) and [{Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}{O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>P(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>PO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]<ce:inf loc="post">

<ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">1,4-Butylene-diphosphonic acid was prepared according to the reported method . Other chemicals were reagent grade quality and obtained from commercial sources without further purification. The elements were analyzed with Vario EL III element analyzer and UV-1100 spectrophotometer. Infrared spectra were obtained on a Nicolet Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">The crystals can also be obtained by the following procedure. 0.1016 g (0.7455 mmol) ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, 0.0522 g (0.0239 mmol) 1,4-butylenediphosphonic acid and a small amount of 1 M HCl were mixed in 20.0 ml distilled water. Five-milliliter DMSO was added to the solution. After the solution was stirred homogeneously, a small amount of white precipitate appeared when the pH of the solution was adjusted to 2.84 with 1.000 mol l<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> NaOH. Colorless block-like crystals appeared after the solution was filtered into a 50-ml flask and kept in the ambient environment for 6 months. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>: C 15.13, H 4.445, Zn 20.59%; Found: C 15.25, H 4.513, Zn 21.68%. IR (KBr pellet, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3452s, 3373s, 3255m, 2966w, 2947w, 2914w, 2879w, 2380m, 1792m, 1647w, 1460m, 1410m, 1333m, 1275w, 1201s, 1178m, 1132vs, 1092s, 1053vs, 1009m, 951vs, 775s, 721m, 552s, 465m, 409m.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">In conclusion, we have synthesized suitable single crystals of five transition-metal 1,4-butylenediphosphonates and determined their structures by X-ray single crystal diffraction. The structures are diverse, including zero-dimensional, chain-like and three-dimensional framework types.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st0005">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Two novel Cu-based coordination polymers [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>]·(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) containing the 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC) ligand have been solvothermally synthesized. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits a three dimensional framework with 1D rhombic channels, which can be simplified into a novel (3, 4)-connected network with Schläfli symbol of (6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.14<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)(6<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>.8)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is one dimensional chain which packed with each other via π–π and hydrogen-bonding interactions to construct a three dimensional supramolecular structure. As the first example related to Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) coordination polymers based on H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligands, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are further studied by elemental analyses, IR spectroscopy and thermogravimetric analyses.</ce:simple-para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Herein, we choose 2-(pyridine-3-yl)-1H-4,5-imidazoledicarboxylate (H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC) as the organic ligand for reaction with Cu ions to construct novel MOFs based on the following reasons: (1) H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC can form various coordination modes through partially or fully deprotonated to H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>PyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup>, HPyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">2<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> and PyImDC<ce:sup loc="post">3<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>−</ce:sup> by controlling the pH values of reaction system. (2) H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC possesses multiple coordinate sites involving one pyridine N atom, two imidazole N atoms and four carboxylate O atoms, moreover, the different coordinate sites display different coordination activities. (3) There are a limited number of MOFs based on the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligand .</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Taking all of this into consideration, we report the syntheses and structures of two Cu-MOFs, [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·(NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(HPyImDC)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(C<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>)] (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), which represent the first example of Cu (I) and Cu (I, II) MOFs assembled from H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC ligand.</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Accordingly, the H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC was prepared according to reported procedures . All other reagents were unprocessed as received from commercial sources. The reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC, Cu(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, in a N,N′-dimethylformamide solution in the presence of NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O afforded the synthesis of pale yellow crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has been solvothermally synthesized by the reaction of H<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>PyImDC and CuI in a N,N′-dimethylformamide/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution in the presence of 1,2-diaminopropane (see supporting information). The detailed crystallographic data and selected bond lengths and angles for the two compounds are listed in Tables S1 and S2, respectively.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">Compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit similar IR absorbances around 1600–1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, which are ascribed to the vibrations of the C–C and C–N bonds in the pyridyl and imidazoledicarboxylate groups. Around 3500–2500<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup>, the band of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is different with compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
. The bands between 3454<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> and 3264<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>1</ce:sup> are associated with the hydrogen bonding interactions of carboxylic acid in the structure of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (Fig. S6) .</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0060" view="all">It is very interesting that the Cu(I) compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was prepared by Cu(II) salt and Cu(I,II) compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was prepared by Cu(I) salt. As the reduction of Cu(II) is sensitive to the reaction temperature and pH, Cu(II) is prone to be reduced to Cu(I) under the right condition (appropriate temperature and pH) . In the preparation of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the Cu(II) ions are reduced in the mixed systems containing NH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL) at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. For the same reason, Cu(I) is apt to be oxidized to Cu(II). In the preparation of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the partial Cu(I) ions are oxidized in the mixed systems containing 1,2-diaminopropane (80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL) at 140<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Concluding remarks</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0155" view="all">2,2′-Oxydiacetate has proved to bridge Ln(III) and different divalent cations. In this work, this interesting series has been expanded with the preparation of nine novel compounds [{Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>}{CaLn(oda)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>}<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (Ln<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Y, Eu, Tb, Dy, Ho, Er, Tm, Yb, Lu). The compounds are rare metal-organic structures containing isolated [Ca(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> units.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The experimental and theoretical efforts have recently been focused on the rational design and controlled synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) due to not only their potential applications but also their intriguing versatile architectures . One of the most effective ways is the appropriate choice of well-designed molecular building blocks (MBB) and metal ions or clusters to achieve the targeting assemblies of such extended crystalline systems with desired structural features and/or physicochemical properties . Although MBBs with 2-fold linear , 3-fold  and 4-fold  symmetries are popular choices for obtaining the well-defined MOFs, 2-fold non-linear MBB is rarely studied. This lies in two aspects: bigger steric hindrance and necessity of the auxiliary ligand known as pillar to sustain the architecture . Compared with BDC , non-linear FDA possesses two advantages as the MBB: the high openness net with the flexible bond angle of two carboxyl (~<ce:hsp sp="0.10"></ce:hsp>126°) and the polarity owing to the oxygen atom of ring, which is potentially applied for gas-storage and gas-separation. Due to the non-linear FDA as the MBB, the choice of the pillar would effect the structural formations — porosity and interpenetration. With respect to the steric hindrance and electronic effect, the flexible and rigid pillars are employed to the construction of structure, respectively. In this work, two novel MOFs have been synthesized, in which the flexible bpp results in the robust porous [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·(FDA)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·bpp·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), and the rigid bipy in 3-/3-D interpenetrated [Zn·(FDA)·bipy]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>).</ce:para>
['else']

<ce:para view="all">Owing to the synergistic interaction between the metal–organic and inorganic components, this class of compounds reveals some remarkable properties. We are currently exploring to design and develop organic–inorganic hybrid materials by the amalgamation of cage-like mixed-valence vanadium clusters with metal–organic complexes. The mixed-valence vanadium clusters that fuse paramagnetic transition metal complexes might be of interest in molecular magnetism . During this ongoing effort, different paramagnetic metal ions have been introduced into the reaction system, such as manganese (II), cobalt (II) and nickel (II). As a result, magnetic materials are obtained through combining paramagnetic metal ions and <mml:math altimg="si11.gif" overflow="scroll">

In this paper, we describe the synthesis and characterization of hybrid materials <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. The magnetic properties of compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are reported as well.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The syntheses of the compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>′ , <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> and the spherical mixed-valence host–guest V15 cluster <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig9"></ce:float-anchor>. The {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} core has been observed in some well characterized compounds containing the same numbers of reduced vanadium (IV) sites . The basic {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} shell in all these compounds is built up from 16 VO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> distorted square pyramids that share edges and corners through two μ<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>- and 20 μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-oxygen atoms, respectively. The shell could encapsulate Cl<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> ions and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules that exert templating effects on the electronic and framework structures of the host metal-oxide shells. However, we have successfully obtained <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with a suitable fluoride and bromide ion source (HF and HBr) in the reaction. Compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is the first example of hybrid materials that contain a [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>F]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is the first example of hybrid materials that contain a [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Br]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> cluster. Furthermore, the [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>F]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> and [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Br]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> clusters present different numbers of reduced vanadium (IV) sites compared to the reported {V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>} core.</ce:para>
