<ce:para view="all">Thinking about the comparability of the first-row transition metals, different paramagnetic metal ions Co(II), Ni(II) and Mn(II) were introduced into the reaction system. Compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> were prepared under similar conditions. In order to study the effect of the organic ligands on the inorganic oxide microstructure, we intended to replace 4,4′-bpy with other organic ligands containing nitrogen (i.e., 2,2′-bpy and en). Based on this thought, compound <ce:bold>5</ce:bold> was obtained by reaction of 2,2′-bpy with NaVO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and HCl in acidic aqueous solution (pH 5.5). Though ethanol is not necessary for the formation of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, a large number of parallel experiments indicate that the presence of a small quantity of ethanol could improve the yield and purity of these compounds.</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para view="all">Significantly, the presence of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> is necessary for the formation of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. When the reactions were performed in the absence of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, nothing could be obtained except for some yellow precipitation, likely corresponding to complexes of V<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>. Consequently, it appears that Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> exerts the role of reducer for V<ce:sup loc="post">V</ce:sup>. Taking into account the characteristic comparability of identical group elements, we replaced Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> with an equal amount of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> or Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> in the reaction system. When Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was used, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> cannot be obtained. However, compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> could be obtained when Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> was used instead of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, but at a cost of the yield and crystal quality of these compounds. It can be concluded that the reductive ability of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> and Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> are comparative and both are weaker than that of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>SO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, which indicates that weak reducer is propitious to the formation of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>. During our experiments, we also found that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> cannot be obtained when some other common reducers such as oxalic acid, ethylenediamine and hydrazinium sulfate were used instead of Na<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TeO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">If 4,4′-bpy was substituted by en, compound [Ni(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>] was synthesized in our reaction system. The mixed-valence vanadium oxide [V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> layers contain infinite zigzag chains composed of edge-sharing VO<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf> square pyramids. Adjacent chains are connected through corner-shared VO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> tetrahedra to form a layer structure. Compound [Ni(en)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>][V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>] has been synthesized in our reaction system, though it can be obtained under other conditions . Several different polyoxovanadate clusters, such as [V<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>X]<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup>, [V<ce:inf loc="post">15</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">36</ce:inf>Cl]<ce:sup loc="post">6−</ce:sup> and [V<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">14</ce:inf>]<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup>, have been obtained by using organic ligands with different functionalities, which indicate that the organic components could modify the inorganic oxide microstructure. So under similar conditions, hybrid materials containing different polyoxometallate clusters are prepared by selecting different organic ligands.</ce:para>

<ce:para view="all">These results prompted us to choose structurally similar ligands that could engage in multiple, simultaneous coordination modes and to use such ligands in the assembly of novel coordination polymers. We identified 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxate (pytac) (<ce:float-anchor refid="sch2"></ce:float-anchor>
) as one ligand of suitable length and have begun to use it in the preparation of new coordination frameworks . This ligand is similar to pca and ppca in that there exists a terminal and a chelating nitrogen coordination site that can be used for coordinating to metal centers. However, while in the case of pca and ppca the coordination sites are in a linear arrangement with respect to each other, in the case of pytac, the chelating nitrogen is no longer exactly opposite the terminal nitrogen, but rather is oriented approximately perpendicular to it. This spatial arrangement of the nitrogens enables the ligand to function as a ‘bent’ spacer . The ‘bent’ orientation of the ligand's N-donor atoms, as well as the presence of an additional Lewis base site in the form of a ring-sulfur atom, lead us to believe that the use of this ligand could yield equally, if not more, diverse structures compared to those containing the pca or ppca ligands. In this paper we report on our continued results with the use of this ligand that has yielded three new structures: two single-metal coordination polymers <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, and a mixed-metal coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. Their syntheses and structures are detailed within.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Powder X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/max 2100 diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>1.5418<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). For single-crystal diffraction measurements X-ray intensity data were measured at 150(1) or 293(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). Raw data frame integration and Lp corrections were performed with SAINT+. Analysis of the data showed negligible crystal decay during collection. Direct methods structure solution, difference Fourier calculations and full-matrix least-squares refinement against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> were performed with SHELXTL . Data from structures <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were corrected for absorption effects with SADABS . Final unit cell parameters were determined by least-squares refinement of 7483 (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 2988 (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), and 4742 (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) reflections with <ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>5<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>) from each data set.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Structure description</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The reactions of the pytac ligand with cobalt nitrate, ammonium vanadate, or cadmium iodide under solvothermal conditions resulted in crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, whose structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Structure <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 3D structure that contains 1D hexameric water channels that constitute 14.4% of the unit cell volume. Structure <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> contains metal–organic 1D chains/layers that are connected to inorganic hydrogen-bonded 2D layers of Co(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>V<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>. Structure <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> contains infinite 1D chains, similar to the metal–organic chains in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, that hydrogen bond to neighboring chains, via uncoordinated water molecules. Crystal data, data collection parameters, and refinement statistics for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>
. Relevant interatomic distances and bond angles for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are listed in <ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl3"></ce:float-anchor>
, respectively.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">We have successfully synthesized three novel coordination polymers using 2-(4-pyridyl)thiazole-4-carboxylate (pytac), cobalt, cadmium, and vanadium oxide. The structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> demonstrate the effectiveness of this asymmetric ligand's ability to generate new and diverse 3D coordination framework structures. Future work will explore the use of this ligand in the assembly of additional mixed-metal frameworks.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="st045">Catalytic epoxidation process</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">In a typical procedure for the epoxidation reaction, to a mixture of catalyst (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg) and substrate (8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in chloroform (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>ml), <ce:italic>tert</ce:italic>-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 14.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) as oxidant was added. TBHP (70% in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) was dried prior to use according to the procedure described in the literature . The mixture was refluxed for appropriate time and the final products were quantified with isooctane (8.75<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) as internal standard.</ce:para>

<ce:sup loc="post">I</ce:sup>Cl(4,4′-bipy)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>][Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>(1,10-phen)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mo<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>]) (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">The prepared crystals were tested as catalyst in the liquid-phase epoxidation of some olefins and allylic alcohols using TBHP as oxidant. As seen in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0015"></ce:float-anchor>, the prepared catalyst can act as active and selective catalyst in the epoxidation of the selected olefins and allylic alcohols. 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol as a representative substrate was chosen for the early exploration of the reaction conditions. The obtained results for the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol with TBHP within various reaction times are presented in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>. It is evident that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol proceeds rapidly in the first 30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min with the conversion of 85%, but then it continues more slowly until it is mostly oxidized within 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h beyond which no considerable oxidation occurs. Blank experiment performed in the absence of the catalyst gave low conversion (28%) after 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h under the same conditions. In order to provide a better insight into the catalytic activity of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the crystals of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were prepared according to the procedure described in the literature  and utilized as heterogeneous catalyst for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol. The results (shown in ) revealed that the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol in the presence of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> proceeds slowly within 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h.</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0095" view="all">To investigate the influence of oxidant and solvent on the catalytic epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol, the reaction was carried out with TBHP and CHP in different solvents (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). In all three solvents, higher conversion for the epoxidation of 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol was obtained in the presence of TBHP in comparison with CHP. The reason may be that the peroxidic oxygen in TBHP has more electrophilic character. Moreover, the results indicate that 3-methyl-2-butene-1-ol exhibits more reactivity in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> rather than CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN. This can be explained with coordination ability of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN that inhibits the reaction by competing with the oxidant to occupy the coordination sites of the catalyst. These results are consistent with previous reports .</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sect0035">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sect0040">Synthesis of 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">5-hydroxy-isophthalic acid diethyl ester (2.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and anhydrous K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 22<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were put in a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL round bottom flask under nitrogen atmosphere and treated with 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of dry DMF. The reaction mixture was stirred for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 70<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C followed by addition of 1,4-dichlorobutane (0.64<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred for 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in an oil-bath at 80<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. At the end of the period, the solution was allowed to cool to room temperature and then poured into ice-water (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) with vigorous stirring that afforded a white precipitated (tetraethyl 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy)-diisophthalate) which was collected by filtration, washed with water three times, and dried in air. Then the tetraethyl 5,5′-(butane-1,4-diyl)-bis(oxy) diisophthalate (2.65<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was hydrolyzed by refluxing it with 95% ethanol solution for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h followed by addition of NaOH (0.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in an oil-bath. Finally, the resulting solution was poured into ice-water (100<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) with vigorous stirring and was acidified carefully with 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M HCl to obtain a white precipitate. After keeping it overnight in the freezer, the white solid was collected by filtration and dried at air. Yield: 2.02<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (96%). FT-IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3096.35(s), 2961(s), 1697(s), 1597(m), 1462(m), 1402(m), 1273(m), 1126(w), 1051(m), 909(w), 759(w), 668(w), 530(w), 479(w).</ce:para>

For compounds <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>, the measured PXRD patterns closely match the simulated patterns generated from the results of Single-Crystal Diffraction data, indicating pure phases of 1–3 products (). The IR spectra of H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>L and compound <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> also show characteristic the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibrations of the carboxylate groups are observed in the ranges of 1597–1621 and 1346–1402<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively  ().</ce:para>

<ce:para id="p0065" view="all">The bib ligand connects two tetrahedral [CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] centres in the 1D metal-imidazolyl chains through the N atoms of the imidazolyl rings, creating a separation of 13.61<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å to form a V-shaped chain as shown in (b). In the 1D structure, the flexible bib exhibits <ce:italic>anti–gauche–anti</ce:italic> conformation and the dihedral angle between two imidazolyl rings is 62.015°. In compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, each L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand connects to four Co atoms at four angles in a μ<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>: η<ce:sup loc="post">0</ce:sup> monodentate modes and connects the [CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedra in a 2D network conformation, characterized by the C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> torsion angle of 180° in the central part of the L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and the dihedral angle between two phenyl rings is 0°, but the torsion angle of C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf>-O…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> O-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2,</ce:inf> CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-O, and CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>…O-C<ce:inf loc="post">phenyl</ce:inf> is 157.94°, 83.55°, 180°, 83.55°, and 157.94°, respectively. The two phenyl rings of L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> is coplanar, but a great changes have taken place in the -(CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>- of L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand ((c)). In this compound, the 2D network structure formed by L<ce:sup loc="post">4−</ce:sup> ligand and [CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] tetrahedra was linked by the 1D metal-imidazolyl chains to form a 3D framework with channels (18.1567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×24.0957<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) (<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>
(a)). Longer length of co-ligand (bib) in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> than that of co-ligand (bpy) in compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> resulted in that compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibit larger channels of individual 3D frameworks in size (18.1567<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×24.0957<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) than those (15.0977<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å×22.2255<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Correspondingly, compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> with larger channels size accommodate more H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules than compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The 3D grid allows each frameworks to be penetrated by two other independent frameworks to form the interesting 3D 3-fold interpenetrating frameworks with isolated water molecules occupying the neutral channels ((b), S5).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0010">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="abspara0010" view="all">Three new mixed-ligand divalent coordination polymers (CPs) {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(1,4-bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>]·2DMF}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), {[Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)(2,6-ndc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·3DMF}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(2,6-ndc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]}<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) [<ce:bold>L</ce:bold> = 9,10-di(pyridine-4-yl)anthracene, 1,4-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid, 2,6-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndc = 2,6-naphthalenedicarboxylic acid] have been prepared and well characterized by elemental analyses, infrared spectroscopy, single-crystal X-ray diffraction techniques, powder X-ray diffraction patterns and thermogravimetric analyses. The crystal structure analyses of coordination polymers (CPs) reveal that all the complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> have the three-dimensional (3D) coordination networks. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> can be simplified as a <ce:bold>
<ce:italic>sqc3</ce:italic>
</ce:bold> 3D 8-connected framework with the point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">24</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>). Particularly, in the presence of the linear 2,6-H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndc auxiliary ligand, a double-deck interpenetrating <ce:bold>
<ce:italic>pcu</ce:italic>
</ce:bold> 3D network of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is assembled by 6-connecting framework with the point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">12</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>). Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> exhibits a <ce:bold>
<ce:italic>ttd</ce:italic>
</ce:bold> 3D 5-connected net with a point symbol of (4<ce:sup loc="post">6</ce:sup>·6<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>). Further, the solid-state luminescent properties of the complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were measured and studied at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">9,10-dibromoanthracene (2.0 g, 5.95 mmol), Pyridine-4-boronic acid (2.4 g, 17.8 mmol), K<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (11.6 g, 35.5 mmol), Pd(PPh<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.68 g, 0.59 mmol) and PhMe:DMF (6:1, 300 ml) were successively add to a 500 ml flask. Under N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> conditions, the reaction mixture was heated to 130 °C in the dark for 48 h. After the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature and filtered to remove the catalyst by diatomaceous earth. The removal of solvent under reduced pressure yielded crude solid. The crude solid was dissolved in dichloromethane and washed with distilled water, then dried over anhydrous magnesium sulfate and concentrate dichloromethane under reduced pressure. A HCl solution was added and adjusted the pH to 2–3. Solid precipitation was produced and then filtered, the solid was dissolved in water and adjusted the pH to 8–9 by the addition of NaOH (10 M) solution. The pale yellow solid thus obtained by filtration and was washed with distilled water. Yield (1.4 g, 70%). MS (333.1387). <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>H NMR (CDCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-<ce:italic>d</ce:italic>6, <ce:italic>δ</ce:italic>ppm): 8.879 (m, 4H, pyridine-2), 7.609 (m, 4H, anthracene-1), 7.456 (m, 4H, pyridine-3), 7.405 (t, 4H, anthracene-2).</ce:para>

<ce:section-title id="sectitle0075">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="sectitle0080">Syntheses and general characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">Despite solvothermal reaction being in a “black box” and being somewhat complicated, it has been proven to be an effective method in preparing MOCPs. A series of experiments were carried out in order to get the optimal reaction temperatures and solvents for single crystal growth. Herein, complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were successfully prepared by solvothermal reactions at 70–95 °C. The crystal structures of these coordination polymers were analyzed in terms of network geometries, the thermogravimetric analyses and fluorescence properties were studied on base of their structural aspects. The pertinent crystallographic details for complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold> were given in  and  respectively.</ce:para>

The asymmetric vibration at 1675 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndc disappeared after conversion to complexes <ce:bold>1–3</ce:bold>, indicating the full deprotonation of carboxylate groups in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>ndc.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In the past decade, the study on the design and synthesis of novel cluster polymers achieved considerable attention due to the structural unpredictability (i.e., which cluster will form and what is the linking mode between the clusters and organic moieties) and potential functional properties in some fields as optics (containing groups IB, IIB or rare-earth metal), electrochemistry based on the metals with many oxidation states, catalysis (poly-acid, zeolite or zeolite-like materials), electrical conductivity (containing group IVA metal) and magnetism . As far as the construction of cluster polymers is concerned, on the one hand, the inorganic salts being prone to form the clusters, such as oxides, halides or sulfides are usually used as the inorganic precursors to form inorganic subunits (SUs) . On the other hand, the literature show that three types of bridges can extend the inorganic SUs into poly-nuclear or high-dimensional (D) cluster polymers: (i) inorganic bridge. With various organic ammines as guest species or organic templating agents, the SUs interact with each other through covalent M–O (X or S) bonds (or through sharing the corner, edge or/and face) between the SUs, producing new polymeric clusters. This is the basic constructing conception of zeolite and zeolite-like materials . (ii) Organic bridge, the most common method. Up to now, lots of bridging organic ligands with N/O/S donors have been chosen to extend the SUs into the 1-D, 2-D, 3-D cluster polymers via covalent interactions or a combination of covalent and non-covalent interactions . (iii) Metal complex bridge. This strategy has been extensively adopted when preparing high-D poly-acids . Some recent reports show that it is being extended to the construction of metal–halo cluster polymers .</ce:para>
['else']

Categorize the paragraph given. Select one or more categories from "synthesis condition" and "property". If the paragraph does not fit into either of these categories, choose "else". "property" paragraph must include specific numerical value of the property. ex) surface area of 2500 m2/g

<ce:para view="all">Compared with the Ni(II), the structure of copper–halo clusters is richer due to the diversity of coordination geometry of Cu(I). With bridging N-donor ligands, CuX can form various neutral oligomeric and polymeric clusters, namely so-called SUs. The most reports are rhombic dimer, cubane tetramer, zigzag-type and staircase chains . Further, these SUs are extended by organic bridges into the 1-D, 2-D or 3-D networks. It was reported that the size of organic ligands determines the mode of the SUs. In general, the bulky ligands as 4,4′-bpy favor the formation of discrete SUs, whereas the small ones favor the polymeric SUs. In compound [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(tri)] (tri<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1,3,5-triazine) , the castellated CuI single chain was reported, while in compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, a new castellated CuI double chain was observed in reaction with the pip.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Synthetic analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">It deserves to note that the pH level of the system plays a key role in the course of crystal growth. The optimal pH values are 6 for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 9 for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively. The reasonable explanation may be: (i) in a acid condition, the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> ion will be disproportionated to the Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion and the Cu metal. (ii) In a basic condition, the Ni<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup> ion exists in the Ni(OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> form.</ce:para>
